author: Billy Liu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
review_content: Performance:Feels very sluggish - was expecting somewhat similar performance to my older 2015 Fire 7 but this actually felt slower on the same latest version firmware. This tablet is best when not utilizing any data-heavy or graphic-heavy applications as it will be a major slowdown.Great as a on-the-go video player, ebook reader, and general tablet for trips where you wouldn't want to lose your primary tablet.

review_content: While I am happy with my new Kindle I am extremely angry that if you have an old one that used to belong to someone else the supposed tech support people fail to understand that as the person who did not initially own the older kindle and has no access to the password for the email attached to that kindle, they still told me to go ahead and DEREGISTER when I had repeatedly asked are you sure thats a good idea? I ended up with a Kindle I can longer use to do anything with except use Safari.The new kindle fire is very light in weight, I didnt get an 8 or above just a 7 inch again, sage green color on back.IF I can get the issue fixed I’ll have better to say about Tech support and more about the new kindle.

review_content: Do not buy if you have kids and want your Amazon Prime purchase history to be hidden!  It shows every single thing you ever bought and even your browsing history! When it is in CHILD MODE that should be completely disabled.  I have to decide what the heck to do now because I got 2 as gifts for my kids.  They are so excited. author: Beowulf
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2019
review_content: Another update - DO NOT BUY THE TABLET! It has serious flaws that I pointed out to Amazon. They said they would fix it and get back to me the following week. The 6 MONTH anniversary of their promise to get right back to me is here, I till contact them regularly and they either lie to me or don't contact me in return. THEY ARE HIDING ITS FLAWS TO MAKE A FORTUNE OFF OF PEOPLE AS STUPID AS I WAS, WHO ACTUALLY BUY THIS JUNK. Amazon has changed their policy of standing behind their products, so don't judge them by the way that they used to do things. Judge them by their current attitudes and policies. You don't need the book if you avoid buying the tablet in the first place.Wrote the above as a review of a book about the Fire 7. Understandably, Amazon refused to post it, so I'll add it here and see if they will be honest about the situation and finally address it.Update - It is now mid November and I'm still waiting for Amazon to keep their word. Instead, it is now 6 MONTHS SINCE PURCHASE AND I AM STILL BEING LIED TO AND IGNORED. The Amazon daily double. I'm told they will get back to me by Monday. Apparently that is the Monday after the Apocalypse. It never comes. They just stall with lies and promises and then apparently hope you will die before you tell people what a rip off they are running. The average time lapse after each promise is MONTHS, and that is a response, not an actual solution. There are other companies that sell tablets, and I can guarantee they will treat you better than Amazon Customer Service. Check back in a few months for the next update.Between this and the SD card and case I threw away more than $200, and 4 months of my life trying to get Amazon to fix the issues. Today, was the death knell for this piece of falsely advertised garbage. It does not hold close to 512GB, as it says it does. I was told that this was Samsung's fault, since their card won't write to nearly 50 GB of the supposed storage. Also, the more books you try to put in, the greater the amount of digital detritus that it will stick in as well. I have 3000 books on it and 6.04 GB of mystery junk has been added to my internal memory. This is a fraction of the issues that this plodding tablet hits you with. You can time the loading of larger numbers of books with a sun dial, and the system decides on its own to go to other sites or to just reload at random. I bought this to put in a large number of books for an Alaska trip. It is so unreliable that I took a tablet with less storage instead. Basically, get this if your standards are low and you don't mind being deceived by Amazon for months. I have bought an awful lot from Amazon in the past, including more than 25,000 books, but this version of their kindle is the worst in many ways, and destroys a lot of previously established goodwill. Don't be an idiot like I was and trust Amazon to do right by you. Look somewhere else. Apparently the Amazon that actually tried to help their customers with issues in a thing of the past, and the concept of quality merchandise is as well.
title: Don't make the worst mistake of your digital life
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

review_content: Bought 3 of these for the kids at Christmas time. I have bought many kindles over the years as gifts and most of them still work today. Well, I was wrong. Amazon says that they only cover device failure for 90 days from purchase and we missed it. This is a hardware issue not caused by any fault of the user, that is not disputed. But they will not replace the device even with a refurbished model. If I'd like to purchase another, they'd be happy to offer me a small discount. Of course that device also has a 90 day guarantee. If the device dies after 5 months, like this one did, I'll have to buy another. Seems to me the cost of an iPad mini makes more sense since they cover device failure for a year at no extra charge and last much longer. author: Jack B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2019
review_content: So let's talk about my wild and not-so-wonderful first delve into ownership of an Amazon product. First of all, Amazon failed to ship the item out in the allotted "Prime" time frame  not a good first impression.Next off we have packaging.  I was somewhat embarrassed for Amazon when I found they actually pack these in the cardboard equivalent of a value meal bag.  Never have I seen a tablet that did not come in a protective box.  Id seen these little "bags" sitting around at Best Buy before. But I just assumed that it was something you took to the register and they gave you your safely boxed tablet. Haha, yeah right.The screen quality on this is horrible. In all honesty, the RCA tablets at Walmart look better (and come in a box). The touch on the unit isn't that great either. It was randomly responding straight out of the box.  Oddly enough, this was cured by adding a tempered glass.This is an Android based tablet and it does not come with Google Play Store. You have to download apk files off the internet and get it. But this thing is so locked down that it won't let you search certain things on Google Play that are on Amazon's app store.  You literally are forced to get them from Amazon...even some free ones.PLEASE NOTE THE FOLLOWING AS IT IS NOT CLEAR (AT THE TIME OF THIS REVIEW)So, when you see the tablet in search results, It says $49 and there is an option drop down. Well the $49 in for some kind of promotions (Great, must be some kind of sale running.). Wrong.  So just like the value meal bag, Amazon has a lock screen unlike any other tablet I've seen.  There's ads for Apps etc on the lock screen. What?!  So, after searching Goigle and figuring how to turn them off, finally got that fixed.  Mind you, nothing in that process mentioned any charges.Later on I was reading my email and found one charging me $17 for promotions from Amazon.  I called in and got some rude girl from an overseas call center (because it would be to easy to route me to the local center I guess). Who tried to tell me that I got "a discount" so I had to have ads or be charged.  After an arguement about my first amendment right to express my disgust at Amazon for thinking they have more rights than any other tablet manufacturer, she refunded me...but failed to tell me she was turning the ads back on. Good thing I had since to ask.  I demanded her supervisor and she tried to tell me the supervisor would agree with her. I demanded the sup again. He came on the line and I explained how shady the advertisement for the product was and how unfair it is to charge someone without their permission. He agreed, left the credit for the charge for me. And made sure advertisements weren't going to come back on.
title: I will never buy another

author: J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: I have enjoyed my Kindle 7 5th generation for five years.  Five years is a long time for tech, so I looked into trading in my old device for the 9th generation.  I received the 9th generation tablet today and after a mere ten hours of playing with the new device, I will be sending it back.The first thing I've noticed is that there is very little difference between the 5th generation and the 9th generation.  More storage is not a big draw for me since I can just use an SD card.  The screen is notably sharper.  Apparently, battery life is better.  Barely.  Most of the specs are identical.  It even fits in my old 5th generation case, so not having to buy a new case was also a plus.However, as soon as I upgrade, I lost access to all my Amazon Underground apps.  I am not much of a game person, but when I first bought the 5th generation, the Amazon Underground was a major contender for the Kindle fire tablets.  Amazon Underground allowed 100% FREE ACCESS to millions of games.  This meant you could play to your heart's content and never pay a dime.  All in-app purchases were suspended.Since I've been using this device for five years, I had no idea Amazon discontinued the Amazon Underground program in 2019.  All my apps that I downloaded to my original device still work.  But when I "upgraded" to 9th generation, all that was available to me were the regular version of the games."No big deal,"  I thought.  I'll just save those games to an SD card and load them to the new tablet.  I bought a brand new SD card today specifically for this purpose. Surprise, surprise, when I inserted the SD card with all my "Actually Free" games, I got a message on the 9th generation telling me the card was "incompatible" with my new device, even though I got no such message on the 5th generation.  The 9th generation did give me a friendly message stating that I could make the SD card compatible with the new device if I erased it.  As the Church Lady would say, "How conveeeeenient!"Again, I'm not much of a gamer, but the "actually free" banner across all those games was what set the kindle fire apart from other tablets.  Now, it's just a tablet - and a slow one.  Why would I want the new kindle when I could get a faster, sharper android device instead?  (And I do have the google play store sideloaded onto my 5th generation; I'm not going to go through that process again just to have a sharper, more crisp looking screen and lose access to all the free games).Finally, this is a very minor issue, but I notice the fonts are not 100% universal on the 9th generation.  For example, the drop down menu at the very top of the device (the one that has your bluetooth, airplane mode, and blue shade icons) does not change.  When you make the font bigger, that menu stays tiny.Needless to say, there is absolutely nothing wrong with my 5th generation Kindle 7.  I will be returning the 9th generation tablet and using my 5th - with all its free games -- until it officially bites the dust.  A lesson learned: new is not always better.
title: Warning: "NEW" is not always "BETTER"
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Regan J. Coussan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: I bought this for an anniversary gift. This is the perfect example of the old bait-and-switch. Sure, we got a tablet, but it doesn't use Google Play, and doesn't have access to a ton of Google apps that are usual on standard Android devices. In addition, the device is literally RIFE with ads, including on the lock screen - ads with VIDEO AND SOUND, no less. And how does one stop them? Why, by paying a $15 deactivation charge that nobody realizes was in the fine print. Never again, Amazon. You don't get to pull a nasty on my wife. I'm literally going to go and pay for a tablet that's three times as expensive, and get a fair deal. I'll by God drive to Best Buy, even though they are more expensive, and give THEM our business.

author: Jalila
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2019
review_content: My sons' family moved near me recently and I was dismayed to find the kids were 1 - 2 grade levels behind in school.  The oldest two, a 4th and 3rd grader, were both at a beginning 2nd grade reading level (thanks West Palm Beach schools!). The younger twins, starting kindergarten a couple of weeks ago, didn't know their alphabet or numbers (their working parents had paid a government subsidized Pre-K school to not do that over the summer).  Their parents said they knew their ABC's but all they could do was sing the ABC song; if you pointed at a letter and asked which one it was they had no clue what I was asking. "What's a letter?"  They didn't know one from the other, much less how to write them.  (Yes, parents, you are responsible for your kids education, not the schools. Enough said.)As a former college professor, who taught how to integrate technology in a teacher training program, with 90 graduate units in education under my belt, I had to intercede.  I started reading sessions after school with the older two kids where I used my older Kindle and my two Samsung Galaxy Tablets, a 7" and a 10", to share reading the same book as they took turns reading out loud while I followed along to give support as needed.I was delighted to stumble over the Kindle Reader "Wordwise" feature that let's the kids touch a pre-selected difficult word and both see the definition and hear the pronunciation. (I hope eventually they can touch any word and have the same feature.) After an hour of reading I let them play with a couple of word games and they competed with each other to get higher scores.  Little did I know that the games came with the option of "buying" hints to accelerate their scores -- until two $35 charges showed up on my credit card statement.  While I was thrilled to see how engaged the kids were with the learning games I realized I needed more control over the tablets.After some research I discovered the Kindles have both parental controls, and another layer of protection through the Kindle  app, "FreeTime" (not available on the Samsung Tabs).  AND Kindle has a "family package" subscription where I can share apps with 4 tablets plus two parent units.  I bought four Fire 7s, along with screen protector film, cute foam protector cases with built in stand flaps, and over the ear head phones.Yes, it took hours to set them all up.  But it was easy and intuitive as I tweaked so many options: the time of day they could use the Kindle, how much time they have to use each media type from the "education" domain before they can play entertainment media, the amount of time they can use it altogether, both weekdays and weekends. FreeTime categorizes all available media as either educational or entertainment. You can set a time limit on each of the media types, e.g., apps/games, books, audible audio, and video, so that all of the educationally categorized media have to be viewed for your set time before the entertainment apps can be seen. I set up 1 hour of each media type with unlimited screen time so if they actually do get in 4 hours of learning in a given day they can play, especially on the weekend.I have yet to view the educationally classified  videos or audio content, so I may change my mind, but at the moment I would like to see the option to not allow videos or Audible as I anticipate it will eventually require maintenance time to liberate memory. There is a Storage management option that will archive unused apps and even let you use a SD card (not included) but I anticipate memory will periodically need to be manually cleared as well.  I would also like to be able to only display on their home page the apps that I select for them. The number of available media on their home page, even if educational, are a constant distraction for them that requires me to supervise their use and redirect them back to the apps I selected that focus on the skills I want them to practice.As I observed one of the twins use a Kindle (I hadn't tweaked yet) for the first time I was almost amused to find she could spend a seemingly unlimited amount of time with (to me) a mind numbingly boring "construction"  app that simply pushed a donkey up a pile of bricks, made him jump down, and build another pile of bricks, jump down, etc.  I would love to see what brain waves and endorphins were exercised in that app as she was almost addicted by the process.  Needless to say, I had to pull her away from that app and threaten to take the Kindle away if she didn't go back to one of the letters or numbers apps I had selected for her. Fortunately she would rather do the educational games than watch TV or anything else. WOW!Additional options let me select content by age appropriateness. The 4th grader wanted to play a kindergarten game her sister was playing so I had to expand the age setting in her profile to encompass the lower grade apps. Perhaps that's a better idea as the older kids can strengthen or even learn skills they didn't pick up in the earlier grades.Right below that option is my favorite selection, "Enable In-App Purchasing". Off.Bottom line - what an amazing resource for parents.  If I had my way every kid in every school would have one.
title: Great teaching tool for kids!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Mister Gizmo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2019
review_content: I bought the Fire7 primarily to complement my Kindle Paperwhite. The Paperwhite is preferable when I'm reading outside and need long battery life. But I do most of my reading indoors near a power source, where a pad's flexibility and color display are useful; that's the niche the Fire7 fits very well.The Fire7 hardware provides terrific value. Its speed and display are just fine for the mere fifty bucks it costs, and far more than adequate for the demands I put on it. The main thing (understandably) missing is GPS. And it's light, especially when used without a cover.Where the Fire7 falls short is in the apps. I'm *especially* disappointed with the Kindle app (called "Books" on the Fire7). I've grown very fond of continuous scroll in both the iOS and standard Android apps that Amazon provides for other platforms. Why did they cripple the continuous scroll feature on the Fire7, when it's an app written by Amazon and used on Amazon hardware? Because it's not there, I'll continue to rely on my almost-ancient standard Android mini-pad for most of my reading. The feature is that important.In addition, of course, we're all familiar with the limits Amazon puts on apps in its app store. As just one example, I can get Google Drive but not Google Maps (the Maps app on the Fire7 is far less capable). If the issue is royalties, why not charge a small fee for apps that standard Android users have easy access to?Bottom line: Amazon has a potentially *great* product in the Fire7, but has chosen to cripple that potential with the apps it makes available to users. And I want my continuous scroll!
title: Excellent hardware value, so-so software

author: DLW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2019
review_content: The pluses - nice size, light weight, lots of memory via expansion.  Minuses -  I had a hard time getting a black screen/ white letter setting for night reading - you first have to reverse colors then open books.  Tech was no help at all on this, as their instructions had no parallel in the fire 7 menus.  So the choice is to keep the color reversed or change to reverse each time you want to read.  Next and more disconcerting is the playback seems to go haywire and turn itself off after a certain period of time. Sometimes it works t try any other playlist, or album, but I have had it fail in this too.  You might have to turn off and restart the Kindle. As for the touch screen it seems a bit tougher to turn pages in reading mode than my original Kindle.  I will hang on to this one but I am disappointed.  They have been making these for years.  You'd think it was down pat by now....... After some weeks I have to say that this device likes to stop working now and then but I've always been able to get it up and running again(this is a new edit 9/3/19) OK now it's August in 2020 an the fire has developed a permanent disability .  Somehow it unregistered itself and won't let me register it again as it says both that I am connected to the internet and that I am not connected to the internet.  The device is clearly connected but the registration form says it isn't.  Go figure.  Having no sync in the settings I was unable to try that approach. Ha ha Jeff ya got me.

author: Odessa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: For starters, I love Amazon.  Who doesn't?And my old Ipad is starting to finally kick the proverbial dust after years of abuse.  The battery is finally starting to take forever to charge, and there's lagging issues due to it being so old, and the updates are just killing it more.  But it is still beloved to my four year old, who somehow commandeered it.All that being said, I was so excited when it finally came in!  It looked awesome, was a little different with the controls all at the top, including the volume, power, charging port, and headphone jack, with the speaker not at the bottom of the device but on the left side, which was an odd placement I thought after I put a case on it, and I typically hold it where the speaker is located.  The opposite side close to the top is the slot for an SD card.  There are no front buttons as it's fully touchscreen also.I already knew before going in that you could not use Goggle Play, although I'm sure there's a way to get around it.  I basically wanted to use it for videos for both myself and my daughter, games, and the occasional book and web browsing.  Now, keep in mind we have super fast Internet.  When I first started the Fire tablet, there was the required set up process, which didn't take long, just the basics such as adding wifi, signing in, etc.  I did purchase the tablet with "special offers" as it did not bother me to see the ads on the lock screen.  Once on, it was a pretty nice setup, especially for those that are already "in" with Amazon as it shows a Home screen with my recent book/audiobook purchases up top, then all my apps below it, the next page shows Books, and includes some books from my library as well as recommendations below it, Videos is next, followed by Games, Shop (which was so odd as it shows things I've looked at), Apps, Music, and Newsstand.So basically, if you do a lot of Amazon shopping, listen to Audible as well as Amazon Music, watch Amazon videos, and read Kindle books, then this might be for you.If you don't use Amazon that frequently, then I'd recommend looking elsewhere for a regular tablet, one that is not hardwired for their Amazon customers.Now in my personal use, because I do use a lot of their services, I do like it.  But it's also dang annoying.  I suppose it's coming from having owned Apple devices, and Samsung devices that I find this tablet to lag tremendously.  Actual startup from the time you press the power button takes about 40 seconds to pop on.  Not too shabby, but there is a lag from opening the lock screen to opening apps that isn't apparent in a good quality Apple or Samsung product.  And let's not forget the horrible lag from going from one profile to the next.  It takes forever, and at this point, I finally erased the profile I set up for my daughter. I loved that I would be able to limit her usage as we already do that, but in this way she couldn't even get on without my code.  You can download what apps they can use, and manage their profile fully, which is great!  But on the flip side, I can't seem to figure out how to get back to my profile without shutting the whole thing down or restarting it as it opens right to her page versus the lock screen when opened back up.And as I previously stated, you can use the Amazon apps, but there aren't as many apps as can be found in Apple.  There are some I love to use, and they do not have them available at all, which sucks.  Amazon's browsing is called Silk, and works fine, although I still find it slow with fast Internet.  The quality of the screen and the battery are two other issues that are definitely cheap and sub par.  The screen quality on browsing has the slightly blurred look of a cheap android tablet. Words are ok, such as in an article, but pictures are blurred, and even video is not that clear or crisp.  The battery is also very weak I've found.  I've had my phone on since six this morning, and turned the tablet on around 10 this morning.  My phone, which I've used all morning to make calls, text, watch a few video's, look at FB, browse, etc., is down to 76% battery.  The tablet, which I've used to download four apps and had maybe about 20 minutes of use and has been on standby is down to 75%.  The battery does not last long at all.  If you watch even a few videos on the tablet, you can easily watch the percentage slowly bottom out.The camera is what you would normally find on a cheap tablet, and I wasn't expecting much nor did I get much in return.  The kindle portion is fantastic, and I can read easily on it, but I also own a Kindle, and I prefer that to this as the glare is greatly reduced even though you can change the page color and brightness of the screen.  I do like seeing the book covers in color though, and maps or things throughout the book that would normally be colored, but otherwise it is still nice to be able to read on it well.  Alexa works totally well, and it's easy to use, and I like the fact that you can use Alexa to play some games.  My daughter is fascinated with her.In all, this is an okay basic entry tablet that's good for watching videos, and is more tuned towards Prime members who have a lot of Amazon features already.  I'm going to keep it as I wanted something cheap for my youngest daughter to watch videos and keep her occupied, and for my occasional browsing.  But if you want a crystal clear screen, no lag, and better selection of apps, then I would definitely recommend going with an Apple or different Android device.
title: Depending On Your Use, This Might Not Be For You
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: CherieO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2019
review_content: Update 12/25/2020I've had this for 1.5yrs and use it only to listen to audio books. For that purpose solely it is adequate. It was used daily for several months then less and less as work gets busy. My 10" tablet no longer holds a charge (it was returned once for this reason already and in my experience is a common Amazon Fire issue) and the 10" tablet is used hours upon hours each day, everyday. The 7" has barely been used this year during the pandemic, but was picked up today for some light internet searching and one game thats been installed for months but only played one time. This device is just a slow piece of garbage. The typical Fire menus across the top of the homepage only show For You and Home. Every site is too large for Silk to load so things have been disabled. This will be the last Amazon tablet I buy.I have an 8" (2018) , 10" (7th gen), 7" HDX (3rd gen) and now this new 7" (2019). I bought this new version for the Hoopla app which provides free access to books using your library card. The app is no longer supported on my old HDX and I was getting tired of bringing my huge 10" to work everyday just to listen to audio books. I use the 10" for everything else and I wanted it to stay at home. I planned to buy the 7" in June when it premiered but I waited for the reviews and because the negatives pointed out things that weren't improved from my old HDX or the 10" I decided to look elsewhere. Then on Prime Day I read the reviews again and though they were about the same I decided that I could live with the major complaints others had and thought I'd probably avoid the more minor complaints since those were likely exaggerated or isolated. Plus, I didn't need great sound (a huge complaint I have about all my other kindles too) since it would be used only with Bluetooth headphones. I didn't need perfect screen quality since its only use would be audiobooks. My major concern was would there be enough storage to temporarily download about 15-20 books over a course of a month, at about 5 at a time. My old HEX struggled there. So, I got the kindle deliverd just after Prime Day though there was a little delay since it was a popular item. I didn't even open it for almost 3 weeks while I waited for a protective cover. When I got confirmation the cover would arrive any day I decided to go ahead and add Hoopla and start downloading books. I played with it for about 4 days off and on and it I started to notice issues that reviews had mentioned. The browsing was slow, loading images is pretty delayed, it dropped the internet connection a few times and I had trouble getting my smart thermostat set up on Alexa. Still, the goal was only to listen to downloaded audio books so none of this mattered too much. Then about 5 days before my return period expired (8/19/19) I couldn't get Hoopla to open. I opened it one time, downloaded books, left the device and didn't pick it up again until the cover was installed. I started to panic when it wouldn't work so I contacted Amazon, explained the issues I noticed and they easily agreed to a replacement. However they set up a replacement for an 8" so I had to contact them before it shipped to let them know they were sending the wrong item. The second agent was helpful but she wanted to do more troubleshooting (first agent already did but I was happy to try because I didn't want to return it) before agreeing to a replacement. We tried her way but nothing changed. She asked me to contact Hoopla and try the device for a couple more days since I still had a few days left to return it. Hoopla helped me get the app working a day later. Crisis averted! I took it to work this week and was only able to use it a few times, less than 2hrs each day, but had no issues. Again, I'm only listening to it so there's not a lot that could go wrong. Usually I'd use it 5-6 days a week, 6-10 hrs a day so it was an unusual week. It's Sat late night now, I'm doing chores and listening to a book with Bluetooth and it's dropping the Bluetooth connection so often I've lost count. It's happening as frequently as every 10 mins. I'm so disappointed. All those "exaggerated" and "isolated" reviews were spot on. This thing isn't stable or reliable.
title: Disappointed. I thought the negative reviews must be wrong. They aren't.

author: Inspector Nash Bridges
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2019
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           The 1st thing you want to do is load Google Play Store.I like to skip registration with Amazon and just use the product as a tablet.I love it.  This is the lowest end tablet you can buy.  Every other tablet computer on the market is better.  Better processor.  Better screen quality.  Better audio.  Better memory.Why the 1 star rating if I love it?  Well, let's face it.  It's a 1 star tablet.  This item is not the top of the line.  It comes with Amazon App Store.  You have to have an Amazon account, and register the tablet with Amazon.  The product does not come with Google Play Store.  You get all of the Amazon advertising, unless you pay the ransom.  They charge you for the privilege of viewing ads, then charge more if you don't want to see the ads.At the price, it can't be beat.  When it fails, and these fail often, I buy another.  I hand these out as stocking stuffers.My favorite use for this is as a scan tool.  That's right.  Automotive computer interface.  I can monitor operating parameters.  With the right OBDII interface, I have all the performance gauges I need, scan for diagnostic trouble codes, clear maintenance indicator lights, and even make changes to the vehicle's operations.  I can check for emissions readiness, turn off daylight driving lights, turn off "Bambi Mode", turn on "Police Mode", turn off the seat belt minder chime, relearn TPMS sensors, reset oil change monitor, et cetera.

review_content: Better than I expected.  I was going to get the 32 fb option but the 16 fb option was available to ship sooner. Excellent deal from prime day! I haven’t tried the tricks yet to get the google stuff yet.  So far I dont need anything except maybe the hangout app.  A friend and I call and video chat that way.I bought a 128gb microSD card to go with it and some of the apps will move to the card but some don’t. author: Arthur Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: Well I have to say that the Amazon Fire Tablet 7" is well worth the fifty bucks I paid for it. It's a great little tablet for the price annnd it comes with ALEXA! Now in order to get it for fifty dollars you're gonna have to put up with a few ads but they are very unobtrusive and in no time at all you won't even pay attention to em. Now you can get the 7" Fire Tablet without ads but you'll have to fork over an extra twenty but hey,to each his own right? The display is crisp & clear enough and the touch responsiveness is on point (no pun intended). But if your expecting to be wowed by the speakers well you need to tone down your giddyness a bit in this department. The speaker consists of seven small holes that are located on the lower left hand corner; now if your holding he tablet in portrait mode and you're holding it with you left hand, then your gonna be covering up the speaker but on the bright side if you cup your hand while holding it this way your hand acts kinda sorta like a megaphone 😃. Anyway, the speaker is the only gripe I have about this tablet and it does have Bluetooth so you can connect it to a better speaker, I use a Thumper 808 with mine and I love the crap out of it 😊. Look folks, for fifty bucks you can't beat the quality, durability or features of the 7" Fire Tablet. If your trying to find something comparable to the IPad mini or a Samsung Galaxy tablet, this ain't it. But if you're looking for a great little tablet thats gonna provide you with hours of entertainment with decent battery life and your on a tight budget...then come on in brothers and sisters the water is fine 😉.

review_content: I bought this new version of the fire 7 in December because the one I'd had for years was starting to act up a little. I should have figured something was off then as I had already explained that I COULDN'T TURN IT ON! author: krafty pixie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: This Kindle Fire was not packed correctly. There was no protective packing at all & it could move freely around the box. The box the Kindle Fire itself came in had no protective foam or even cardboard.I figured I would test the Fire to see 1) if it even worked after all the jostling around (& possible dropping) 2) to see if I actually would want to replace it if I liked how it worked & what it offered.Pros:None the product was broken. It turned on at first & enabled me to go through the tutorial & check out the features. It appeared to allow me access to my Kindle library & I manually downloaded my current Kindle Unlimited Library, but after leaving if off for a few hours it wanted me to start all over again.Cons:Any app that Amazon has put on this tablet you can only "force stop" & not disable or uninstall. I don't have much confidence in apps that can't be disabled or uninstalled staying off, from previous experience with other (not Amazon) tablets. Since this tablet was broken I'm not sure if it's always the case, but the 2nd time I turned it on, all the apps I'd forced to stop were back on.The rest of the cons are from when I first turned it on & it was working & from reading help articles on how the Kindle Fire works, so the information is correct.You cannot remove the app icons from your home screen & you do not have another screen to drag them to so you don't have to see them. You can only drag them on top of each other to create a folder & pull as many apps as you want into that folder.You can't change the size of the icons on your home screen. I use large font, so my home page icons are huge.Since this Kindle Fire arrived packed so poorly I contacted customer service via Chat on Amazon & could not get a straight answer on whether or not a new Kindle Fire would be packed in protective packaging (which was very odd to me). I will be returning this Kindle Fire & looking at other tablets instead.

review_content: Tablet is great, comes with lots of extra features and lots of free movies, books, music & apps. Perfect for an adult. (Using the Parental controls disables alexa. That and because it said child profiles cannot make purchases is why I didnt turn the controls on to begin with.) When I set them all up, it said child profiles couldnt make purchases TWICE. So, I left parental controls off just so they could keep alexa. My 2,5 & 7 yr old love to use Alexa because 2 &5 cant read or write yet & 7 cannot spell everything properly yet. I taught them to speak to their devices and they were all doing great. Now they barely even want to touch them cause they dont have Alexa to help them find what they want.Oh, and every time you get an alert from your amazon purchases, they go to every tablet! My sons birthday is tomorrow and he already was alerted when each gift shipped! I had no idea it did that til I picked his up and saw "your item/package: ... shipped!" Full description of each item. Idk what to do now. I ASKED ALEXA several times in several different ways "how to keep the tablets out of my shopping cart" or to "disable Amazon alerts" to the tablet and she said she found nothing on that. author: GypsyMama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: I scooped up three of these (2 of them in different colors) on Black Friday for $30 each and it was a great investment for entertainment and education for my kids. My children who use these are all between 8 and 14 years old. They are at ages where some of them know tech as well or better than myself, so I needed Parental Controls that were on point to give them access to resources and content without exposing them to porn, extreme violence, or predators. The Kindle Fire 7 definitely delivers in that respect. Everyone's standards are different, so I love the fact that you can allow Amazon to screen content by age and set that age yourself! Anything above PG (and some edgier PG choices) that my teen or preteen read or watch, are either viewed with my supervision or previously screened before we watch or read together so that we can discuss anything that we need to. As such, the highest age setting for Amazon curated content on these portable handheld devices in our house is age 9, even though my oldest is 14. This allows for differences in opinion that I might have about what content is appropriate and the fact that all of that content can be viewed in private. I have disabled the browser through parental controls for anything other than this curated content and specific websites and youtube videos that I have added to their content individually. This is a SUPER feature!!! For each child, I added access to videos of things that interest them such as woodworking, cooking, crafting, favorite music artists, magic tricks, and more.Books can be added as content as well, so I am able to take out library e-books and audiobooks through my app for them and only share what is theirs.The app offerings through Amazon are not as extensive as other operating systems, but there are plenty of word games, Teach My Monster to Read, Starfall, Candy Crush, Roblox, Mincraft, some Lego Games, Crossy Road, photo editors, and painting apps. My children don't play the ones with in-game messaging or chat and do not have social media accounts. They have games to practice math skills, learn languages, and develop other skills. You have the option to set educational goals for kids and the option require them to meet them before accessing entertainment if you'd like. I don't,  because I want them to read and build skills for fun, which they might not if required.I have curfews and time limits set individually for each child that can be turned off or on through my Amazon account on my phone, where I can also view exactly what each child has been doing on their tablet and for how long.Overall, my children might have enjoyed a Galaxy Tab more with its increased access to games and the internet less focus on parental controls,  but they are thoroughly enjoying their Amazon Fire 7 tablets AND we have peace of mind that they are safe.Also, the value on these can't be beat. We had both a Galaxy Tab and another Amazon Kindle Fire in the past and BOTH ended up worn out or broken after about 2 years of use. These are much more cost effective at that rate.
title: The Best Parental Control Options in tech industry!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Robb Boutros
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: I picked this sucker (and note the term) on Black Friday, and was relatively excited to do so. My LG Gpad had quit on me some time ago, and I wanted an adequate replacement, which I believed this was. It was not. Here's the tablet worked well enough, and after a "thorough" set up process I started using it. The first thing I attempted was screen mirroring. Turns out that this model doesn't support screen mirroring. After a lengthy search of seeing if there was a way to enable screen mirroring, I threw in the towel on that. It left me asking the question of how could it be possible that my six year old LG tablet can support Miracast, and when I did use it, it worked very well. Yet a brand new tablet with supposed better technology can not, or will not?Okay, maybe there's some other features that would be worthwhile using. After putting it down for about a minute, I was greeted by an ad for Progressive Insurance. This tablet is AD SUPPORTED. However, here's the real kicker; if you want to turn off the ads, you have to PAY TO DO SO.  Well, screw that!!! You sell me this device with built in advertising that I don't want, and then I have to pay for the privilege of turning it off?So let's recap;This model has, the Fire Tablet 7 has;-No screen mirroring-Built in ads which you have to PAY to turn off.Thus, based on those alone (especially the built in advertising) back it goes!! If you want a tablet, then consider purchasing something comparable. I cannot in good conscience recommend the Fire 7.  I might be too late to help someone who has already bought it, but at the very least I can warn those who might be considering purchasing this.

author: Randall Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
review_content: This is my second go round with the Fire tablets. They are what they are; inexpensive Android tablets. Yes, they run Amazon's version of Android, but they are basically Android tablets with a skin on them. The screens are acceptable, and while they are not the snappiest tablets around they work for my needs. Remember, this is only a $50 tablet folks. Temper your expectations.There are two reasons that I purchased the Fire tablet as opposed to a commodity Android tablet (Walmart and Best Buy sell a few for about $50 with similar specs). The first is that there are accessories for the Fire tablets that are widely available and built for these tablets. I purchased three rubber bumper cases (one for each kid's Fire tablet). The same cannot be said for commodity tablets. There is almost always some sort of compromise with universal accessories. I don't have to make those compromises with the Fire.The second reason I selected the Fire tablets is because of the widely touted parental controls that are baked into the Fire OS. To be fair, should you enable "FreeTime" on the tablets (in other words, create a kid's profile), the parental controls are amazing. You are able to set operating hours on the tablet for either weekdays or the weekend, limit the amount of time spent on certain content, and limit total screen time. Should you choose to spend the extra money and enroll in "FreeTime Unlimited," there is a wide swath of pre-screened content that will be available to your child on demand.Unfortunately, there is a significant negative to the Kid's profiles as well. You are unable to share in in-app-purchases with the Kid's profile. I would estimate that over the past couple of years I have spent around $100 on in-app-purchases for children's games that my kids enjoy. I can share these apps with the Kid's profile, but any purchases that I made in those apps are not available to my kids. Amazon has started to allow in-app-purchases from a Kid's profile, but that does me no good for the investment I have already made. I also was unable to get a clear response with regards to whether or not my kids could share any in-app-purchases made through the kid's profiles (I spent over two hours in chat with Amazon reps trying to understand exactly how FreeTime worked).Because of this my children will continue to use an adult profile to access their tablets. You can still enable parental controls like a curfew or ratings limits. You just don't have the same granular level of control you would have if they were using a kid's profile. Considering the resources that Amazon is able to bring to bear on a problem, this suggests to me one of three things:1) The recent lawsuits about kids making purchases spooked them2) Amazon wants to make money by forcing you to purchase content that you have already purchased3) Amazon wants to force you into a FreeTime Unlimited subscription, which ironically wouldn't solve my problem eitherSo would I buy one of these again? Absolutely. They seem to be of slightly higher quality than commodity tablets you can get for the same price. The only reason that this does not get a 5 star rating from me is that the kid's profile setup does not allow in-app-purchases to be shared. This is an extreme negative for me.
title: Parental controls are not as good as advertised without FreeTime

author: Darryl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
review_content: I got the black 16 GB model with special offers. It arrived two days early, and works far better than I expected for a $50 tablet.I don't plan to use my Fire 7 online that much, as I bought it primarily for PDFs, ebooks, and media such as audio podcast, movies, music, ect. I loaded all of my books and podcast onto a 400 GB micro SD card, and it's an awesome little media tablet, which frees up my phone and laptop for work or play.I'll note here that I replaced the default Amazon interface by downloading a very simple hack, followed by installing the Nova Launcher, and now it's a standard Android tablet rather than an Amazon tablet. Amazon is amazing, no doubt, but I do my shopping on my phone, and have other plans for this tablet.The most unexpected bonus of the Fire 7 is it's ability to emulate nes, snes, gb, gbc, gba, sg, and sms, flawlessly, AND even PSP and PS1, with a 90% compatibility rate. The biggest drawback of this model is having only 1 GB of ram, however, for retro emulation, ebooks, and media viewing, you don't really need a super computer, and this tablet will work fine.If you want high end audio, you'll need a Bluetooth speaker or something that connects via 3.5 audio jack. I've tested this and it's flawless.Honestly, I can't believe this tablet is only $50. I highly recommend it for all of your basic media and gaming needs.

author: RBurgie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
review_content: I use mine primarily to read or listen to books by enabling the "Text to Speech" option in Settings. However, since the last operating system update, that function has been messed up. If you disable the screen, then the speech stops after it encounters the next page (except that it will continue to finish the paragraph it's reading if the paragraph is split over two pages). So you need to keep the screen enabled (which reduces the battery life). Then it stops when the display time limit is reached (which turns off the display). So you need to set the screen display timeout limit to the max which is 30 minutes. Finally, they put a limiter on the volume control. Normally I'm on my tractor when listening to the books so I wear bluetooth headphones. But the 7 inch fire only has half the volume since the O.S. update. Bottom line, via the "system update", they can make your device (that was working perfectly fine), turn into a paper weight forcing you to buy a new one after a year. Quite disappointed.
title: Can't hear Text to Speech book reading
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Candace Peaches
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2019
review_content: i now have a tablet that i can use and it's not heavy. i like that it fits in my palm nicely. its just the right size for reading my fan fiction online. it fits in my bag or purse and doesn't take up a lot of space. i got the plum color b/c it was as close to purple as i could get. now i just have to get the sd card to hold my storage and a cover to protect the it. mine is a 16 g.b. the price wasn't so bad either. i had a amazon coupon and got 5 dollars of the price which brought the price to up 50$. i just hope it lasts for a long time(at least up to 5 yrs). if you don't like heavy tablets, this one is for you. try it. you just might like it. c'ya'
title: pricing

author: TonyTyga90
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
review_content: UPDATE: Compared to the iPAD the kindle is way better as an eReader outside. No glare on screen. Gotta give credit when it is due. + 1 Star for this.The Kindle Fire tablets suck at being a tablet but is an alright eReader at best. The software the tablet comes with is Fire Os. This locks the tablet down to Amazon's very limited app store. I would recommend installing the google play store (you can google how to do this). This will open the door for additional apps but retains that horrible fire os interface. The interface has several pages that are really just store fronts and cannot be deleted. If you select anything in it just opens the corresponding app. IE you go to the books page and select a book, it just throws you into Kindle app that anyone can download on ios or android. Same with the Music and video pages just opens Amazon Prime Music and Video respectively.The hardware sucks also. The back cover colors are a nice touch but screen resolution is worse than most budget smartphones. Now you could make the argument that the Kindle Fire 7 screen is larger than your phone screen. I would respond that yes and most people have a larger screen than that located on something called a television. And unless it’s a Tube TV, your television has a better resolution also. What's up with that charging port? I have had to 2 charging ports on 2 separate kindles go out on me with the latest one only lasting 2 months. It charges well at first, then over time you will have to hold the charging cable a certain way and then finally it does not charge at all becoming a brick.It's 1gb of ram is just pitiful. It is fine for reading a book OR listening to music OR watching a movie but having more than 3 apps opened at a time and you will lose memory. Example I had the kindle app open on a textbook, notes app to take notes and settings app because I forgot I had it open. Jumping just between the kindle app and notes app, the kindle would lose memory and stall. In its defense, I don't know of any device with only 1gb of RAM that can run Android in 2019. Expandable storage was nice but only certain apps can be moved to an SD Card. Also the battery life is not great. I could just get 1 day on standby with no use at all in my backpack. Literally have to charge it every day.Again alright eReader but horrible tablet.If you buy it, buy it on a deal for $30.
title: Alright eReader but horrible tablet
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: David P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2019
review_content: For the most part I Love the new Fire 7 (2019), the only thing I dislike, so far, is Amazon does not use the full Android OS.Because Amazon refuses to use the full Android OS I can not get or use some of my favorite Apps. They are now only available on Google Play, and Amazon does not allow use of Android Apps if they are on Google Play. Apps like Trivago, Amtrack, 7-11 Rewards, MyTuner Radio, or iTranslate just to mention a few I have tried to switch from my old Fire 6 to my new Fire 7 but are no longer available on Amazon.
title: Needs full Android OS
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Without AdsColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
review_content: I've been looking for a new e-reader and decided to take advantage of the Black Friday sale ($20 off).  All I really want is to be able to read books and go online, so this seemed perfect.  A few things have already stood out:1.  Delivery for TERRIBLE.  Amazon listed the delivery as 'handed to a resident' but the box was actually left in the atrium of my apartment building - on the wrong side of the locked door.  And no one bothered to ring the bell.2. My so-called discount is a rip-off.  the device is subsidized by ads and 'recommendations', including full-screen ads on the lock page.  When you try to turn them off, you're advised that it'll cost $15.  So my deal was actually $5 off and ads.3. The battery is terrible but battery saver is great.  If you're not prepared to deal with the limitations imposed by battery saver (it turns on automatically at 20%) then you probably want a device with a better battery life.4. It's great with non-Amazon files.  I transfered a bunch of .mobi files while it was synced to my computer and they popped into the library without having to jump through hoops.With the exception of the ads, this kindle is basically what I was expecting.  A cheap little e-reader with great customer service and resources behind it.  This isn't an investment - it's something I can throw in my purse to read on the bus.
title: Exactly what I was looking for (but the "discount" is a joke)
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Caitlin C
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2019
review_content: I bought this for myself after using a Kindle fire 8 kids edition tablet i had bought for my son in 2016 he was no longer using it for apps and I got tired of reading my books on my phone screen. I loved it but after awhile it started running slow and I was having problems so i decided to get a new one for myself. This one was on sale for 29.99 and it seemed perfect. I do love this one too. It is small enough to fit in my purse. It runs great and I have all 2500 of my books downloaded to my 64 gb SD card with plenty of room to spare. My only complaint is the battery life. The old kids edition fire 8 had excellent battery life I could leave it unpluged in my bag for months and it would still have around 80 percent battery. This one dies so fast it's unbelievable but I can't complain that much for the price I paid. It has never died on me while I've been reading and as long as I make sure it's charged before I leave home it will last me until I can get home and charge it again. All in all it's a great tablet for a great price.
title: Great tablet. Not so great battery.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: JAS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: First and foremost, FOR THIS PRICE is a great product!! Unbeatable, I must say; it's a lot more that you can expect!! I am surprised this thing is such a high quality product for just few bucks (I bought mine on eBay for $39,99, but later I found it's the same price here at Amazon).AMAZON x100: It is true its operation is 100% based on a Amazon environment, and that its Android OS is a special version (with some limitations); however I  use Amazon store and services a lot, so that does not bother me at all. The inconveniences that are annoying for me I have overcome them satisfactorily...TRILLIONS OF ICONS: For example there are tons of Amazon App icons in the main screen that I don't use, and the app they belong to cannot be uninstalled (or at least I haven't found the way to do it). Well you can stop their services so they don't use tablet's resources, and occupy less memory and space that way; but the icons are still there. Also, they are not allowed to be stored in a folder (by long pressing each icon) so you have to deal with that bunch of icons in the main screen, which is very annoying (to my liking). But today I finally discovered a TRICK ;) to store them in a folder (Yeah!), so goodbye to those disturbing icons that I don't use (I just see 1 folder). My screen is already clean now, and only with the Apps that "I" use.AMAZON'S ANDROID: As for the OS limitations, the only one I could not overcome is that I have an annual subscription to Norton antivirus, and I have it installed on my Desktop, Laptop and Smartphone; unfortunately it cannot be installed on Fire 7 (9th gen). Today I contacted Norton technical support and they confirmed it; they say it cannot be installed due to the version of Android that Amazon uses on their tablets, which is limited and also different, with a very specific configuration that meets their tablets. Well instead I installed a free anitvirus that is going well for now (hope it protects me enough).STORAGE: As in every smartphone or tablet, internal memory is a concern of all of us (it quickly gets full); and this Fire 7 is not the exception. However it has 10.63GB for user's available internal storage (of 16GB it comes with) and I still have 8GB and something FREE, but this is because I use a 32GB MicroSD (it accepts up to 512GB) and configured all apps to store things over there. This is a good advice for all smartphone/tablet users. Oh yes, also Amazon gives you 5GB for Free in their cloud for you to store your stuff (pics, docs, music, or whatever you want). That's space you won't use in your Fire's storage so that's a nice gift.BATTERY: The battery life is awesome; what I've tested so far it gave me about 8 hours while Spotify downloaded my entire playlists for offline use. After that I gave it the second charge and have it playing music for about 5 continue hrs and the battery still has 70% remaining.SPAM: There's something that bothers me a bit which is the advertising of Amazon stuff when I unlock the screen. I haven't found how to stop it so after various attempts to get rid of it I ended up accepting to live with it. I just swipe my finger from the bottom of the screen and advertising is quickly gone.KEYBOARD: It can be set in several languages (well that's standard; I just downloaded the Spanish dictionary so it checks my spelling), but something that I liked is that it includes the Swipe method of "writing" (you enter words by sliding a finger from the first letter to the last; you lift only between words). I love that method and have used it in my smartphones for years now so I'm glad I found it here too.MORE TO COME: I'm so excited with my new Fire that I want to explore more functions, for example Alexa, and more other stuff that comes with the tablet. I will find the time for that later, but for now, I am very happy with what I've got.MY CONCLUSION: I am 200% satisfied with this product, I think it works sensational, at a very satisfactory speed. It plays my Spotify and MP3s playlists without problem, pairing it with my JBL Flip 4 speaker was fast and easy (and it sounds spectacular), the WiFi works perfectly, the email configuration was super fast and without problems, etc etc etc. What a good product!! And for this price, even better!!
title: Awesome Product!!!

author: Jorge A. Pita

review_content: I got this new Kindle Fire as a replacement for the original Kindle Fire of several years ago, which still works fine but I wanted a faster processor and nicer display. author: Lynda Turpin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
review_content: I bought two of the Kindle Fire 7 models during their Prime Day, so that I could put my Audible audio books on them for travel.  The product descriptions state that you can increase the memory to 512 gb with a MicroSD card, so I also bought 2 128 gb SD cards so that I would have sufficient space for all my audio books.  I have a different model Kindle  and I am able to store my Kindle ebooks and Audible audiobooks on the external MicroSD card; so I assumed I could do the same with these.  HOWEVER, with these new Kindles you don't have the option to store the Kindle books or Audible audiobooks in the external storage.  You can move games, etc. but not the applications that use the most storage.  Since other Kindle models allow me to store audio books, ebooks, music, photos, movies, etc. on the external storage, why can't I store those things on the external drive on these models?  My audio books especially take up a lot of storage, and this limitation is going to be a pain in the rear, because I won't be able to have all of my audio books when I travel and am not near wi-fi (especially if I also want to have some ebooks, music, movies, etc. on my Kindle).  Not sure what the advantage of extra external storage is if you can't put anything on it.  I am not going to be able to use these Kindles as I had planned. I will likely give away at least one of them - maybe both. A waste of money for me - very disappointed.
title: Disappointed in the "External Storage" capabilities compared to other Kindle models.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Nature Boi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review_content: as a dedicated long term customer and shareholder of AMZN I am very disappointed in them for offering a tablet with only a 90 day warranty.  these are marketed as an affordable option for people who need a tablet.  when the device was working it was a subpar user experience at best and it broke exactly 6 months after purchasing.  shame on me for not reviewing the warranty clearly before purchasing but shame on Amazon more.  I have always viewed Amazon as a brand I trust and therefore assumed they back up their hardware products with a 1 year warranty.  I didn't feel I needed to check. Big disappointment for me.  BTW, due to my persistence I am getting a replacement but what about everyone else?  what about struggling parents who already have enough on their plate and don't want to go into "angry" mode with a cus serv supervisor?  I will remain a customer but I am now guarded in my view of them.  very disappointed.  BEWARE
title: beware 90 day warranty
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Bambi Sloan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2019
review_content: I bought this half off on black Friday.  I like it for videos but thought because it had location, it would give me GPS abilities in my car.  I didn't expect much.  Videos and GPS is all I wanted.  I got videos but no GPS hardware.  Most people, when googling, don't realize that location does not equal GPS.  It's really not good for anything else.  Would be good for kids but since there is no GPS and the Amazon update causes google play (if side loaded) to do a log in loop where it won't let you log in, this really isn't good for anything else.  Really a waste of $30 when $20 or so more I could of bought a cheap android tablet that had GPS on it.  Can't give it anything else but one star due to the lack of GPS.  Most are going to think location equals GPS and  not have the thought to google that.  Would give it more stars if it actually stated "no GPS" in the description or described location as no GPS hardware or something to make that fact clear!  So many bought a Fire thinking it had GPS so I am not the only one!  Also, buying a Bluetooth GPS is expensive.  Cheaper just to buy a cheap android tablet with GPS.  Steer clear if you want GPS abilities!Update:  It's horribly slow!  Watching youtube is insane!  It lags and then the audio and lips get unsynced and then I have to move it ahead and then back over and over and try to get it syced and it usually never does go back synced again.  It's super annoying.  I know it's not my internet as this NEVER happens on my phone, my blueray, or my smart tv!  Maybe it's the youtube app that's not made by google or youtube.  Because Amazon doesn't have a youtube app made by google or youtube in their store.  I downloaded another one and it happens on that too.  It doesn't happen as much on Netflix or Amazon videos but the processor in this is grap.  It does freeze on games and that makes game playing frustrating.  I have no idea how this has so many good reviews.  Yes, I sideloaded google play and get many alerts to update google play services but the processor of this should be able to handle it as these exact same apps are on my phone and my phone never freezes like this.  It's crap!  I wouldn't even give this to a kid unless it's a young kid that wouldn't care about freezing in games.  People that gave this high reviews, tell me your secert.  I can't take away the one star I already have this but would if I could.  I would NOT purchase this again.  I'd just save another $30 to $60 and get a lower cost android tablet.  This so wasn't worth it!  Even at the $29.99 Black Friday cost.  Most especially since I got the case that was the same cost as the tablet and the SD card.  Ugh!  So mad at myself for this purchase!Oh, and to add, the charger cable just broke.  In less then a month.  The end won't stay in the tablet and just falls out.  If I didn't have charger cables I'd be screwed.  Yeah, don't do it!  Even the cheapest micro usb cables I have bought lastest more then a few weeks!Updated:  Ads on the lock screen?  This just gets worse and worse for me!
title: ADS ON YOUR LOCK SCREEN!  Good for videos and kids but not much more - NO GPS ABILITIES!

author: Sara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: It’s good for its value, but like all tablets, the price adds up as you start tacking on other things like the case and such. The ads aren’t bad. I think people who are complaining are spoiled or are upset they had to settle. If you have children, obviously you never let them have access to ads because they don’t understand to not download them. In terms of the glitchy, I notice most of those reviews are with people who uses the SD card. I know it shouldn’t and I know any IT person would say I’m crazy, but adding on storage always slows down a pc. I do think over time this will begin o glitch. I saw 2 samples in store. The one that was glitchy felt older and wasn’t updated. The one that wasn’t was updated and felt smoother. So I bought the square trade protection just to be safe. I wanted a tablet for some game playing, web browsing amd amazon shopping, simple writing and reading, portable, smaller than the ipads, but bigger than the kindle screens for reading and that kindle oasis price tag is a joke. Setup was super simple and understanding how to use it doesn’t require much of a tutorial, but I can’t say that’ll be the same for you if you’re someone who yells a lot at computers and complains about this new generation.Some cons: the screen doesn’t feel good to swipe. It’s good for tapping. I am really happy I bought an anti-glare screen protector together with my purchase. I was able to put it on first thing which helped with screen feel issue and harsh light. The resolution isn’t perfect and might be too much effort for your eyes if you’re always working with 4k. It’s heavy. I swear the ipad mini is lighter even though they’re the same weight. I think it’s about weight distribution. The resolution and the weight are going to be my deal breakers. If my eyes feel dizzy or my fingers keep complaining, I’ll return it, no matter that I purchased it with a goft card. Otherwise if you have the money and you really want a tablet without the high price and you don’t notice weight, I’d recommend it. If you have an amazon bookstore nearby, I recommend checking there. I’m starting to realize that the price was a little less in store than online.It’s not a waste and won’t be something you’ll hate yourself for buying even if you do decide to return it. Just don’t wait too long to try it and decide if you want to return it.*After a few days, I’ve decided that if I had money, I would get a better tablet. The weight isn’t much of an issue anymore, but the resolution is awful. I will be keeping it b/c it’s what I wish my tablet would be and there are times where I really wish I had a tablet and this is the cheapest on the market with a brand name I trust and no need for store interaction. (Ads/ “special offers” are still not a problem for me, unlike other reviewers. Just putting that out there for those worrying if the discount is worth it. It is.)
title: Good, but resolution ain’t so hot.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Essie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: Purchased in Best Buy. I wasn't going to buy anything, I only went in to accompany my family member to pick up THEIR Black Friday deal. I was shopping around as they waited in line and after picking this up and putting it back down over and over again (as I've done to previous Fires every single Black Friday) I eventually caved. I always wanted a Fire, and as an ipad mini owner who doesn't use tablets that much, I never felt the NEED for more than 1 type of device (phone, game system, etc.) I already had a Paperwhite, why another one?Well one cute green color and debating to myself that it was the mere cost of a "lunch out with friends" I might as well. My mom even joked I could "trip and fall and break it with no heartbreak". It was THAT cheap.Pros:Functions like an ipad. For someone who has no major need for things and not a major "glued to screen" person, I didn't demand that much. I wanted a device that had the basic social media I could check up on: Twitter, FB, IG, etc. It has an alternative Youtube app (now, as I've seen people previously complain Fire lacked Youtube) that's called something like Youtube.com app. It can play a few games too.So in short, for a price of a lunch, it really packs a lot. You pull it out, this cheap covered (plastic) thing, yet it really compares to ipads and other tablets. For someone with not much demand (few apps, just to read), it is MORE than enough for a cheap price.- Price! On sale or not, it's still either only $30 or $50.- It functions well enough. It has the basic package of social media that can be downloaded. I use FB, Twitter and IG. I can download all of these.- Continuous scrolling in KindleCons:-The plug where the charger connects to the device (not the other USB end), is hard to charge. It is hard to push into the device and it takes a bit of a yank or wiggle to get it out of the device. I can't see this charger or the charging port to last long at all.- Gets warm after only a BIT of playing.- Slow as a slug. Slow in everything it does. I'm not in a huge rush to play or read, but it's something to keep in mind for other users. Even Kindle, if I leave and re-enter sometimes it takes for a solid bit before it really loads.- Questionable idle battery life and even more questionable active battery life. This guy DRAINS. In a world of portable batteries, it's not much of an issue, but still, battery does not last as long as it is advertised.Overall:I still love it. I don't demand much from it. I certainly don't expect much from a cheap tablet. However, for it's price, it's really good! With more and more parents shoving devices to their kids, I can see this as a starter tablet (they have kids versions too!) instead. 8/10.
title: It's fantastic considering it's price and how cheap it feels

review_content: This device is insufferable. author: Horse Farm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2019
review_content: Good:  cheap when it's on sale.  Good choice of colors.Bad:  horrible screen, lousy viewing angles, bad color reproduction.  Battery life is so-so at best (probably would be better if not for the various Amazon apps' constant phoning-home).  The built is also not very good.  The plastic backing is creaky and feels fragile (get a case--a cheap one, it makes no sense to spend an appreciable portion of the cheap tablet's price on a case).  The worst part is Amazon's so-called App Store.  The "store" is filled with IAP-infested garbage.  No alternative browsers, no Duolingo, and apps for some of the smart devices (that work with Alexa) aren't even there.  Sideloading apks can make the tablet barely usable for things other than watching movies.  The Silk browser bypasses DNS settings, so forget about blocking ads in the browser (but a good DNS ad blocker does prevent Amazon apps from reaching Amazon servers, as a result, they would try and retry incessantly and drain the battery).  The lock screen ads aren't too bad, just irrelevant.  You'll quickly learn to ignore them.Bottom line:  don't pay full price.
title: Good thing it's cheap (when it's on sale)
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Antulien37
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2019
review_content: We use these exclusively for our kids because of FreeTime. The value is in being able to control the content and put time limits in how much they can play. The “goals” I’ve mostly found useless because even the educational apps are categorized as “games”.We were initially happy to upgrade to the New Kindle Fire 7 as we had 5th Gens that were laggy and annoying. The tablet does seem to run smoother and the screen is nice. The battery life is not so good.The biggest problem with this new tablet, though, is that MANY kindle apps (free and paid) will NOT appear in Amazon FreeTime NO MATTER WHAT. I’ve spent hours browsing the forums, on instant chat and on the phone with customer service. Everything has been tried. Nothing fixes it. They replaced the first two we ordered that had the problem. The third has it also. Amazon CS doesn’t seem to know whether it’s the device or a software problem or an account problem.I suppose it wouldn’t be such a big deal if the apps that won’t appear (they play fine on the adult profile btw) weren’t the kids favorites or apps that I’ve paid for!  They worked fine on the 5th Gen!At least videos work and some of the apps works. I just hope Amazon will fix it.
title: Trouble with Freetime

author: Mary M. Thumm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2019
review_content: I rather like that it "chimes" when turning on or off. It is more "responsive" on the touch screen. My older one had issues with that as I think the touch screen was old. As of now, I'm using it mainly as a reader.  I have not put much on it, as I'm concerned about is memory. I used my older kindle as a tablet for games and one game in particular blew through all available memory, plus a 32gig memory card. So that is a "wait and see" issue. One of my favorite things to do in the summer is reading outside. The glare of the sun usually makes it impossible to see the screen, and therefore, read. I have not tried it yet, so I can't really judge if the screen is different or not. Overall, I like it, but I can see myself using it more  in the winter than summer, and using it mainly as a "reader"over a tablet.
title: It chimes!
