author: Just an average shopper...
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
review_content: Bottom line: this is an outstanding little tablet that certainly fits my needs for a more portable device.I have owned the Kindle Fire 8 2018 and traded It along with another device to have two 20% trade-in discounts and of course the credit (though Amazon was stingy on the trade in credit in that Fire). I now own the Kindle Fire 10 (2019) and the Kindle Fire 7 (2019).First be realistic - this is a 7" tablet which offers more screen real estate than a cell phone but is not a full screen tablet. It is not my choice for watching movies and working at home (that's the Fire 10) but the 7 will be when I am traveling light and I want something larger than my cell phone.Performance is decent. It is not lightning fast but it is very fast compared to my 2012 Nexus 7 it replaces in my lineup. The 16 Gb is ample even for downloading a few movies and certainly plenty of reading content.The single speaker is good - I certainly do not find it annoying - but if traveling I will be using a BT headset or can use an external speaker.Bottom line: on sale, and then with the trade in discount, this tablet cannot be beat for an on the go, toss in your bag device (<$35).If you are comparing it to an Apple or other more expensive device, just don't - you will absolutely have better screen resolution and performance with those devices! Also it will cost you at a minimum 5-10 times more money. Buy one of those if that's what is important to you.
title: Great tablet for what it is intended
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Katelyn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2019
review_content: So now that I've had this tablet for about 4-5 months, I think I'm ready to review it. And mind you I am not a tech expert telling you everything about its build, but I am just your "average Jane" who wanted a user friendly mini tablet.I wanna start off by saying that this tablet is good for some things, and bad for others. If you want a real tablet, go elsewhere. If you want either something for your kid or a small, on-the-side-of-your-phone entertainment device, this is better. I already have a Samsung tablet to go with my phone, which I use for more advanced computer-like purposes, but I bought this Fire 7 to use more for basic fun and entertainemnt. It's there for when I want to watch TV, movies, or videos, play games, listen to music, etc. when I'd rather give my phone a break from use all day - or for when the phone is too small, or the Samsung tablet is too big. So, the 7 inch screen is the correct size for easy carry but still large enough to watch vids or play games.Before buying, I was intimidated by other reviews of "horror" stories about this tablet doing weird things, working on its own, being too slow, etc. and I want to say to all, that I have not had any of these issues after 5 months of moderate use, *for what it's intended for*. Of course if you want to go downloading a bunch of stuff to it that is more suited for a real tablet or smart phone, you might slow it down/mess it up a bit. Mine is not too slow, nor does it do anything haunting.One down side to it however is the battery life...it is not good. It might last a day on a full charge, and even when sitting standby, the battery is dropping as though it has been being used non stop for game play. So be aware of that. Oh, and the screen is a cheap plastic too. I hated how my finger would drag on the screen to operate it, which is something I don't notice many others mentioning. SO, for not a whole lot of money, I would invest in a glass screen protecter like I now use for it in order to have a smooth screen that more resembles a real tablet/smart phone. I also put a case on it, which there are many more options and varieties available on Amazon other than what they try to sell with the Fire 7.P.S. The add that displays on the lock screen is not a big deal at all. Some make it out to seem like its horrible, but just swipe to unlock the thing and the add goes *poof* gone. No need to spend extra money to remove that unless you really really need to.Overall, I recommend the Fire 7 for you, if you know what it is youre buying.
title: It can be worth it

author: Kimberly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2020
review_content: The main issue with this version of the Kindle Fire is how it constantly disconnects from wifi, and no, it's not the wifi signal.  No other device we've connected to wifi (anywhere) drops the wifi signal as much as this does.  At times, it can drop the wifi signal almost once every two minutes while you're trying to watch a show which is extremely annoying.  I've had to restart it multiple times for it to connect again.  My older (2014) Kindle Fire rarely drops a signal (the only reason I'm not still using it is because that version no longer supports vital apps like Hulu etc.)  Seems like a dodgy way to get people to upgrade (to an inferior product no less).Worked ok for 30 days, and then after that, constant dropping of signals.  I've read many reviews here that sound like amazon is shipping refurbed models when people have this issue and DO get a refund.Overall, extremely dissatisfied, and the reason for 1 star because what good is the quality of the video image etc. if it won't stay connected?  (And just a note: we've not only had the issue on our extremely strong home wifi network, but on other wifi connections at work, friend's houses, etc., so it is NOT our wifi connection.)  You'll note that when you search for "kindle fire constantly loses wifi signal" there will be tons of hits on google - it's not just me.Buyer beware.
title: Constantly drops very strong wifi connections - yes, everywhere
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Lou G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2019
review_content: The overall quality of the Fire 7 is pretty good.  I had no problem navigating through it and finding the apps I wanted to add.  I did have a lot of trouble finding the right mix of cords to plug it to the TV.  There are a few adapters, etc you have to get in order to do so.  I liked the old Fire tablets that had a mini HDMI connection.  The recent versions do not have this and when you search Amazon to find the correct cable, it can be confusing because of all the sponsored listings that are not what you are looking for.  I would give the Fire 7 and overall rating of 4 stars.  The reason I reduced by one was because I think Amazon should do a much better job of including the adapters needed or asking if I want to buy one.  They automatically asked if I wanted a cover to go along with the tablet but nothing about adapters to plug into either a TV or monitor.
title: Cannot plug directly to TV

author: Bookworm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2019
review_content: My tablet was starting to get cranky, so I was looking around for an inexpensive replacement for reading and web-surfing, and spied the Kindle on sale.  I mostly check daily things like email, news, social media sites, etc, in addition to reading.  I WANTED this to be a viable replacement for those tasks, but it just is not.The primary issue with this thing is SPEED - it is ridiculously and surprisingly SLOW.  Slow as in click on a link, put the reader down, sip some coffee, glance at the screen still loading, sip some more coffee, turn on the tv, and MAYBE the page will have loaded by then.  THAT kind of slow.  Mind numbing slow.  At first I considered the possibility of holding onto the table strictly for the purpose of breaking me of my internet/social media addiction!  I genuinely thought I might keep it just for that use, because waiting on pages to load would surely do it!  But it was just too annoying.The other deal breaker was battery life.  I read up on battery life before buying it, but I could not, in a week's long trial of day-to-day, normal use, get more than about 4 hours out of it before having to charge it again.  I don't do any gaming, I only very rarely watch video clips and never full videos on a device, and still I couldn't get more than 4 hours.As a READER this is a fine device - if you're buying one mostly for only that purpose, go for it.  If you're expecting it, as I sadly did, to be a serviceable replacement for a tablet, forget it.  In fact I can't believe I keep finding this LISTED as a tablet on online lists of "Economical Tablets."  I'm such a long-time Amazon customer and user, that this reminds me of the earliest days of Kindle's, which came packaged with something they euphemistically labeled an "Experimental Browser," which meant clunky and just barely there.  This has a full scale browser, and of course you can download others, but the processor speed is so pathetic it renders the browser virtually unusable.
title: Do not expect this to be more than a reader
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: K. Pittman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2019
review_content: I knew there was going to be a learning period, always is when upgrading.  I really dislike this product.  The download/transfer by USB does not work so if not at home with a WiFi connection you can't get your books.  They have made it much harder as they have grown the product to navigate though it.  It takes a lot of steps to get to your books, much less the one you are currently reading.On the plus side.  The screen is nice and clear, easy to read, good colors.  Perfect size.  Battery lasts a very long time.  The charging port being moved to the top is a wonderful improvement.I would not recommend this one to anyone.  Try one of the others first.  They are a bit more expensive but might be well worth a try.  I did love my original Kindle, got a bit spoiled I guess.  Better should not mean more difficult.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: I have purchased 4 of these Amazon tablets.Pros:  great value for the money. Small and light. Charges fast and keeps a charge pretty well. Great for my 8 yr olds to do their virtual learning zoom meeting and for playing their favorite games. Came in cool colors which made my kids feel like they were getting something true to their own taste/customized.Cons: HORRIBLY made charging port. Horrible. I originally purchased the kids tablet that comes with the blue or pink squishy case. It was on sale for $35. After 8 months the charging ports went bad, sometimes charging & sometimes not. The twins got bday money so they purchased this fire 7 tablet & I gifted them the comparable case. The charging port went bad on one of them. After 45- 1 hour with customer care (who was nice & helpful) I was issued another tablet. Problem is that a) she deactivated both tablets so I had to spend another 30 mins with customer care to reactivate the tablet that was working fine. B) the charging port on the replacement tablet went bad after 3 weeks of gentle use. I have to spend more time on the phone with customer care for a new one. What a mess!!  If you check out the reviews, the charging port is a reoccurring issue. Shame they won’t fix the flaw. If so, I’d be giving this 5 stars because it exceeds expectations for the cost.

author: Sarah Collins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: I am hooked on listening to Audiobooks when I travel.  I travel often in areas with poor cell service, and need to download the books to keep the narration from being interrupted.  I don't want to use my phone for books, so I purchased this small tablet  to listen to my Audible books through a bluetooth transmitter plugged into my car radio. First, when I leave the wireless connection, Alexa was notifying me was too often when there was no wireless service.  I had to disable Alexa notifications.  Second, if it is connected to wifi, I usually take several minutes to start playing the Audiobook.  So, I usually keep the device on airplane mode until I need to download another book.  Third, you would think if the device was connect to the wifi, all the updates would download overnight.  No, the last time I left it connected to the wifi, the next time I got ready to use it, it to at least 10 minutes before it was ready.  Fourth, the tablet stays in its Amazon case.  The bluetooth transmitter and the tablet connects without a problem 90% of the time.  When it is not connecting, I usually has to stop and restart the bluetooth tooth on the tablet.  What I don't understand is why must I open the tablet cover for the book to start playing after I hit play on the transmitter.  I don't have to sign into the tablet, just open the cover.

author: Joe Kerr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
review_content: The day I received it I set it up & charged it overnight. The next morning, I unplugged it, set it down, & left it for about 2 hours. I hadn't loaded any books or videos or anything yet. Came back, like I said, about 2 hours later, & battery had dropped from 100% to 81%. In 2 frickin hours with NO use. When was this piece of garbage made? 2014? So I plugged it back into the charger. I then proceeded to download all my digital purchases. Took me nearly the entire rest of the day, about 10 hours to download about 200 books, 1 because the WiFi on it is super slow, and 2, because the screen is clunky & doesn't respond very quickly. I unplugged it an hour before bed. An hour later, it had gone from 100% to 86% battery. In ONE FRIKKIN HOUR! I wasn't even using it! Next day, while I was reading on it (which is a chore, as pages are slow to flip & it often takes several 'flips' to get to the next page),  I noticed the download symbol in the upper left corner. So I swiped down on the notifications, & watched as the device, without any direction from me, downloaded video after video after video. Videos of what, you say? Who the hell knows? It just listed them in notifications as "Amazon Video". I couldn't even find the videos anywhere on the device. So, the "videos" used up ALL my internal storage, so I had to put in a 32 GB class 4 micro SD card - I tried putting in a 64 GB GB UHS 1 card, the device didn't recognize it. The device itself told me I could only put a maximum of 32 GB in the external storage, & that it had to be class 4 speed or LOWER. Again, what is this, 2014? Then ALL my books & manga disappeared off the internal storage, so I had to spend another whole day redownloading to the 32 GB card. Every time I try to use the device, I see notifications for a dozen or more "Amazon Video" auto downloads. I don't watch videos on Amazon. I don't watch TV or any streaming services. I read books, manga, & comics. So I have absolutely NO IDEA what these mysterious video downloads are. As for the screen resolution, it's terrible. I ended up installing the Kindle app on my Samsung Galaxy Tab A 8" (2017 model) & it works perfectly. Way better resolution, and no lag. Also, no mysterious auto downloads. Also, if you want to use any apps other than the couple hundred crappy ones in the Amazon App store, you have to jailbreak the device (this part shown to me by a friend who is a software engineer, with his newly bought device, same as mine), then install like 5 or 6 apk files, then do a couple restarts, then you can actually load the Google Play Store app. You can also install other things with the ACMarket & HappyMod apps, & so on. You cannot put up widgets. You cannot play non-Amazon games (there's nowhere close to enough RAM anyways). The screen for this device doesn't have pages, it's one continuous scroll, so since there's no set dimensions, you can't load widgets of any kind. This thing has a VERY small amount of RAM, so I doubt it could even easily play videos on anything but a 4:3 ratio at VGA resolution. Don't waste your money. And don't even get me started on the literally HUNDREDS of ads I've BEEN FORCED to look at while using the device. Thanks, Amazon, real classy!
title: Just don't. Seriously, it's a piece of junk.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Carol A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2020
review_content: I liked the Size of the New KindleFire 7 (2019), but again like all the new models they have removed the Carrousel, an Amazon Representative assured me it was just like my old Kindle. So now, I own a 7 tablet a 10 tablet and a Paperwhite, with no Carrousel. I find all my tablets very unfriendly. On my old reader, I didn’t have to see all of my apps, I didn’t have to sort all of my books, because they were in the background, sorted by author or title. I could just use my friendly Carrousel to pick from the books I read every day and relegate any book that I wasn’t currently reading to my library and just choose from my Carrossel. All samples were on my Carrossel and I could read them, put them in my Library or delete them from my device is I didn’t like them.  So much easier to do and very user friendly. Not a million steps.  Amazon, when you have a good thing, don’t change it!!!! Please bring back the e-reader that has the Carrousel for the simplicity if for nothing else !!!! The picture quality on the new Kindle 7 is very clear and the sound for the audio books is perfect. That’s why you are missing a star, but maybe you should be missing two, for my frustration and money spent collecting Tablets.

review_content: A very low-cost option for a tablet.  Primarily used for email, some games, and internet search.  You can get this tablet with a variety of discounts to the tune of $40 or less.  As an Ipad user, the tablet those have limitations.  The Amazon App store is very limited--but does have some familiar items.  It can be used with Prime Video and Netflix.  However, battery life is short.  Lots of ads at start-up which can be quite annoying.  It can be used with Alexa, however, it will default to the tablet especially if another Alexa device is within earshot.  If you need a tablet for quick searches, the built-in browser is okay.  The tablet has a plastic backing, the screen is adequate, and speed is okay too.  Again low-cost option, but worth it for the uses, I described above.  It would be good for kids.

review_content: This is a basic cheap tablet. Nothing fancy. I bought this tab for playing sleep apps before going to sleep and occasional internet access. Screen quality is ok, you can see the pixilation on the screen but for my intended use its not an issue. My photos look ok but if  I wanted to show them to someone else id use my big Samsung Tablet. Battery life is ok. Use the tablet for aprox 8 hours a night with about 30% usage per night with the Bluetooth running. Seems a  little high but there is not a large battery with this device. Comes with a usb plug in charger that I can conveniently plug in next to my bed for an easy recharge while it plays the apps at the same time, so the battery is not an issue. The touch screen works ok. Sometimes can be subborn to respond but my regular tablet is as well so could be the nature of tablets in general. Granted for a price you can have this promo  that pops up after sleep mode removed, but that is never thoroughly explained at time of purchase and should be. The tablet itself is good for my specific purpose irregardless of the ads which I have come to ignore.

author: Arthur P Niederfringer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
review_content: Let me begin by stating I am visually impaired and benefit from large print and text-to-speech apps. Amazon tablets fulfill this need above all tablet brands I have used because the layout uses larger system fonts throughout.An apparent speed increase and increased space for apps and content makes 2019's Fire 7 feel faster to boot, load apps and change screens. But to get more speed, you need to remember that a tablet with 1GB RAM like the Fire 7 runs best if you go to Settings and disable those you don't use every day. For example, in Connected Devices, I shut off Bluetooth and Print services. In Wireless, I shut off WiFi if I am not on the web.  I turn Alexa off unless I need her. I absolutely shut off Location Based Services under Security & Privacy. Under Apps & Notifications, I block all notifications. The Settings panel is rearranged under the new Fire OS, currently 6.3.1.2, based on Android 7.1.2  This new OS certainly offers many new options to Amazon app developers. However, I have found some big changes from Fire OS 5 that limit the tablet's flexibility.Like Android 7, Fire OS 6 does not offer apps the  ability to write data to your SD card, including those from Amazon. You can no longer move any apps to the SD card.  I like to move data from my computer to my tablet, but, most puzzling, Amazon Drive has disappeared from the Amazon App Store. Only Amazon Photos remains and it's for photos only. I now use Dropbox. Its method is clumsy, since you can't copy a folder. You must highlight each file to select it. Then Dropbox offers to save all  to device, and the SD card is offered here. Dropbox is the best cloud storage service offered on the Amazon App store.I use my tablet mainly for reading magazines, newspapers and books, using Audible and the Kindle apps. This tablet retains the essential feature of turning a magazine page into text where the print size can be increased and the article read aloud by Amazon's Ivona voices. No Android or Apple tablet includes such accessibility features like the Fire tablets.Now that my 2019 Fire 7 tablet is faster, has more internal storage for apps and content, and runs the new Fire 6 OS,  I am going to request the Amazon App store to specifically add @Voice, the excellent text-to-speech reader, essential for visually impaired users.  It reads web content well with the tablet's Amazon Ivona voices.I reduced my rating to 4 stars since these issues surfaced after my initial review.If you try to load the Google Play Store, be advised that Google may no longer instal  on an unauthorized device like the Fire tablet. Google denied my second attempt to do so after I reset my Fire 7. This is fair, sinceI learned that  device makers have to pay Google a license fee to use Android on their devices. I am now completely in the Amazon sphere and all is running well now....Arthur.
title: REVISED: Improved Speed. Great Tablet for Visually Impaired. Fire OS 6 concerns.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Donald Shinn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: I replaced my old 2012 7" Fire Tablet with this one and was assuming it would be an upgrade. Sadly, it's not. I absolutely love my 10" Fire Tablet, but this one just doesn't measure up to it or my much older seven inch tablet. The color saturation is lower, colors aren't nearly as sharp and vibrant as on the ten inch Fire tablet (or the older seven inch tablet.) The image quality is lower also. Text in particular is harder to read and seems oddly black and white mixed together and not a solid black. The build quality is lesser also and feels cheap and plasticky. I probably should have kept my old 2012 seven inch Fire tablet instead of trading it in. I'd just assumed the newer model would be an upgrade. That's how things like this typically work. Not so much this time. If you need a cheap, somewhat disposable tablet, and the color reproduction and text clarity aren't important to you, then fine, get one of these. Otherwise, I'd look for other options. There's just nothing about this tablet that's better than my old one from 2012 and much that seems to be downgraded. This was a swing and a miss to me. I'd assumed the quality would be similar to my ten inch Fire tablet and this one isn't even close. Maybe mine's a lemon, but I suspect this is the new norm for the lower end Fire tablets. My cheap smartphone has a better screen image than this tablet.Edited to add. On top of everything else, it's now dropping my wallpaper, switching apps on its own, launching apps with no input from me. Shutting down apps wile I'm trying to use them. This is my fourth Kindle Fire and it's by far, and I mean really by far, the worst I've had. I've had to do a factory reset, but that only helped for a few days. It's going back.
title: Very disappointed.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Emilia Aradia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2019
review_content: Just got my second Kindle Fire - a Kindle Fire 7 (9th Generation) to replace the Kindle Fire (1st Generation) I had that broke a bit ago. I did not enjoy reading eBooks on my small phone in the app, nor was it worth lugging around my large gaming laptop to do so, either, so it was time to invest in a new eReader. I tried to order from Amazon, but they seemed to have gone out of stock between when I added it to cart, and when I checked out, so I ended up going to Best Buy to get one the same day. I've had it for a few days, and I have to say, it's great! I did not purchase this expecting it to be the fastest tablet available, and it isn't, but it does its job. I am able to browse Facebook and Twitter at a decent speed, and reading books is a breeze. I plan to get a microSD card to improve on the limited space that the 16GB brings to the table, but other than that I have no real complaints besides the awkward placement of the speakers (I feel like my hand should go there!). The battery life if "okay" - it certainly isn't the 8 hours it brags, but I would say around 5-6 hours of continuous use at a lowered brightness (as I read things) it should hold up just fine; It will last even longer if you are just reading and not browsing. All in all, a decent tablet at a more decent price - even better if you snag one on Prime Day! Also makes a Kindle Unlimited subscription SOOOO worth it.

author: SunKira
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2019
review_content: I upgraded from my Fire HD 7, which was working fine, but I wanted the new features of the All-New Fire 7 since it has Bluetooth, Alexa, camera, and SD slot; not to mention the great price!  I was really surprised at how "crisp and clean" everything looks.  The streaming is so much better on this model with a cleaner picture and better volume.  I like the keyboard better too.  Battery life seems to be the same, although I expected it to be longer on this model, but that's not a deal breaker for me.  I just received this last night, so I'm still learning about everything.  So cool though when I asked Alexa this morning who won the game last night between the Cleveland Indians and the Chicago White Sox.  I got the answer so quickly and she understood my question!  I wish my car phone would understand me like that!  That thing can't even understand the numbers I say.  So bottom line, I definitely recommend this new version of the Fire 7!

author: JM Ray
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2019
review_content: This is my first tablet, purchased solely to be able to watch United Airlines inflight entertainment onboard their flights. The latest United app cannot be downloaded on this even after installing Play Store - That's United's fault, not Amazon's so I'm not rating them based on that. Before purchasing, everyone should know this tablet does not have access to a full app store; just a limited one designed specially for this product so it isn't really a full working tablet. That is Amazon's fault.I've also had difficulty getting books to download from other websites. It seems only to accept Kindle books downloaded from Amazon and not from the library or other sites even if they are Kindle books. I have to download them to my computer and then email them to my Fire.I find the tablet a little heavy to hold for reading a book and the screen has a lot of glare. I can't read with this for more than a half hour or so without getting eye strain and a headache. My old Nook has a much better reading screen. The sound quality is poor for watching movies or tv, but certainly a much better size than my phone for that purpose. I find the tablet cumbersome to use and not at all intuitive. The constant ads are annoying. I wish it would stop trying to get me to play Keno and Clash of Clans.I have a Macbook, an iPhone and a Samsung phone. This seems to combine everything I don't like about each of those and very little of what I do like. I would not recommend this tablet, even for the cheap price. I didn't expect much, but this doesn't even meet those low expectations.
title: No United App

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
review_content: I bought this on Prime day because it was on sale and I had an upcoming trip and did not want to lug a bunch of books across the country on 4 different trips. I couldn't believe the price difference between the Kindle and the tablet and that the kindle was so much more $ even though the tablet could do more. So, here's the run down now that I've used my boyfriend's old black/white kindle and this tablet. I also suspect the tablet is cheaper because it is more in demand than the kindle. Overall, think about how you plan to use the device and what's most important to you in the device.Pros: versatile tablet that you can download shows (Netflix) and watch on the airplane, read ebooks, search the internet, download just about any other apps. It's very compact and I sprung for more memory (32G) and have been very happy. 7 inch screen is plenty for me to sit in the dark and enjoy a show. Not big enough for a group to watch, but plenty for 1-2 people.Cons: The biggest cons are that the screen has a lot of glare (much like a typical tablet). Additionally, it is a slow processor. I'm able to watch downloaded shows just fine, but I've not really tried actively watching over wifi all that much. I notice the slow processor when I go to open another app... I click on it and nothing happens... I wait and wait... and then something pops up. Sometimes it is super quick and other times it is sluggish. I still love the device, but it can be slow at times. I wish this had a screen more like the Kindle for reading because the glare really bothers me because I read a lot on vacation in the sun. For that reason, I sort of which I spent more for the kindle, however, I LOVE being able to download shows all in one device, so that is really NICE!!Note: you cannot listen to Google music on an Amazon device... this was a con for me since I subscribe to Google music and have downloaded playlists for the airplane. Not a huge deal, just had to have both my phone and the tablet accessible.

review_content: Pretty! Amazon represents that this device will display Kindle format, and PDF format documents. It also represents connectivity with PC or Mac computers.I have connected it to three computers, two of them Windows 7 Ultimate, and one of them Windows 10 Pro, and the device does not show among connected devices on the computer. I know how to geek, but consider it a waste of time when i have higher priorities.I buy a lot from Amazon, and don't mind suggestions. But this appears exclusively as a storefront for Amazon. date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
review_content: The single speaker has been improved, so the sound is better over previous models & the tablet works well with, apps, surfing the web, alarms, and reading my kindle books. However, this tablet did not meet my needs. My 2015 fire that wore out worked better for what I wanted. I needed a small tablet to take to work, so that I could play my Facebook games on a bigger screen than my phone. Initially I was able to do that. I downloaded FB & played my games, but after several weeks, I kept getting kicked off the games. I tried uninstalling then reinstalling & when that didn't work, I uninstalled FB, but it wouldn't reinstall. I called Amazon & the customer service representative tried her darnedest to help me, but no success. The best she could do was help me download FB lite. I can play my games, but unlike the regular FB app, I have to log into my games each time. The whole point of getting the newest model was to have a small tablet so that I could play my FB games on a bigger screen than my phone without any issues & this one fails. When the new "8 fire comes out, I will be buying that.

author: J. Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
review_content: Bought this for my 6 year old to replace a Nabi tablet (that was a replacement for a Samsung tablet). I thought I hated the Nabi, but now I can't figure out if I hate the Nabi or the Fire tablet more. This thing is SO slow. It takes forever to load, download, ECT. I side loaded Google play because all the apps I had previously purchased were from the Play store, but of course Amazon and Google can't play nice, to the detriment of their customers. Within a month this tablet was shutting off sound in the middle of a movie. Doesn't matter if it's Prime movies, YouTube, whatever. The sound randomly turns itself all the way down and my son has to toggle it back up. I contacted customer support and keep being told to reset the device. Gee, thanks, I'll just reset the device multiple times a day. No problem. I've tried taking the case off the tablet, thinking that was the issue somehow. It's not. The tablet will also randomly freeze and need to be restarted. I have an extra SD memory card to take some of the strain off the device, but it doesn't seem to make a difference. The one thing I will say is that this thing is fairly indestructible with the case that I have on it. It's been dropped, thrown, stepped on, and the screen is still intact. (And btw all the other problems started before the tablet with abused....with the problems and the resulting frustration of my 6 year old most often being the reason for the abuse). Pretty much we will use this till it's dead and then never buy another Fire tablet again. I really do love most things Amazon, but I'm just super disappointed this time.

title: POS
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: panfriednoodles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2019
review_content: Let's start off by saying right off the bat that this should NOT in any way be your primary tablet. It shouldn't even be your secondary tablet. At best this could be a tertiary tablet. But at this price point, for very specific use cases, this is a recommended purchase.The first thing you need to realize is that this is a highly subsidized piece of hardware on sale for the price of a pork chop at a decent restaurant (I got it for $29 on Prime day and see it is now on sale for the same price in Septemer 2019). Do the technical specs suck?  Absolutely. Is the battery life and non-usage battery drain painful considering there is no cellular connection in the background?  Sure. Is the lack of access to Google Play Store and Amazon's overt, aggressive, and unapologetic efforts to get you to spend money in their ecosystem annoying?  Hell yes.  Does the Amazon skinned UI / UX suck donkey balls? You bet.  But even with those faults there are some redeeming qualities that make this worth $29, maybe even $39 or $49.Pros- Expandable memory as primary memory - I'm surprised this doesn't get mentioned more. The 16 gb that comes with it ends up being 10 usable, so of course I added a microsd card. I was a little surprised that the 64 gb card that I initially inserted was rejected and the tablet said I needed to use a class 10 card. Odd, since I was only planning on adding some mp4 movies and my other tablets / devices don't care about read -write speed.  So I put in a class 10 card I had lying around and configure the Storage settings. Turns out the microSD card ends up supplementing the primary 16 gb of internal storage. That is to say, most apps will install on the microSD card. Also, more importantly for me, Netflix, Spotify, and Amazon Prime movie and music download to the SD card. Let me repeat that - DRM protected content that won't download to my SD cards on my high end Samsung phone can be downloaded to my $29 tablet + $23 microSD card.  This is huge for me. I got an iPad over an Android tablet for my 10" tablet because I wanted to watch offline content on the plane. I can now do that on my $52 cheapie tablet.Hands-free Alexa - this 2019 fire 7 has hands free alexa, which basically means I'm getting an additional echo dot that doubles as a tablet for $29. Awesome. It actually convinced me to buy the Amazon cloud can for my baby monitoring. Now when I'm home I leave my tablet plugged in on the nightstand and can say "alexa, show me the baby" (I named the cloud cam over the crib "the baby") and the screen shows me the baby. Again, for $29.  Considered getting the 8" for show mode, but I already know all the Taylor swift lyrics by heart.I'm not going to go through all the cons I listed above and that are all over the reviews. The specs are ~2013 (MediaTek 1.3 GHz / 1 gb RAM, 600 x 1024?  yikes). But an echo dot, baby cam, bedside Kindle reader, and airplane offline movie viewing and book reading device, sure sign me up for $29.  Just make sure.you have a real tablet also for actual browsing, productivity, gaming, etc.Like I said, for specific use cases, this is well worth the money.
title: Technical Review from a sophisticated engineer
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Taylor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2020
review_content: Slow but cheap. Installed Google Play(easiest thing in the world to do) and it barely handles it. A couple apps like YouTube and some very low end games will make this tablet just about unusable. I had to delete just about everything but barebones software to get her to not spend 20 seconds loading Netflix. I caught it on sale for $30 so I really shouldn't be complaining but for those looking for a the best all around Fire this is not it. Screen is super grainy due to the low resolution and dpi but if you have little kids this will probably do. If your looking for a Fire that is super affordable and performs quite well considering, spend the extra $30 and get the 8" Fire HD. It's much quicker and better in every way. I have Google Play Store on mine and it runs all my apps just fine. Little to no lag and the battery last twice as long as the 7" Fire. Honestly the 7" is really just for kids, no adult would put up with the tablets shear sluggishness and inability to do just about anything.If you have the money though the new Fire 10(9th Gen)is what you want and for the money it beats out any other tablet on the market ATM. USB-C PD 15watt charging and a quicker, snappier octa-core possessor that is incredibly efficient. Beautiful 10.1" display in true HD. So many good things to say about it I could go on an on.Anyway, this is about the new 7" Fire. It's awesome as a paperweight. Can't think of too many other reasons anyone but a child would be content with it. It's not the worst tablet out there, if you're these people that still have a whole slew of units, I mean kids, then yea snatch up a few and stick em in their face they'll shut up so you can actually get stuff done around the house.

author: Chris Williams

review_content: First fire tablet I have owned... I do own several other smartphones and tablets,etc... But this was my first fire tablet... author: Nikki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2019
review_content: Purchased 4 of these on sale for Black Friday price. I will be giving 3 away (Sage, twilight and black) and kept 1 (black) to be used as a car video screen for baby.This tablet is perfect for what I need it for. I was able to download videos/shows from Netflix and Disney+ for Car rides. Baby is rear facing still so I purchased a Velcro tablet holder which is amazing and holds it in place when driving.  He hates getting in his car seat and gets restless during long car rides; since installing this on the headrest he hasn’t cried or whined Even when tired. He looks forward to the show and gets super excited when it starts. Very adorable and priceless for a mother that has things to do. Even with video playing he was still able to fall asleep during a long car ride.I gave this a 4 out of 5 stars only because the lock screen shows advertisements; kind of annoying and worried Baby or baby nephew (Christmas gifts) might accidentally click on ads when trying to turn on the tablet. It shows car insurance ads to game app advertisements (very colorful). Hopefully, parental controls will help. For the 1 year old he just swipes screens with his full palm so this may be an issue for him. If I had to pay full price for this tablet I would have returned it just because of these annoying ads but since they were on sale it’s hard to pass up the deal and am willing to put up with it unless it becomes a problem for the kids.The screen is a good size and light weight for toting around town. Will be used for car rides and at restaurants when kids start getting restless. Purchased durable cases for the kids and screen protectors too. A review video said his kids have had this tablet a long time without breaking it bc it’s made of plastic so that’s why I chose this vs. an iPad for the kiddos.16 GB really is not a lot of memory because once you download the main apps you use there’s not much left over for downloading content to use when off WiFi. It does come with an SD slot so may need to think about purchasing extra storage.Other than that, it has been a wonderful addition to my Chevy for entertaining baby. It’s sleek, video quality is amazing and doesn’t buffer when Driving offline. The sound is amazingly pretty good quality and loud enough even when mounted on the car headrest. no need to Bluetooth it to the car speaker or external speakers. super glad I bought this instead of having TVs installed in the car seats. This was very cost effective and you can move the tablet around or take it with you.Baby approved!UPDATE April 2020:Ads not as bad as I thought. Love the tablet more than expected since it is very light weight and durable. Everyone I gifted these to loved them and use this on an daily basis. Perfect for movies and games. also use this for home security system/watching my son play in the other room while I work from home (quarantine life).Cons:LAG-TIME!!!! Omg just to turn this thing on or switch between screens or apps takes forever and you keep retrying and eventually makes everything get all messed up or shut out!! Super frustrating would not recommend this as a work tablet, etc. too annoying. Come on Amazon! You can do better than this!!!Memory at 16gb is more like a generous 10gb which is nothing by the time you put on standard apps. Purchased a separate Samsung memory card for ~$20 (128gb) which did the trick!ABCMouse apps are limited and difficult to use these educational games for my son With his tablet due to major lag-time!!

author: Erick Legue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019
review_content: I've had previous Kindle Fires in the past and they've always been good values, but this model is much lighter and sleeker than previous models, making it much easier to carry and hold. The new On Deck system automatically downloads episodes of shows or movies I might be interested in to watch on the go when I may not have internet access, which is fantastic. The genius of On Deck is that it only uses free storage to save suggested downloads, so if I use more storage for things I download, it removes or downsizes On Deck content to free up space. The usefulness of this feature has introduced me to some new content that I'm really starting to enjoy and it's convenient to catch up on shows while working on other things as opposed to just mindlessly watching television on a couch. The Alexa integration is also very useful, especially when I'm not near an echo device. Searching the web via Alexa is vastly more convenient to using search engines in the browser using the on-screen keyboard.
title: Latest model and OS is a huge improvement

author: Overland Park, KS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2019
review_content: Traded the gen 5 for this one. See it as an upgrade for the 16GB internal memory, both the 2.4 and 5.0 wifis, cameras, new battery, Alexa voice on demand - as opposed to touch screen prompting. The 5.0 bandwidth boost is good for streaming. Will go to 512GB expandable memory which may come in handy, but I'm fine with 64, so far, using wifi, wifi cloud, or OTG. Works with Gen 5 cases, after some alteration. Gen 5 cases don't do the sleep/awake thing. Am not a gamer, or an artist.  Use it for music, videos, photographs, and documents, like books, magazines, etc.  CON: have not been able to access the 16GB memory. Use EStrong File Manager, VLC, and San Disk Memory Zone. Those worked on my Gen 5 and my Gen 7 10.1". Tried tethering to a Windows desktop, but it can not see it either. Did wifi DL an Adobe file, then was able to move the file onto the expandable memory. Would like if an Amazon tech can show me how to access the user portion of the 16GB.  Would probably upgrade in another 4 years, as well as my 10.1 Gen 7.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2020
review_content: First of all, this thing is a good budget tablet. I mean seriously. It works really well and could be sold at 3x the price for how well it works. If you have kids that want a tablet this is a good choice (don't bother with the kids version of it. This thing is tough.)Battery life is ok. It will last almost all day if you use it a lot. The older versions seemed to do this better though, with no obvious reason or improvement between the versions that justifies worse battery life.It has ads on the lock screen. Its $40. No big deal.The OS this thing runs has tons of annoying quirks. Screenshots are darker if you take them with the brightness down, for example. If you screenshot, you better turn the brightness all the way up first or the actual screenshot will be too dark. Not joking. Its annoying. Its probably a bug. They refuse to fix it.There is no way to set the time yourself. If your power goes out and your wifi box reports the wrong time to this thing (typically, it will say its midnight after power outage) you're stuck with the time wrong until it checks again, which can take all day. Hopefully it doesn't happen at night if you use this as your alarm.Icons on this thing are awful. Terrible. They are just the name of the app with the amazon smile thing under it. Finding your photo gallery is a huge pain because of it. I've never seen worse icons on anything.
title: Good tablet. Bad software.

author: Margaret Gayle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: I purchased this to replace an older, larger Fire, mostly because the price was good. But I should have spent the extra dollars to get the next larger size. There's no comparison. Amazon does many things right -- for example, the glass on the screen is the same great quality, etc. -- but the difference in viewing satisfaction is very noticeable. When reading, there's more squinting or page-turning; when playing a game, it's just not as much fun; and when watching a video, you're missing a lot that you see on a larger screen. That said, it has a great alarm clock system and if you use it primarily for that, it's a great choice. (I need multiple alarms each day for various events, and Kindle handles them beautifully with full control over the settings.) But if you want to use it for something that involves your eyes for any length of time, by all means go bigger if you can.

author: Michael Sweeney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: Every professional review I have ever read says to get the 8 inch instead of the 7. I have had two 8s and they are fine. I like them. The only reason I bought this one was to give as a present for someone I didn't know well and this was appropriately priced. Circumstances changed and I ended up keeping this Fire. I must say that I really like it. I only use it for watching videos, light games and occasional web browsing. I actually prefer this 7 to my 8 because it is easier to hold. The screen is larger than my phone, but it is light enough that it doesn't bother me to hold it up while laying in bed and watching videos. I would not pay full price for any of the Fires, not because this isn't worth $50, it is, I just wouldn't because they are consistently on sale for half price a few times a year. Plan ahead, get a great deal and enjoy this for the device it is. The Fires are absolutely great at what they are, lightweight, low-cost tablets that give you a bigger screen than your phone. They are terrible at being what they aren't. They are not several hundred dollar computer-equivalent tablets for serious work and multi-tasking. If that is what you want, plenty of top manufacturers are more than happy to take all of your money for that. That's not what I want, so that's not what I got.I like Alexa. I love Audible. I enjoy Prime Video and all the other streaming services. This gives me all of that and more.

author: Zoie W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2019
review_content: This is a decent tablet for the price. I needed a new tablet for work and could only afford this, so I am happy to have it. However, I want to let other customers know the things about the tablet i found annoying so they can if it bothers them.1. All ports and buttons (volume, power, charge, headphone jack) are on the top. In my opinion this isnt user friendly, very inconvenient and awkward to use.2. Every time you install an app (paid or free) amazon emails you about your purchase of the app. Turning off notifications for the app store does not circumvent this.3. I personally should have read more thoroughly about the ads before purchasing, but in my head it would be small ads on the Home Screen and perhaps some notifications that are ads.Please note that the ads take up the entirety of the lock screen every time you turn the screen on. I turned my tablet's screen on for the first time to a full screen of "Game of Thrones Slot Machines!". Wasnt expecting that...One nice thing, however is you can change the settings to recieve only kid friendly type ads, in order to avoid obnoxious or awkward ads.4. The battery seems to drain as fast as my 3 year old, broken phone (Samsung Galaxy s7) I will update this review when I have timed the battery.5. In order to use any browser other than Silk (Amazon's Browser) you have to take several steps in order to download the Google Play store and then download your prefered browser there.6. The keyboard is very clunky feeling, and inefficient. There is no spell check, no numbers on the first page of the keyboard, and you have to cycle through 2 pages of the keyboard to find symbols and specific punctuation.7. This isn't really an issue, you can change it easily, but it was really amusing to me that Amazon is avoiding usage of Google products so much, they set Bing as their default search engine on these.Overall, the tablet is decent and I actually like the interface, but there are many annoyances in my opinion. As a picky person and a usual Android user, I would not choose this tablet if I could afford otherwise had time to save up for something different.If you have circumstances like me, however, this is a fairly good tablet and you can put some work and time into making it function better for you.
title: Decent Tablet, but has its annoyances.

author: Jarrod B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2019
review_content: I bought one a while ago (a couple of years ago), but found it so painfully slow and lacking basic usable apps that it now lives at my wife's shop as a spotify machine. But, when I saw the newest version had more RAM, a better processor and was only $8/month in sale, I decided to give it another try.Build quailty: Simple, but fair. All plastic but that isn't a bad thing. Doesn't feel flimsy and actually feels like it will hold up. No glass back to break, decent weight and comes with Bluetooth AND a headphone jack!Cameras. 2mp both sides. Still absolute trash, but for $40 I couldn't hope for much. Yet, the cameras are absolutely the worst out thereDevice options: Still uses micro usb, but that isn't always bad. Glad to see they kept the SD card slot!!! Good job. Makes for an even better personal media tablet. Headphone jack a nice keep as well. Built in Mic and well.... That's it. It is a cheap tabletSoftware: Here is where they get ya. This is designed to make Amazon and Bezos money. Right off the bat Amazon tries to entrap you into paying for extra services during startup. If you are not careful you may click on one and get screwed. Then, they burden down what was once Android OS with a laborious UI that slows.the whole thing down. Each screen is designed to keep you spending money at Amazon only. Even their app store is a limited, watered down version with apps that seem 2 years out of date, and they only have a 10th of what you needThey keyboard is kind of trash as well, oddly spaced and suffering with lag. The animations only highlight how slow 1gb of ram truly is.Then there is Alexa...Their spying app is just a resource hungry analyitic collector that bogs down the device to a crawl. Seriously makes it near unusable!But, there is hope...At its core, it *is* an Android tablet. And, if you use Prime and Kindle, the reader apps are great. But you don't have to suffer with poor apps. You can get Android's Google Play store on a Kindle and it wi!I run nearly every standard app! You will have to search but it doesn't require any programming knowledge at all! In fact, 10 minutes of clicking and a reboot later, and you can have any Android app you want! I have a REAL version of MS Outlook, OneNote and even Adobe apps on mine.Speeding it up is even easier once you unlock developer mode. Once you look up how to do that you can change ALL sorts of things! By reducing or turning off on screen transition animations , forcimg 2D hardware rendering and killing off some background processes (all just simple clicks, no programming knowledge required) it will be like a different machine! No "rooting" required, and no warranties voided!I would disable alexa. Not only does it suck resources, but Amazon makes no secret that it records all the time and their privacy "policy" doesn't exist compared to Google it Apple. Just say NO to Alexa.With Google Play installed and some system tweaks, you get WAY more than $40 should get you. It is pretty durable. Battery life isn't the greatest, but not the worst. It is a pocketable size, and the Kindle app is a must for book fans. I found that, once I Put Spotify, the Real YouTube and Google Podcast apps from the Play Store and slapped in an SD card for offline storage, you have all the entertainment you need for a day! It is not an iPad and not even 1/50th what a surface is, but for $40 and an afternoon of setup you have a coo little entertainment device.For even $50, if you aren't expecting a PERFECT device, you may find it the best casual device out there. A perfect airplane companiom, couch tablet or cubicle device to keep you entertained. And, a PERFECT book size.
title: Affordable. Accessible. Sandboxed. Not for creators but for entertainment ... With a few tweaks

review_content: WOW! What a disappointment! I ordered it in the July Amazon days, was told it would arrive August 4. Didn't happen. It finally arrive August 27. OK, I can deal with that. But. The battery power starts to go down as soon as you unplug the charger, and just keeps going down and down. And I'm only reading e-books! Second: least "sensitive" screen I've ever experienced. It just doesn't "get" your touch the first three or four times.  Truly annoying. Even though I got it for half-price, I REGRET the purchase. Save your money - wait until another couple of "versions" of this model have come out, then read all the reviews. This one is a MAJOR disappointment.
title: DON'T bother - wait until the next version

author: Elaine Gulliksen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2020
review_content: I bought this one to replace an old kindle Fire - which I LOVE - because it wouldn’t update apps anymore. I was excited to get my new one - what a huge disappointment!! The Home Screen is more complicated, I have to do more steps to get to my books, etc. Today I was at a Dr. appointment and turned on my new kindle to read. I got a screen saying I needed an internet connection to set up my Fire...it is already set up! I could not access the device past this screen. I had to turn on the mobile hotspot on my phone so that I could access what was already on the device. Similar things like this happen ALL the time, and today I was over it. I dug out my old kindle, charged it, and my books were all there right where I left them. I think I’ll be returning the new one - it’s just too clunky to use and NOT intuitive or user-friendly.

review_content: This is my fourth Kindle and until just recently I’ve never had a problem. I don’t know what they’ve done but the battery drains when it’s not in use. author: Avalane
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2020
review_content: I loved my first Fire tablet, but it became obsolete after all the"required" apps that were added ate up my storage space.It got to the point it was all it could do to load a book to read.So I upgraded to this 16 GB tablet, and ran the setup upon receipt.I've not loaded anything of my own and the new tablet will notrecognize content on my transferred SD card. It just wants to reformat it.I have less than 9 GB usable space and customer service says it isoperating system and my apps taking the rest of the gigs, except they areNOT my apps. I don't use most of them and they are not removable.Operating space use is expected and accepted.This is not a bad product, just be aware you won't get all it presentsto be.

author: Loren Davidson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: This is a decent device for what it is - basically, a means of reading ebooks. It has some other functionality, and I've used its browser maybe twice so far. Minor annoyance: sometimes when you turn on the Fire while in the middle of reading a book, not only doesn't it open to where you were in the book; you have to find the book again in the Books app. This is something that Kindle for Apple iOS doesn't screw up.My big disappointment is in the battery. While reading, it has enough juice to get me through a book without a recharge, and that's good.  But if I'm between books and don't pick it up for a week, it will be almost totally discharged. Even Apple batteries hold a charge better than that. My Fire is only about a month old, and it's annoying that I have to plug it in once a week whether I'm currently using it or not. If I can put a three dollar flashlight with AA batteries on a shelf and not use it for three months and then turn it on and have it work, why can't a $70 Fire do that?
title: Disappointed in the battery life

author: MimPep
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2020
review_content: Purchased 2019 Fire 7, 9th generationComparing to 2014 Fire HD 6I’ve had new Kindle for a little over a week.Pros:Weighs less.Easy to setup and sync.Brightness has greater range.It was delivered six days ahead of estimated date👍🏼👍🏼Cons:Not HD so pixels are more visible, especially when reading books.  Movies not as noticeable.Ads pop up while Kindle is off and stays on screen for a long time.  I waited 5 minutes before turning it off only to have another ad pop up.  This seems to slow down the tablet from charging.  I now power off the unit.Major irritation.  Sometimes the battery gets warm when charging.I still recommend this Kindle but be careful when charging.

author: Curious Epicure
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2019
review_content: I have two other Fire tablets - a 2015 7" one and a 7th generation HD8 - that I am comparing this to.I got the HD8 because I thought I would prefer the larger screen size. It also turned out to be much faster than my 7, which is sluggish in spite of having a chip, and it has a much longer battery life than the 7.I purchased the newest 7 because it turns out that I prefer the smaller size which makes it easier for me to hold in one hand (I use it mostly for reading Kindle books). That plus my HD8 screen developed a crack for no apparent reason. It still works with the crack, but it's a visual annoyance.So, back to the new 7" -Because it is a newer model and has twice the built-in storage, I assumed that it was going to be at least as fast as my HD8. I was wrong. This new 7 is maddening slow. It has a slow response time for most touch actions (half the time I repeat the action because I'm not sure if it registered) and downloading books from my Kindle library takes forever. I thought I'd gain speed with fewer books stored on the tablet, but that hasn't seemed to make any difference especially since waiting for the download is ridiculous. It is not related to my internet connection since my HD8 still downloads books in a split second.I have not tried adding more memory as a solution since the sluggishness was apparent right off the bat without my having downloaded any additional content, but I will try that as a possible solution.What I do like is the size, the price, and the sage color. The older Fire colors were frankly pre-school-color ugly. I am the type of person who can tune out ads and it seems the only ones I get are on the lock screen, so I'm okay with the lower price with ads trade-off.I think the Fire tablets are pretty darn amazing for the price, and I believe that you ultimately do get what you pay for. I'm just not sure why a newer model is so much slower than the older models I was seeking to replace. Not happy.
title: Great battery life, much nicer color choice, but is maddeningly slow
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: generic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
review_content: Annoying ads that appear every time you turn it on or wake it that have to be dismissed to use the tablet.Many apps you're used to not available: LastPass, for instance (and it's essential for me), and no real choice of browsers: Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Vivaldi, etc are not available.The main reason I got this is to use as an inexpensive way to access my cable channels in the kitchen using Cox cable's Contour app. It will inexplicably stop playing after some minutes, needing to be restarted. It's possible that this is an issue with Contour, but this never happens when using it on my android, iPhone or iPad.
title: It's a "you get what you pay for" kind of a thing.

author: CherryZipPurple
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2020
review_content: $50 might seem like a good deal, but mine (and my daughter's) are inoperable in less than a year of use.  This was purchased as a Christmas gift, and the 90 day warranty started on the date of purchase, so I only got 6 weeks of operation before the warranty expired.  Guess when it started to get very glitchy?  Yep!  Right then.It has always had trouble kicking me off the internet, closing apps and doing random things like adding something to my cart that I didn't touch.  Occassionally the keyboard would act up.  With frequent troubleshooting I persevered.Yesterday my keyboard became completely inaccessible.  I tried restarting, changing settings, I even tried the Japanese keyboard (googled it), but while I was able to then access the keyboard, it did type in Japanese and caused my search for buffalo plaid to result in Marie Kondo (absolute truth).  So, I finally called Amazon for help.While the customer service representative was polite, the only thing she could advise was a factory reset.  Ugh.  Not fun, but with a useless Kindle, I had to try.  This did not work.Keep in mind this kindle was purchased less than a year ago, was used less than that (for email, Amazon, pinterest and light browsing) and now is going to the electronic recycling center.I have never liked the comparison of kindles/android because the prices are so different, but even at $50, pretty badly functioning for only 10 months is a terrible deal.  I am getting an ipad THIS Christmas.Was it a lemon?  Maybe.  But I feel like Amazon is no longer producing quality products and standing behind them.This is the 8th kindle fire I have bought for my immediate family (more for relatives), plus a show, an echo and many dots.  I was considering purchasing dots for older family members (safety) but I think I have to break up with the Amazon products....  I have stood by Amazon (I still have my original kindle, pre-fire) and have been a prolific but trouble free (seriously) customer.  However, I am not a fool and won't keep buying kindles if they are junk and Amazon doesn't stand behind them.They DID offer me a  (small) discount to buy another fire, but why would I buy another after this disaster?  Would you?  Maybe it was a lemon, but if it was, they certainly didn't make it right.  Good luck if you decide to buy.
title: CAN'T TYPE, Inoperable (with light use) in less than 1 year
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Jean Souza
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2020
review_content: I purchased my Kindle 7 because I had a very old one that I used primarily for reading Kindle Unlimited books via Text To Speech and the battery was failing..  How disappointing to find that it doessn't seem to do Text To Speech.  Other reviews seemed to concur with this and recommend using a special App to do the speech.  Totally complicated.  Amazon Help was no help at all which is why I am giving the product, Amazon anyway, 4 stars rather than 5.After literally hours of trying to find a simple solution I finally struck gold with You Tube's "Text To Speech On Kindle Fire." the video by Kriston Johnson.  So simple and easy.  There are other videos but most of them recommend Apps, using the Blue Tooth feature, etc. etc.  None of that is necessary.  Others report that they managed to get it to do Text To Speech but it stops every few minutes and must be restarted.  I am not having that problem.  It just goes on and on, everything my old Kindle did just slightly different locations on the touch screen, easily gotten used to!  Now I absolutely love it and Kriston Johnson's video gets 10 stars.  Try it.

author: Wiccanlez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
review_content: As a person with disabilities, I love the fact that the Fire 7 is light and easily held in one hand. Makes reading and doing tasks easy with all the apps available. The brightness is adjustable to all light and the size of the type is easily adjustable for ease on eyes in reading and in viewing media. It's a little larger than a paperback and can be tucked into a bag or small backpack. I would get a cover for it just to protect the screen and because it's so thin and to make it more easily held.I wish they hadn't removed the collections feature. I have sheet music that I like to have in a folder in one place or certain areas of folklore or history in one place but now I can't. author: JS2012
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
review_content: Let me start by saying I rated this tablet based on a specific set of criteria:1. Price. Even though I paid a little extra to avoid Amazon's "special offers" (what a clever way of saying advertising) and the highest internal memory, I still ended with a tablet that does everything I wanted, and more, for less than $100 dollars. While that's not an insignificant amount of money, it was still far less than the alternatives, and frankly, I'm not going to lose sleep if I lose it or drop it or if it's stolen. I could afford a more expensive device; I just didn't need it.2. Access to my Amazon content (particularly Kindle books) and to Amazon in general. Adding a micro-SD card removed storage concerns for less than $20.3. Portability (bigger screen than my iPhone, but still small enough to hold with one hand,  tuck into a back pack or purse, car console or door pocket, etc.). I still have my original 10" Fire tablet, but I switched to the first generation Fire 7 when it first came out for its portability and the agility to expand memory with a micro-SD card. 4. Ability to access e-mail and surf the web.I don't use this device to edit or compose documents or graphics, or otherwise perform any processor- or memory-intensive tasks; I do that on my home computer.  For the same reason, I'm not concerned about what some perceive as a lack of software or Amazon's exclusion or blockage of Google Play apps (and yes, I know that there are ways of getting around this). The capabilities of the tablet and the apps on the Amazon App Store are more than adequate for the needs I listed above.If you need an actual computer in a tablet format, than maybe you should look at the alternatives. But for a small tablet that does simple tasks well and is easy to carry, I think the Fire 7 is an amazing value. I liked it so much that I bought new Fire 7 tablets for myself and my wife, and moved my original 7 to the garage, where I can use it to play music, or refer to online help and videos for automotive and home projects.
title: Great value for a tablet
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Without AdsColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Baroque Tossit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2019
review_content: I’m a semi-retired I.T. tech and one of my customers sometimes needs support when I’m out and about without a computer.  My smartphone doesn’t offer a screen large enough for remotely working on the client’s network.  I needed a device that (a) is inexpensive and (b) fits into a suit coat pocket,  and (c) can remotely access a Windows domain.The Fire 7 sometimes goes on sale, but even the full retail price met my first requirement.  (As a bonus, Amazon broke the payments into 5 monthly payments, no interest).I confirmed that the device will fit into my jacket pocket (although one of the jacket pockets is small, requiring removing the case that I bought for the tablet).  Requirement #2 met.Initial setup, including attaching to my Wi-Fi network, allowing all Fire updates to install, and going through the various menus and options took about 30 minutes.  This includes moving all of the app icons on the home page that I won’t be using into a folder and setting a login PIN on the Fire.I installed Splashtop Business from the Amazon app store.  I’m able to access (and troubleshoot) the client’s remote network servers and computers.  The screen of the Fire 7 doesn’t have great resolution, but it’s larger than my  smartphone screen and works well enough for my purposes.  Final criteria met.From there:I set up a new Gmail account specifically for the Fire 7, which doesn’t mean giving access to Amazon to my corporate account.I setup an HP Envy 5000 and a Sharp 3701 printer, using the IP address of each printer.  I wouldn’t want to print out the Encyclopedia Britannica with automatic stapling and hole punching using the Fire 7, but it does simple printing.I installed Private Internet Access using the Play Store app.  No problems, seems to work O.K.Encryption of the internal storage took less than 30 minutes, and I’ve noticed no degradation of performance (YMMV).I installed an office productivity suite (not that the Kindle 7 lends itself to typing large documents or editing spreadsheets, but in a pinch it’s a good app to have available).Loading Kindle books was, of course, a snap.  Reading e-books on the Fire 7 is not as good an experience as a Kindle Paperwhite (plenty of reflections outdoors), but O.K. as a time killer while waiting for my wife to finish shopping.ORIGINAL POST: I elected to stay with the native Silk browser - I’ve seen ‘how to’ articles on installing the Chrome browser, but Chrome tends to be resource intensive and Silk will most likely do for my purposes.  EDIT: 11/2/19 I've side loaded Chrome Browser onto the Fire 7, just to make life easier; I spend considerable time in Chrome professionally and I'm finding it easier to stick with one browser.  I've noticed no significant degradation of performance.I added a micro-SD card for extra storage (having gotten the el-cheapo 16gb Fire 7).  One thing the Fire 7 is missing is a decent file explorer.  I’m still experimenting with those apps - there have been security issues with some of them.  EDIT 11/2/2019:  I've elected to use File Commander for a file explorer.Battery life isn’t great, but I only need 5-6 hours so it works for me.The Fire 7 is marketed as an “entertainment” machine; I’m not much one for watching videos on a handheld device but it can show my “Prime” movies.  The 8 or 10 inch models would be better for entertainment consumption - they have more screen room and better resolution.  As noted, I bought the 7 specifically for its size, price, and capability, and I’m using it more for productivity than for media consumption.I’m rating it at 4 stars because it’s cheap, it’s easily transportable, it can be secured, it does what I need it to do and did I mention it’s cheap?  It doesn’t come close to doing what my iPad can do - but the iPad doesn’t come close to fitting in my jacket pocket or close to matching the price of the Fire 7.EDIT 11/2/19: I've ponied up the $15 to remove the ads from the screen - I got tired of seeing them.HTHRegards,Jim
title: Not just for entertainment consumption.  (Edited 11/2/19)
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Benjamen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2020
review_content: Overall I'm pleased with this Fire tablet.  I was going to buy a basic Kindle but figured this being about the same size with more versatility, I'd give it a go.  The OS isn't bad, much like Android, but not all the apps I'd like are available.  Nor is Chromecast available in the streaming apps I use, which isn't that big of a deal.  I can just jump back on my phone.The biggest design flaw for me is having the devices speaker on the bottom left side (figuring camera, volume and power button is on top).  I am right handed, so I tend to hold it in my left mostly which covers the speaker.  Again, not big a deal since I can reposition it.  But, using it with zoom, speaker location isn't condusive to camera location when typically held in left hand.Overall, I'm pleased with the device and the price is reasonable.  I'd recommend it.
