author: CJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: I got this for Christmas because my sister knows how much I love reading graphic novels but can't read them on my regular kindle or my kindle app on my laptop. Since I'm recovering from surgery, I've spent a ton of time on my little Fire 7 (I got a 64g card to add to it as well). I have always used Apple products, so adjusting to the Fire was a little challenging.  After having the tablet for a little more than 3 weeks, here's the breakdown of what I like:-Great control of functions; screen brightness, bedtime color vs daylight color, I love how I can just pull the top of the screen down to get to the main settings I want-Connectivity; very functional to connect to spotty wifi and Bluetooth headphones. I paired the Amazon Basics blutetooth wireless headphones with it and after a little struggle of only connecting to one ear or the other, they worked out really well when they both paired.-Reading; I love that I can buy books directly on the Fire instead of "purchase and send to" from the website. I love the controls it has for the kindle, and that I can also easily get magazines or newspapers as well as graphic novels. The guided panel-by-panel reading of the graphic novels on the fire is amazing because it allows me to follow the story in the correct order so I'm not going back and re-reading. Reading regular books is also nice, but the experience is not necessarily any more astounding than on the lowest-level kindle (which I also have) except that the interface on the fire for finding your books and collections is a bit more user-friendly.-Listening; I have a large Audible library and I love that it's so easily accessible on the device to see my books and explore others as well as purchase them directly. Book sound quality is tinny just streaming from the tablet but it's not exactly designed for that, and when connecting to headphones it's great. Now that I have the fire, I feel that I'll use my prime music more; before I hardly even remembered I had it but now I'm optimistic I'll stream more music due to the ease of it being right there.-Games; I've been playing solitaire and toy blast every day for hours (recovering from surgery remember) and the graphics are good. Ads are annoying but when the tablet is in airplane mode it works out great as ads don't play but you can still play the game. I've also installed some word games that are nice and don't have any glitches either.What I don't love:-Pre-installed apps; I don't want to put my email on it, or use the camera, or use half the apps that have come with it. I'd like to remove them, at least from my screen so it's easier to find what I do use, but I have not found a user-friendly way to do that for any of them.-Battery life when wifi is on; this sucks the life down pretty quickly. I'd say I get 5 hours of use before I'm at 40% when wifi is on and I'm playing a game and listening to a book. Pretty easy solve, but I dread what streaming a show would do to the battery life.-the ads or "special offers;" yes I understand this is how you can get a pretty functional tablet for $30 on holiday sales, but even on airplane mode I'm getting the lock screen advertising games or dog food. It feels like a bit of an invasion of privacy.-the notifications of amazon wish list items on sale or even sales; I know an item I have on my list is on sale Amazon, but that does not mean I want to order it right now or that I actually need it. I'd like to turn off the notifications but I don't want to miss notifications of my actual orders from amazon.Now, this is clearly no iPad or even and iPhone. It's not going to blow you out of the water regarding usability, but it is a great tablet if you want basic things from it. The battery life will limit you, but on airplane mode it's much better. If I was an actual gamer, or avid TV streamer, I wouldn't look to a Kindle 7 for my needs. At the price point of a $30 dollar tablet (during sales) you really can't beat the product if you're wired in to all different elements of the Amazon empire like Kindle, Audible, Goodreads, Prime, photo storage, Music and Video. Even if you're like me and use it for maybe 4 things instead of as a replacement for a computer or something, you'll still enjoy the experience.  I stuck a mini pop socket on the back of it and holding it is even more comfortable for my smaller hands.
title: Nifty little budget tablet for reading, games and music
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: juancarlospro
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019
review_content: Recently acquired 2 Amazon Fire 7, generation 9.So far it has been an adaptability process, like a roller coaster.One of my children is autistic and with his special condition he sees the tool very differently, the other is a normal child.Some pros and cons that I have observed so far:- Long durability, they are not the 8 hours that they promise, but it gives a quite acceptable performance, more than any other table of its same competition.- The ads for my autistic girl, it's a problem, she doesn't understand that and it breaks down.- If children are going to use it, before giving it to them, they must put a cover for children and its glass screen maker, it applies to any tablet.- The limitations that are had for the installation in the children's user, is striking.- Free content has many ads, should lower a bit.- They should negotiate with Google to install Google Play and yutube (we know of its separation and that it is possible to install it, we have already done it) that would make it one of the best tablets in the market, without being second to anyone.- The speed with which it works is very good, the level of cooling is acceptable for use.- The resolution of the images is kept in a very good range.- The resolution of the front camera could be improved, but for the price, it is possible.- The purchase via amazon prime on amazon day, very good offer, it was worth waiting for.- In short, until now the team, together with the child protection, has resisted, falls, anger, bad breeding, dirty hands, impatience, of my two children. Thank you Amazon because I can spend more time with my wife, without sacrificing the time we are close to the children.
title: My experience with children and amazon fire 7
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: wheatbix
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
review_content: I've only had this for a few days, but it's just okay. I'm not overwhelmed with joy. I bought it during Black Friday and it was $30, so I did not expect a lot from it. I wanted to try to play Pokemon Go and other games on it, but many of those aren't actually available in the App Store. I saw that there's ways to get it on there, but it's a lot of effort, and I can tell that it is probably too slow to run the program without a lot of glitching. Even brand new out of the box, the screen is very slow to respond to my touch. As an apple product user, I'm used to very responsive and quick touch screens. This one is a little bit excruciating to use as a tablet, so I think I will just stick to the Kindle features. Not a huge letdown since it was so stupid cheap, but would have been nice if it was more functional as a tablet. Maybe their newer, fancier, more expensive models work better. This one is just about right for $30.
title: Slow, but appropriate for the price

review_content: Takes forever after you hit a button for anything to happen so you are beating on the thing, not knowing that its changed screens and the next thing you know you are looking at things you never supposed humans were able to physically do sexually. author: Phillip Baxter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2020
review_content: We bought this on a whim as a cheap tablet upgrade for my kid. We already have a decent-sized library of games purchased on Google's Play Store. We had no interest in rebuying our entire library in a different app store, so we side-loaded the Play Store app onto the tablet, and downloaded the games. However, apps downloaded through the store cannot be added to the Kids Mode of the tablet! I see no reason for this other than requiring parents to rebuy games on Amazon's own app store.Looked into downloading a standalone "kids mode" launcher app, but the main one we found had several reports that on the Fire Tablet pressing the home button would simply close the launcher. The workaround required rooting the device. That crossed the threshold for me of being beyond the effort I was willing to expend to make this tablet work.Another option might have been to investigate using something like the Nova Launcher and trying to lock down what the account was able to do. The only remaining option was to leave the tablet in adult mode, giving our kid unfettered access to anything on the device, including full access to any Amazon Prime Video movies and recommendations for things (like teen/adult-targeted comic books based on my history of reading Star Wars comics) that I don't necessarily want him accessing at his age.In the end, it was too much effort to make this cheap tablet work.In addition, the cheap off-brand case we got was poorly designed, with the speaker holes redirected down into a 90-degree bend and out the back of the device instead of up towards the user (they should've flipped the main body of the case 180-degrees... how hard is this??), leaving the sound muffled and hard to hear.While we got the tablet on sale, by the time we paired it with the name-brand case, it would've only been another $10 to get the kids bundle, which included the case, a 2-year no-questions warranty, and a free year of their kids app/book subscription service. A no-brainer!But then the Samsung Tab A 8.0 was on sale for only about $35 more, and included a bigger, better screen, a case (that, to be fair, from reviews I'd seen, would probably need to be replaced), better processor/gpu and memory (important as the kid gets older and plays more advanced games), double the on-board storage, a much better battery, and a kids mode that we already had experience with from another tablet and that includes the ability to add all our existing Play Store apps. We decided that was probably a no-brainer.We returned the Amazon tablet, and are still currently using our older 10-inch Samsung tablet with only 16gb of storage that was a hand-me-down from a grandparent. Will probably go the route of the Tab A 8.0 when we feel a stronger need to upgrade.
title: Kids Mode Can't Use Play Store Apps
verified: Samsung made more sense

author: TLP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2019
review_content: A word to the wise regarding the trade in offer on any Amazon Kindle device. Before mailing the item for trade, make sure it is fully charged, and take a photo of the device switched on. Otherwise Amazon will tell you that the device was not functioning, and will cut your trade in amount in half. I submitted a functional device for trade, and this is what Amazon did to me, they are insisting that the functioning device I sent back to them did not work. I called customer service, and was told they can't do anything about it. So, be wary of this offer, because Amazon can do whatever they please once they have your device, and you can't do anything about it.
title: Beware of the trade in offer

author: Math Nerd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: Fire HD7 is slightly bigger than the Kindle PaperWhite ( which is about the size of a paperback book ), making it not quite as comfortable to hold.  The Fire HD7 also requires more frequent recharging, just about every other day as opposed to a week for the Kindle.  It also does not automatically open to the most recent page read, instead it displays an ad screen.  A swipe up will bring you to the menu screen.  I think the best way to use the Fire HD7 is to click on  For You  on the menu bar.This will display your most recent book as well as the previous 2 or 3.  It also displays the current outside temperature, and just below that your Watch List on Amazon Prime.  Unlike the Kindle, you can watch movies on the Fire.  I don’t.  If I’m going to watch a movie, I prefer a larger screen.At home that means my TV, on the road it’s my laptop PC.  One last difference.  The Kindle displays a yellow light while recharging, a green light when fully recharged.  The Fire has no such indicator, but it does display a progress bar at the top of the screen.  All that said, I still prefer the Fire HD7.  Book covers display in color, as do the Collections, which is a nice reminder of what books I have downloaded.  The collections screen could use some improvement.  The collection name is displayed in bright orange against a white background, which makes it difficult to read.  Not sure why Amazon went with a font like that.  An easy workaround is to triple tap between the collections boundaries, which magnifies the display.
title: Fire HD7 and Kindle Paperwhite comparison

So customizing personal reading experiences is an easy adjustment. The advertisements it came with were only on the lock screen so it's not really that big a deal. author: Ashley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
review_content: 5 stars for price; 0 for functionality out of the box.  So 3 average.  If you don't side load the Google Play store, I don't know what you would do with this thing unless give it to your kid. Yes one of my primary uses for a mobile device is as a Kindle - but I have a Kindle, an iPhone and an iPod for that. I have Fire Tv for TV. What would I do with this without Google Play?  (Oh, but still not all apps work, like 23andme.)  I got it to replace my dying iPod touch, so if Amazon ever seriously blocks Google Play, I want a refund.As a cheap way to get into Android, I'm glad I tried this when it went on sale on Prime Day, but only because of Nova Launcher. If Amazon successfully blocked it, again, this would be useless. Using side-loaded apps with Amazon's native launcher is the laggiest thing that ever lagged.  (Also, does anyone know how to fix the terrible autocorrect?  Duck I thought Apple's was bad.)Aside from the lagging (omg the lagging), the touch screen and keyboard in the native launcher are terrible.  I actually liked the way Amazon's is set up, but it was so rough, and slowwwww, especially compared to the ease of an iPhone.  Nova Launcher is the only thing that fixed this for me, even for Amazon App store apps, making the whole thing run much more smoothly. I'm still not crazy about the touch screen, but it's no longer aggravatingly frustrating.One thing that is incredibly frustrating is that push notifications are not reliably working for any apps - from the Play store or Amazon app store. I think I can fix it, but this thing is a lot of work. A lot a lot.Night mode/blue shade washes the screen out, but for reading it's fine. Regular mode looks nice to me (unless you're in a side-loaded app on Amazon's launcher - then it's wonky).It's fine as an iPod replacement, especially as it takes a microSD (one of the biggest pluses other than price), but overall I'm not impressed. I thought about getting one for my young kid, but I'm not gonna bother. He watches his Prime shows in the FireTV , so I don't see much use for this, at least until his iPad mini stops working. As much as I hate to say this, I'm sticking with Apple for my main mobile devices - as they stick it to me with their OS updates that purposely brick your device. I wish there were mid-price Android options that would compel me to switch.

author: Steve Cripe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review_content: The newest edition of the Fire 7 is a "good" quality. Screen is nice, apps all load and work without difficulty. I did not give 5 stars because the battery life seems to not be up to par with the rest of the tablet. The charge does not want to last 24 hours, so plan on charging it every day, although let it run down as much as possible before you charge it again so it doesn't form a "memory" in the batteries. Also I have found if you turn off the Wi-Fi when you are not using it helps to not drain the battery as quickly, and when you are done with it, don't just close the cover and allow it to be "turned off" that way. Hold the on/off button and completely turn the entire tablet off. This shuts more of the components down and helps conserve the battery also.

author: Angela Li
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: Granted I'm not a seasoned pro on the Amazon ecosystem, I picked up a pair of Fire7's due to the low price and seemingly grand-sounding specs (16gb, quadcore, bluetooth).  I am a supporter of the android/google ecosystem though so my expectations and opinions admittedly skew towards that experience.1. This is slow.  I've used 1st gen mini ipads that no longer support most of the current software, and it still feels smoother and lot more responsive than this Fire7 running an app.  It's already leaning towards a no-recommend unless you're strictly using this for reading, Amazon shopping, and Alexa-integration.2. Battery life seems pretty weak.  After struggling to work a few hours to download and work Skype, Google Sheets, and couple other cloud-cooperative productivity software, I was down to emergency plug-in.3. Skype, and I assume other apps, were not providing notification flashes as they arrived.  Nor do they provide badge counts on the icons.  After prolonged testing, I also realized Skype would not run in the background to the point it would receive messages until I loaded the app up.  What good is that???4. Google sheets, is stuck on the main page, when you try to tap on sheets, it just returns to this screen.  I cannot connect from a webpage, which usually prompts to edit using the Google Sheets App.  Nor could I open spreadsheets from Google Drive.  Hoping to use this as a mobile device at work around the warehouse makes this a feeble attempt.  I later side loaded Google Play and it's services just to run google sheets.  Now that it works, it's still slow to run, it does not seem to run multiple apps, or keep Skype running in the background to receive up-to-date messages between colleagues.  This also leads to a headache of figuring out how to remove initial google accounts so that I can distribute them out to workers.  THAT doesn't work, I had to remove the device from my google device ON ANOTHER machine in order to remove non-password access to my google account.5. The Amazon launcher itself is an issue to laugh at.  This is an endless barrage of lures to use, buy, subscribe to Amazon products.  Although this is a hack of android's system, it intentionally tries very hard to grant any useful access to Google productivity features.  It's an endless sea of book, video, product recommendations which likely are curated by it's hard-working engineers that studiously watch every move their users do to give them, "A simple Amazon experience".6. When I tried to use account permissions, eg. for kids and family members, I tried using this feature to lock out colleagues from basic amazon and google accounts used to set up productivity.  Nope, this does not work well at all.  If you grant some content, it's not app-related but the user gets suggestions of 'appropriate' videos, articles, or other consumption-based material.  If you grant  just the apps you want available, the user was presented with downloadable "something" of the 2 apps.  When I tried it, the apps did not load after downloading, and they show up in weird dynamic categories like:  allowed, or suggested, or recent.7. Overall, many people will find pluses if they are heavily invested in a certain ecosystem (Amazon, Apple, Samsung, Google, etc.)  If anyone plans to invest in a tablet with some freedom, I highly suggest saving a few bucks and go with an Android tablet.  If you want smoother integration into a fine-tuned tightly-regulated ecosystem, Apple shines above Amazon's.  If you are heavy user of Alexa, shop only on Amazon, and big-time 'consumer' of media, this could be seen as a great 1 or 2-year buy.  I do shop heavily on Amazon, however that alone is not enough to feel comfortable using this as a productivity tool day-to-day.
title: Maybe I'm expecting too much?

author: David Mootoo

review_content: I bought this with the original intention of giving it to my 8-year-old niece for her to use at school with distance education classes. Sadly, it did not reach her, because I have taken a weird liking to it.It is an Amazon gateway device - there is no arguing that. All it is really is just a mobile ad for getting you, the user to buy Amazon's services. I do not have Amazon Prime or any subscription from them. However, I have taken a liking to reading, ever since I can remember and this combined with "Kindle Unlimited" has allowed me to return to that passion, without having to buy volumes of books with small living spaces to store many books.But, being an Android user, I managed to find a way to load Google Play Store on it and put a couple of my favorite apps on it. This is great for an alternative Netflix, YouTube, Amazon Prime video content device. Personally, I use it for reading. It's easier to keep 12 books in this little device than to lug around a suitcase full of different books. Would recommend it. Games? I'm not a fan of gaming on touchscreen devices (my hands block more of the screen when trying to control whatever) so I haven't installed any games on it. Comic books and magazines are actually very nice. They might actually be the cause for me to upgrade to the HD version.

author: KK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2019
review_content: My main purpose in buying this was to have a convenient way to watch movies while flying, since a cell phone is too small and a laptop is too big. I also use it for casual browsing when I'm settled in on the couch, and for displaying recipes while in the kitchen.Just a few years ago, this tablet would have cost more by a factor of almost ten. I had a $400 iPad that, for my habits, had zero edge over the $30-$50 Fire.  It feels sturdy and well made. Nice in the hand with the textured coating on the back. Fun selection of colors. I don't need to use the Alexa feature because I mainly use this at home where I have Echoes in every room already.There is slight processor lag opening apps, but not enough to bother me since I use this for relaxing and not urgent matters or work. The battery life could also be better. Mine lost 25% sitting unused for a day, even though WiFi is supposedly turned off when idle according to my settings. When flying I definitely bring a portable battery pack to keep it lasting through using the screen constantly for a few hours. I also wish that you could modify the app main screen in a way more similar to a cell phone. My main screen feels too busy, displaying all my apps instead of just my most used ones. A minor OS update that adds a screen timeout selection shortcut to the pull down quick access settings would be appreciated, so that I can easily switch to a long timeout when using this for recipes or leave on a short timeout when just browsing around.Overall I am still blown away that I can get a fully functional and great feeling tablet for less than a tenth of the cost of major competitors.

author: Stan Jones

review_content: Amazon Fire 7 TabletI bought this because I wanted a tablet small enough to hold easily one hand in bed, on the couch while watching TV, and so forth. I have an 8-inch Samsung, and it’s just too danged big.So, the Amazon Fire 7. I got the 32GB model for $69.99.I kept it a couple of weeks and returned it, details below.Pros:1. Good build quality.2. Tight integration with the Amazoniverse for shopping, ebooks, video, music and all the rest.Cons:1. Very weak app store. Some of my favorites, like SmartNews, Gmail, and MyFitnessPal, weren’t available, and similar products just didn’t make the grade. It does have Words With Friends, but despite an hour or two of fiddling, I absolutely not get it to sign in and sync up with the Words With Friends games, opponents, etc, on my phone and other tablets. Maybe there’s a way, but it’s just too much trouble. WWF should be easy fun, not a configuration marathon.2. Poorly organized interface with too few configuration options. Rather than a home screen with your favorite apps and a separate interface with all apps organized alphabetically, you basically just get one long vertical scroll with all your apps on it. If you can’t find the one you want, you just have to use the search tool.3. *Too* tightly integrated with the Amazoniverse. At times, it behaves for more like an unabashed marketing platform than anything resembling a general-purpose tablet.I'm giving it 3 stars because the hardware was a 4 or 5, but the functionality was only a 1 or 2.Sorry, Jeff Bezos. Sticking with plain old Android from now on.

review_content: The price on the Fire 7 is definitely right, and I have a Kindle Paperwhite that I love, so I was hopeful. I needed a small tablet to use as a portable barcode scanner. author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2019
review_content: I tried an Amazon e-reader (paperwhite). Everyone said it's soo much better than a FIRE tablet. I wasn't impressed by a paperwhite.  Claims of a battery life that lasts WEEKS!!! Nope. That is if you set screen brightness to low (which I set at 10 out of 24). And WEEKS of battery life is if you only read 30 minutes a day MAXIMUM.  Yeah, I routinely read 1 or 2 books A WEEK. At the end of the day, my FIRE tablets (I own 4 of different sizes & generations), I routinely have approximately 49% battery life... at the end of the day. Sometimes it gets down to 35% and I'm still reading - but I can plug it in easily and keep reading. The paperwhite has the micro usb port on the bottom of the unit - making it difficult to charge & read at rhe same time... plus you get to damage your cables by bending them when you get tired and try to prop the thing on a table or pillow.My favorite thing about my Fire tablet... I can download Libby or Overdrive from the app store and then check out books from my library for FREE. There I can download books in Kindle format, PDF, EPUB & MP3 Audiobooks... and through the library app they all function seamlessly.  You cannot get all those formats on a regular Amazon e-reader without doing several extra steps.You can also download apps, games, music, access the internet via wifi... and expand the downloadable memory with a micro sd card.  I can't recommend a Fire tablet enough. This particular purchase was for a friend who has never had a tablet before. I let him borrow one of mine & when the price dropped to $29.99 he pounced on it.

review_content: This Fire 7 is replacing my reading device of many years. It is an original Fire that I bought when they first came out. It has subjected me to more frustration than any high-tech device in a long time. But the good news is that I have limited sight, my Kindles ability to change font size and screen brightness are a godsend.Here are some problems.1. There are two notations for changing font size. One is in CONTROLS, a horizontal orange line with a white dot that can be used to adjust the size. The other is a double box, accessed through the book readerm with + and - in it. An adjacent orange line controls brightness.On the latter screen, I mistakenly touched the left end of the brightness  control orange line, and the screen went black. A black touch screen is a big problem. Ultimately I went into a walk-in closet, and after I became dark-adapted, could make out just enough to raise the screen brightness to a useable level. I consider this a design defect - a user should never be without a way to find the needed touch-sensitive area.2. A Kindle may have a number different capabilities, but the designers should never, in their search for incremental elegance, loose sight of the fact that its prime function is TO BE A BOOK READER. I recently wanted to retrieve a book from my library, and after considerable swiping, tapping, poking, and prodding found the book, and downloaded it. I then worked some more to get the book in the local library, with the full-screen icon displayed. I never did get the book to open, until I shut the Kindle down and restarted it.4. I do a lot of highlighting and bookmarking,My old Fire is great for this, but the Fire 7 makes way too many unwanted page changes3. The devices too many modes, and too many different ways to move between them. To put it into engineering terms, this is a state machine with too many states, each state has access to too many other states, and the state transition triggers are inconsistent.I never play games, watch movies, or listen to music, It is OK to have them available, but they shouldn't get in the way of reading books with a barrage of spam-like suggestions. And I really dislike having to swipe up eat gaudy opening scvreen.This is a fine tool - once you figure how to navigate this overly-complex interface. After a number of hours use I am starting to get it. But I still find myself going back to my old Fire when I am in a hurry.
title: Great Product, User Interface Complex and confusing  at first
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Bruce_in_LA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: I replaced a three or four year old Fire 6" with this Fire 7".  The 7" is incrementally larger (circa 1/2" taller) but a tad lighter at 10.5 oz.  Because it is more streamlined and thinner it "feels" an ounce or two lighter, although it isn't.  The new Fire 7" is definitely faster and has a better touch screen.  I am sure I will be using it more than I used the 6".This is an inexpensive item so any criticisms need to be viewed in that light - whatever the criticism, it's good for the price and 10-20% the price of a mini iPad.SOFTWARE. "WALLED GARDEN."  I was trying to replicate the software apps I used on my iPhone, with a number of problems.  While Evernote, Dropbox, Washington Post and WSJ were available, and of course Netflix and HBO, other apps I use were not.  The Amazon App store is limited.  See next section.SIDE LOAD APPS.  "SIDE LOAD IN BRIEF."  There is a procedure I had forgotten that you can fairly easily side load some Android apps that are not inside the Amazon Fire App store.  For me, these are all functional apps (not games).  You go to Settings/Security, and say YES to Apps from Unknown Sources.  Then you go to a p k mirror dot com (lots of online articles point to this).  You search for the app you want, download it, and answer a few fine print Fire questions like "Download?"  "Open?"  "Install?"  Then the app shows up like a native app on the Fire home screen.  There is also some way to install Google Play Store on a Fire, which I haven't done.  Apps like  New York Times, Flipboard, and Feedly that I use literally all the time, had to be side loaded this way.  Other apps like Trello generated error messages on Kindle.  Feedly installed but would NOT accept my logon via Google account, the only way I can get into it.  Net net, there are some applications like this I couldn't replicate on Fire as on my iPhone.  Also I use ONENOTE on ipad and iphone but not Fire.  I had to use a different podcast app on Fire than on my iPhone (podcast addict).  Remember that for some things with no Fire app you can resort to the browser and a bookmark (e.g. Trello).  (In addition to the method cited here, there is some way to install the actual Google Play Store, see online articles and training videos).MEMORY CARD.  It REJECTED a micro SDHC card I'd been using in my Windows laptop.  I got a new micro SDHC card and it recognized it out of the box, but asked me with a popup dialog if I wanted to (A) specially format it for Fire use only, or (B) use it as a transfer card.  This new card generated an error warning in my Windows 10 laptop, but it worked OK anyway.  I transferred ten H264 movies and Fire read them fine.  I accessed them with a free Fire app store app, File Commander.  I understand you can also access memory card movies via (A) Video > Options > Personal Videos (sometimes I can't find this path) or (B) via an app called My Videos.  File Commander is easiest.SCREEN.  "DECENT."  it's good, but for the two digit price don't expect a retina screen like on some $500 tablet.  It's fine for me for video, some fine print apps like Washington Post text looked distinctly grainy though.  It makes a good eReader; weighing 10.5 oz versus my Paperwhite 7 oz.INITIATING.  "FROZE!!"  A "D" for the out of box experience.  After several initiation steps, finding wifi, and downloaded an update, my Fire froze in "JUST A SEC" mode for over an hour.  This is common (see Google); you have to hold down the power button for 30 sec for a reboot.  On rebooting, I got the JUST A SEC screen a few times, but only for a few seconds.SUMMARY.  Some bugs due to the limited app library, but a good tablet for the price and it's gotten much better compared to 3 years ago.
title: It's Good, but be aware of some limitations
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Without AdsColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: beezageeza
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
review_content: I'm updating this review and deducting one more star.  Amazon tried to contact me by email, voicemail and phone because they wanted to resolve this issue.  That's a good thing, right?No.  I have needed to explain the same problem each time to a different person and the last person told me that it is not possible to change Alexa accent to something different but still have Alexa do the things it should.  I already knew that, so why call me to tell me that the Alexa programming is faulty when I already know that.  Amazon says my "feedback is helping us build Earth's Most Customer-Centric Company".  I don't think it is.To make it worse, one of my gripes was how the Fire Tablet does not recognize Hawaii as being part of the USA.  They called me at 10 am California time without realizing that in Hawaii, that is around dawn.  Not considerate and it kinda proves my point.  They did not read my review and made the same systematic mistake.If you live in the USA and you want Alexa to speak a different language, it is not possible.  The program will speak in a different language but then most skills and apps stop working.  Lucky for me, I just wanted to hear Alexa with an Aussie accent.  Imagine if I lived in the USA but only spoke Spanish or German?  Then, Alexa would be completely useless, even though the capability is there.  Very lazy programming by Amazon developers.original review below:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~I went on a little buying spree on Prime day, figuring it was a good time to start building a home automation system.  After some thought, I went with Alexa over Google.  Don't know why, but now I know more, that might have been a mistake.With Google products, one tends to expect hardware and apps that have had a bit more thought built-in than competing products.  So it is a real shame that I discover Amazon products are not designed the same way.  I would think that for Amazon, the idea was to hook people in with a great home automation assistant and to make sure it was at least as good as the closest rival. Then trap them into a cosy buying feedback loop.  Not so - Amazon have settled into the benthos of mediocracy.  Some aspects are really good but it has so many basic flaws.  The problems seem to come from the tablet but mostly it is Alexa.  For example, If I were British and living in the USA, I might I might prefer Alexa with a British accent, and I do.  Americans might also like to try a different accent  BUT YOU CAN"T.  Alexa is able to speak with a British accent, but only if I go and live there.  If I change the accent, my permissions, apps, and what I can access will change.  I will not, for example, be able to do any banking and about half the apps I have do not function as they should.  Why?  I imagine it is a shortcut in the code - linking the accent as well as the source country with app permissions set by location.  If thats the case, why is it not carried through to ALL apps and features?  Amazon store still defaults to the USA as does search engines and everything else...  Just very poor product development and lazy people not checking things.  Thank goodness they don't build aircraft.While on the whole location thing.  The tablet does not automatically set the date time and time zone.  Why?  Someone forgot that Hawaii is a US state.  The bottom right hand star on our flag is us; and the star is as large as all the others.  The "system" defaults to California (3,000 miles away).  I had to manually scroll through to choose location (Hawaii is located in the Pacific so again the app. permissions are probably different.  Then you need to scroll through the 48 different world time zones to find Hawaii.  What a stupid design.  Anyway, if someone wants a couple of Alexa tablets and 2 echo shows, you will find them in the trash outside my house.
title: Alexa?  get your act together!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Victor Le
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2019
review_content: This running Fire OS (Androidish) does pretty well with day-to-day tasks... without any of the Android UI features or apps. For $30, during Prime Day for me (or during Black Friday or Christmas), this is a really good tablet for that price.For the tech-savvy, I would not recommend this. 1 GB of RAM is still not enough for any current day device (maybe besides Vanilla Linux), let alone Android. The 16 GB ROM is a welcomed addition (though only 10 GB is usable to the end-user). This tablet is definitely not for gaming. Minecraft is barely passable, running on the Automatic Low-Memory-Graphics setting. HOWEVER, the UI (Fire OS) is not as choppy as I thought it would with the internals. Some things do take some time to load, but overall performance is good enough. Nonetheless, I personally do not like the Fire OS skin.Also, the 800p/720p screen is good for general use. And the Dual Band WiFi is much appreciated. This, in my experience, is best used as a media device, which I think is what Amazon intends for this device. Otherwise, I'd pick something else with a better screen, internals, and UI.If you are tech-savvy, you can definitely port over Google Play Service and the Play Store for better usability. It's a pretty easy one-time process and you can download a legit copy of YouTube and regain some extra usability after that.Suggestions:Amazon could literally increase the budget for these tablets by porting over VANILLA Android, which is open-source and would be more beneficial to the user and Amazon as it decreases development costs. Fire OS (still Android) has very limited capabilities because of the UI skin. The addition of Vanilla Android can not only offer more capabilities, but it can also increase price margins for better internals and better performance, leading to better user experience. However, knowing Amazon, this is going to be a stretch. I can get the purpose of Fire OS. It's simple and intuitive, but it is very limiting for my taste. I cannot justify buying Amazon's bigger and better tablets.Overall, this is a good tablet for the price. However, Amazon could make this SOOO much better and more capable. I can definitely recommend this to a certain group of people, like kids or people who would like to use it as a secondary device. Otherwise, other people should carefully consider this tablet and their options. For me, it met my needs as a secondary device, but it's definitely not going to meet my needs for college, for example. This tablet is not for everyone.Sidenote: I love the Twilight Blue Color for this tablet. This definitely added some flare to my stash of black stuff XD
title: Good secondary device. Bang for the buck.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Granny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: The first thing: it won't open right up on the app page, "OH NO" you have to see Amazon ads first, and get them off by swiping the little camera, this becomes more annoying when the screen goes black every few seconds, causing me to go through the whole process again. I have tried to lengthen the battery saver time without success. Second, trying to access and load apps that are not in the Amazon appstore is a nightmare.  Loading the app for my Blink security camera was a breeze and it works better than it did with my old Ipad but I have 2 pet cameras I got at Walmart, that the app is not in Amazon's appstore, and I can not get the Google appstore to load on to this tablet,  I guess old Jeff considers Google a competitor, but by jumping through a bunch of hoops I was able to find the app but I can't get it to load onto my Fire.  This is just one example of their forcing out the competition. I was unhappy with my Ipad for their monopolizing tricks, but Amazon is just as monopolizing. I guess I got what I paid for though. But, when my old Ipad quit charging and I knew it would cost as much as a new tablet to replace the battery, I started shopping for a new tablet, and I sure did not want another Apple. This Fire was the best deal, I could get it with my Prime, they were willing to give me a trade on my old Ipad and the Fire had all the features I wanted, and I am on a fixed income, with social security, so I shop price. But, now I wonder if I got the bargain I was hoping for.

review_content: I purchased this tablet in order to be able to read books. On my other kindles I will go along and watch movies, read email, do other websites, and so forth.The 1 problem that I see is that amazon is cutting out Other browsers, other apps And Google Items that are easily available on Samsung or other android tablet.This is very frustrating to me.I find more Information and items on google then I do on amazon. author: iconoclast
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2019
review_content: If you don't mind cutting lots of corners, then this is a perfect device for you.Let's start with the software.The first corner it cuts is that it's an Android device.  If you've used iOS or iPadOS, you will immediately see that Android is much worse.  But if you're okay with that, great.The next is that it's not even set up as a general-purpose Android device.  You can install apps from the play store, but it's a big hassle, and most of the documentation on how to do it online is WAY out of date.  So be prepared to waste a lot of time, if that's your goal.  (Actually, if your Google search includes the version of Android this is running, maybe it won't waste too much time.)  If all you want to do is use it as a Kindle, it'll be easy to use, and you'll be all set.Lastly in software, you're going to have to put up with ads on your screen unless you want to pay extra to remove them.  If you're okay with this, excellent, as it won't be a detraction for you.Now let's look at the hardware.Next is the screen.  If you've used Retina displays on Apple devices, you will not be impressed, but if your expectations are low, it'll be just fine.  Maybe even great.  And if you've used black & white Kindles, you also won't be impressed.  This adds color, of course, but for many books that is not any advantage.Lastly the battery: it sucks.  This is my second one of these devices, actually, because my family members used the first one and didn't bother keeping it recharged, and the battery lost its ability to hold a charge.  With my new one, I'm using it for myself and making sure it gets charged regularly, but when I unplug it I notice that the battery goes down quickly.  It really has the worst battery life of any device I can think of that I've ever used.If you're okay with all these downsides, buy it!  I got it REALLY cheap on Prime Day.  It was so cheap it was almost free!  (But of course the time that it sucked up made it much more expensive, indirectly, so note the warning above about the time it could take to make it into a general-purpose Android device.)  If you really want a quality tablet OR a quality book reader, and are willing to pay more, then go elsewhere.  This is not great as either.  You get what you pay for, but for this price I don't think you can do better.
title: An amazing deal, but not an amazing device.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

review_content: Got this during an Amazon deal for less than half list price. Of all the online instructions to add this feature, I found the Android Police website to be most useful as it gives you the version numbers of each of the 4 components you'll need to download and install. I found that I had to reboot after installing the APKs (as instructed), and then partway through setup, I had to reboot again as it wasn't accepting my Google login (but did after the reboot).

review_content: Since amazon keeps bugging me to review this, you shall get your honest review!- The battery can barely hold a charge. Fully charged on Friday afternoon. author: anonymous23
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: I bought this Fire to update my old 6" (4th Gen.) that I purchased 3 years ago.  After having this new Fire 7 (9th Gen.) for a week now and have been using it every day for long periods of time, I've made a few comparisons between them.Let me compare the specs.  I will refer to my old Fire HD 6 (4th Gen) as my Old 6", and my Fire 7 (9th Gen.) (this product) as the New 7".Screen size:Of course, the Old 6" one has a smaller screen at 6", and the New 7" is 7".Winner:  Even though the New 7" has a larger screen size, I'm actually on the fence about this one because are some advantages to having a smaller tablet to carry around.Resolution:Old 6" is in HD with 1280x800, 252 ppi.New 7" is SD at 1024x800 with 171 ppiWinner:  Old 6"Processor:Old 6" has Quad-Core 2@1.5 GHz + 1.2 GHzNew 7" has Quad-Core 1.3 GHzWinner:  New 7", although I honestly don't know anything about those numbers, but I do know that the new one is faster than my old one.Camera:Old 6" has VGA front facing, 2 MP rear facing cameras, and video 1080p@30fpsNew 7" has 2 MP front facing and 2 MP rear facing camera, and HD video recording at 720pWinner:  New 7"Battery Life:Old 6" has up to 8 hoursNew 7" has up to 7 hoursWinner:  Old 6"WiFi:Old 6" is 802.11 b/g/nNew 7" is Dual BandWinner:  New 7"So looking it over, it looks like the new 7" is the winner between them, but I am debating over whether to keep it.  I prefer a longer battery life and HD resolution which the old 6" has.  Sure, there are many benefits to the new 7" over the old one, but not every benefit carries the same weight to me.  Everyone has their own preferences.  However, I got the new 7" at a good price and I can pay in installments, so I guess I'll keep it.  But I will still use the old 6" periodically, like when I want to carry it in my purse.  (The smaller size is actually an advantage over the new one in this instance.  Another advantage is that I can use it for longer periods of time and will appreciate that extra battery life.)The one thing I'd like to stress is that there are features that they used to put on the smaller, less expensive models that now you have to upgrade to an 8" to get them (such as HD and longer battery life).  I own an 8" (7th Gen.) that I bought a couple of years ago, and although it does have those features, it's very buggy and you have to reboot several times a day.  They're not making them as well as they used to, for some reason.My main point is that if you have an older working model, you may want to consider holding onto it, and you'll have to decide for yourself which benefits outweigh each other.
title: Better than my old 6" one (on paper)
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Spencer Yeamans
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2019
review_content: I use both the HD 8 and now this device (all new Fire 7) for travel and for situations where I cannot take a full size laptop.  These devices respond well to a USB mouse (with adapter) and bluetooth keyboards.  I've been extremely happy with sitting in a coffee shop, with a small table, and having a compact setup for checking and responding to emails and other tasks.  The 7 has a screen that is a bit too small for anything productive, but is excellent for surfing the web, watching YouTube, reading Kindle, and the like.  Both the 8 and 7 are EXTREMELY durable, meaning that I don't have to carry them around in an extra sleeve, and they are more less, like a big phone that I can put on my kitchen table and leave it, without having to close it up or worry about it getting damaged.  This is great for quickly accessing information.  As a person who does not want to spend a lot of money on android tablets, I believe both the HD 8 and the New 7 are WONDERFUL products for the money.  The 7 is SLIGHTLY slower than the 8, but the difference is nominal.  Also, I would encourage new users to check for updates frequently when first getting the device and setting it up, because after about 12 updates the speed and performance improved rapidly...Fire OS does not have a reminder system similar to Windows that lets you know an update is pending.  I am very pleased with both my HD 8 and this New 7 for travel and for light productivity work in situations where taking a laptop or chromebook is not a good idea, especially when on vacation and working outside (like at the beach).  The screen is bright enough that I could use both at the beach, while under a pavilion, and get work done (for those of us who need to be tethered to work when even on vacation!).  All in all, Amazon Tablets are excellent values.  They are not gaming laptops, and they are not for graphic design, but they are for rough-and-tumble performance and I use them every day!
title: Amazon Tablets, especially New 7, are Excellent, Durable, Multi-functional, and Awesome for Trips
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: MikeFrett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
review_content: For a long time I avoided anything mobile. I could take a desktop computer apart and put it back together blindfolded, I've done it, but these mobile devices were beyond me. I see this for 40 something dollars and well, why not? I don't have WiFi so I bought the "GL.iNET GL-MT300N-V2 Wireless Mini Portable Travel Router" to plug into my wired modem, works great.I fire the thing up and it runs me though some kind of initiation demo, which I appreciated. Since I was so use to the non-mobile side of technology, I thought this would take some getting use to but I was wrong. I was deep in the jungle, building cities and matching up pieces of candy in no time. Alexa kept me company, thanks Alexa.I don't get the hate on the 'net, I haven't had a single issue with this item. Everything runs smooth and the available games play just fine. Must be a troll thing...If I had any complaint, it would be the heat emitted on the backside and the battery life going from 100% down to 50% in such a short time, or at least what seems like a short time. I understand all of you now, I understand why you stumble about the city streets bumping into walls and tripping over sidewalks. It really is kind of addictive. I can't do without my desktop the same way you can't do without your mobile device.
title: I understand now

review_content: I own each size and latest model of the Fire Tablets. I have to say that the 7 and the HD 8-models are just way too slow compared to the HD 10. These are honestly not worth the money until they upgrade these devices with AT LEAST the processor and RAM that the HD 10 has. They definitely need to do some updating/upgrading on internal parts. However, for $29 as an Amazon Prime Member, you get what you pay for. I don't recommend the 7 or HD 8 until some upgrades happen. With this being said, I am hoping for some huge changes on the next model(s)!

author: Beachgirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: This is my second Fire 7. My first lasted exactly 5 years, and since I used it every single day, it really owed me nothing. But wait, it DID give me 5.00 and 20% off the new one on the trade in program. The Fire has a very clear screen, streams beautifully, and this newer 9th gen one has hands free Alexa. I do not understand people who go on a rant about how its a piece of junk,  that it only lasted 5,6 7 years. Come on people! What do you expect from a $50.00 device that is called into service daily and has lots of fun apps and capabilities? I read a lot, and this is my go to for reading anything, be it the most recent novel or historical works or periodicals. It's a no brainer.
title: Great tablet, great value
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: PD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
review_content: Of course it's not the best tablet on the planet but at 50 bucks, expectations shouldn't be at iPad level. My main tablet is a 2018 iPad pro 12.9" which I use all the time for artwork, music production and a ton of notes with the Apple No.2 Pencil. Thing is, I needed to be able to read and research my books in Kindle and/or watch a training video on YT while using the iPad, plus I often want to read or watch tutorials on YT at night and that huge iPad gets too bulky to hold when trying to relax on the couch. All I wanted was a simple lightweight Kindle reader in color and something to watch YT vids on. Voila, the Fire 7 is perfect for that. I'm obviously no android-based fan, I'm a Sheeple fanatic, but this Fire 7 is a perfect compliment. Plus Amazon is huge part of my life's ecosystem, and the Fire is totally integrated that way. For 50 bucks?? What a solution! I see review griping about all these non Amazon features that won't work, like Google Play...really? There's a solution for that, it's called Samsung. The Fire is designed to extend Amazon's world and for the price, it's quite fine. Look, my snobby expensive iPad Pro is phenomenally fast and a screen to die for and for artwork it's truly a replacement when using apps like ProCreate and blah blah blah, so I'm VERY used to a best in class device. But for FIFTY BUCKS how on earth can you gripe about an Amazon-linked device that gives you multimedia in your hands? It wouldn't be my only device but just a s library in my pocket, it's worth its weight in gold. One reviewer said the Fire was taken over by someone who was controlling the device before their eyes. This was after her 8 year old daughter was using it... sounds more like an issue with the wizard, not the wand, lol.50 bucks... no brainer.
title: C'mon, it's a fifty dollar tablet
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Without AdsColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Eric Peterson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2020
review_content: As long as you know what you're getting, and the specs are very clear, this is a great small tablet for the price.  Need a small screen for Netflix, Amazon Video, VLC or something similar?  It's great for that, as long as you know what you're getting.The built in speaker is not great, and there's no stereo sound, just a single speaker.  If you plug speakers or headphones in with a 3.5mm headphone jack, you're in good shape.  However, my experience with bluetooth, which is what I was hoping to use to handle audio most of the time, was that there's a noticeable audio lag when using bluetooth.  It didn't matter what speaker or headphone I was using, and whether I was using VLC or Netflix...that audio lag was there, and it was annoying.As long as you know this tablet is not HD resolution, not super beefy hardware, not stereo speakers, etc...you're in good shape.  I would have gladly kept this tablet if not for the bluetooth audio lag.  Unfortunately, that was the one limitation this tablet has that wasn't clearly laid out in the product specs.This is a fantastic small device for anyone who wants to hand something to a child or bring a low cost device with them on a trip, just know about the product's limitations and make sure it fits your needs.
title: Great for what it is, at the price, with caveats
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Fernando Melendez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2019
review_content: As with many purchases, this all depends on what YOU want to get out of it. This 7" Fire with 16GB is the smallest and most stripped down, bare bones, version that I could find. All I wanted was a souped up Kindle e-Reader. I don't particularly like the Paperwhite for it's screen. I'm in the minority, I'm sure. But this Fire tablet was heavily discounted for Prime Day at $30. But I will be using it strictly for reading eBooks. I never liked the FireOS, there are not really any real apps for developed for the FireOS anyway. I have my phone/laptop/PC for anything really robust.The stated purpose: Reading Kindle books. And it delivers. Better screen quality, more features for the Kindle eReader app, the works. 100% what I was looking for.Only downside: Ads on the lock screen, ads on the homescreen, everything directing me to BUY on AMZN. Which, if you can ignore them, you have a great, portable, easy on the eyes e-Reader with a seemingly endless choice of titles to choose from on said site. For the discounted price - could not find better.That's why I knocked off a star. I paid for the device outright. I pay for books that can only be found and downloaded from your site. WHY the ADS?? I can't use this device outside of your ecosystem, why "force" me to it from it?
title: Best Basics for the price

author: L. Anderson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: Very good product, works well, is pretty fast and the speaker is very nice. author: lh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: This is my third Fire as I have broken the screens on the previous two. Both of those (seventh generation) served me well but at 50 bucks I simply replaced them as needed. They both still work...albeit with scotch tape on the screens.This recent purchase (ninth generation) has been very annoying. Basically all I require is a tool for reading books, e mail, researching and shopping on line, an app for tuning guitar and easy access to my printer.Pros:1. Speaker sound quality seems better.2. Inexpensive in money...but not in time and annoyance.Cons:1. The screen is not as sensitive as the previous two. Annoying.2. The included e mail app works, then doesn't work, then works again, then doesn't work, then works again. I have had to dig out my last Fire to I insure an uninterrupted flow of e mail. Resolution efforts for same have been VERY annoying.  Still do not know why this has been happening.3. Cannot use my favorite free app for tuning guitar - Guitar Tuna. Downloads...then locks the tablet up when you try to use it. Switched to a different app.4. Cannot use the included app for my HP Printer, nor the free HP Print App that worked well with my previous Fires. FINALLY found an app that does work....very, VERY annoying.5. The constant ads and other intrusions on my home screen and in Web search efforts seem much worse than previous Fire generations. These clutter up my screens and noticeably slow down research efforts. They sell me absolutely NOTHING!This will be my last Fire.
title: This Fire generation is annoying!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Brian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
review_content: I have had a need for a small tablet, but didn't want to break the bank in getting one. Apple tablets are just way overpriced and expensive, and regular Android tablets are starting to become harder to find. So, when the Fire 7 went on sale for the holidays for just $29 I said why not? It is a very simple device so do not expect premium performance. There is a very noticeable lag when starting apps and pulling up menus. The OS, which is Android based, is fairly intuitive. The app selection from the store is lacking, but I was surprised at some of the apps that were available.  Even though the OS is Android based, you can only use apps specifically for Fire tablets instead of the whole gamut of Google apps for Android. But I was able to find nearly all the apps, or at least versions of them, for what I wanted on my tablet to control my smart home devices, keep track of news, email and social media, play music through bluetooth, and a few other oddball apps I like to use. This device is also my introduction to Alexa. I have been weighing either integrating my house with Google or Alexa. My mind is still not made up on which direction I want to take on that, but I figure the Fire 7 was worth it with all the integration features of Alexa in a tablet which I also had a need for. Given its price range, especially with periodic sales, it is definitely worth checking out.
title: Good Enough For My Tablet and Smart Home Device Needs

author: Christopher Stapleton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2019
review_content: ***  This review is for the older version***I ordered this tablet June of 2018 and have used it for over a year.  I ordered it as a cheap backup to my work tablet and because I love the 7 inch size.  The Fire 7 has been a mixed bag, but with some adjustments, I would order one again.The first thing I will say is I ordered the no-ad version.  Not worth it at all.  However, order the most memory you can possibly afford!  The 8 gigs on this device is barely adequate and I had to factory reset it last month because it had become almost unusable.Secondly, forget apps.  They won't work.  Trust me.  Games kinda work, but some features will not.  News apps do not work at all.On the other hand, it runs Amazon apps and media well.  No problem with video or books.  Also the Silk browser works very well and I do a lot of net surfing on this tablet.The reset bought me several more months but I will probably replace it around Christmas.  I love 7 inch and feel the 8 inch is still a little big.  However, I may upgrade to the 8 just to see if the experience is any better.  Either way, I am buying the larges internal memory they offer.Like I said a mixed bag.  For browsing, reading, and video watching, this tablet is excellent for the money.  For apps, games or anything large, forget it.  Too few things work with the 32G SD card as well.****I will probably buy the newer version later this year, if I do I WILL GET THE LARGEST MEMORY AVAILABLE!!!***

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: Bought it mainly for travel so I don't have to lug my laptop with me and also save precious carry on space. Once I got Google Play downloaded it was more functional for my needs. I'm not a Prime member and will only utilize the Kindle book portion out of all the Amazon apps. The low $29 price made it a good buy. And I agree with others that battery life isn't the best. But for the price I guess you can't complain. Just keep the charger near.EDIT: 12/10/19---I'm very disappointed after browsing the Kindle books available on Amazon. Yes many of them are cheap and even free, but they're from writers who would never have been published by real publishers. I also find that the books i'm interested in are so expensive to purchase for Kindle.Why would I pay over $10 for the Kindle version of a book when I can just get the actual book used and in good condition for $3.00?! It's disappointing that after purchasing this tablet and anticipating using the Kindle part of it, that i've already bought 3 books off e bay for 3 bucks each where they were going for over 10 dollars here at Amazon for Kindle.When Amazon brings their prices down for Kindle book purchases, i'll start using it. author: David Stevenson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2019
review_content: My first Fire tablet turned 4 years old this year.  Since I was used to it, I didn’t think I really needed a new one.  Plus, I was dubious as to whether my apps, settings, pictures, movies, etc. would be restored to the new Fire.  I was offered a trade in, plus $20 credit, so, $30 for my old one.  So I took it.  I must say, I was surprised. The new Fire has a better sounding speaker, better screen, and battery.  It is also faster.  I never realized how much the old Fire lagged.  The onboard typing board is better also.  Downloading my apps and settings, books, movies, etc was seamless.  I just had to reformat my micro card.  Not a problem.  I am very pleased in the quality and experience.

author: Sarah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019
review_content: I got this on sale on Prime Day for $29. The screen resolution and battery life aren't amazing, but seriously an amazing deal for the cost. Literally I just got it to watch movies on while I do other things; having this as an extra screen allows me to still use my phone or laptop while casually playing a show in the background. I don't have a TV, so this is perfect for that purpose for me.Overall, if you're tablet shopping and want something powerful, this is NOT the tablet for you. But if you're on the fence about splurging on a tablet at all, this is the best deal you can find, especially if you can wait for a sale.Random things:- I bought a case but don't feel like it's necessary. I used it without any case for a few weeks and it never felt too fragile. I only recommend a case of you are particularly uncareful (or have kids) or if you're like me and just wanted one with a stand so the tablet can prop itself up easily anywhere.- The lock screen has ads on it, which bother me a surprising amount. author: William L. Schart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2020
review_content: I have been using iPads for a number of years, but I had been considering getting one of these. I have a job where sometimes I sit for hours at one place controlling access and will read to kill time. My iPad was kind of big and my iPod a bit small, so I like the size of this. It will fit handily in bags as well as in my hand when using, and it is easier reading on this than my iPod. And it’s more versatile than a hard copy book. Some places I have WiFi access, so can go online too.That being said, there are some things that my Apple stuff is better for. There is no version of Garmin connect for this, and I used a Garmin for cycling. May not be an issue for you. I haven’t been able to get the Kindle set up to get my Mac.com email. Not sure if that’s because I’m not doing it right or if the Kindle email app isn’t compatible with Mac.com. The sound quality of the built in speaker isn’t great. And the smaller size can be a problem, especially for someone who doesn’t have the best of vision.All in all, I don’t see this as a replacement for my iPad but as an addition to it. There are some situations where this will be better, some where the iPad is better. And it’s handy to have an alternative available when I have to plug in my iPad for recharging.

author: glenesis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2020
review_content: Pros: It's inexpensive and feels solid. The camera app is barren but it has a few zoom levels. The photo quality is not bad, probably the least awful camera in any 7 inch tablet I've used, and I've owned quite a few of them. Internet speed is ok. Ads are huge, and plentiful, but not really very intrusive, and of course you can always pay Amazon a modest ransom to remove the ads..Cons/warnings: This device is not fast. Lag ranges from barely laggy to *OMG What am I waiting for now?!?* Scrolling is jerky and sucks. Apps that run great on my antique Android devices crawl on my 2019 Kindle Fire 7. This device is never, ever anything resembling quick nor speedy in any way ever. The screen is pretty blue. There's no way to make the screen not blue nor even less blue. I suggest the devs please include the Ambient Display setting from stock Android which would let us add one please, user-selectable amounts of red to the screen. The image on the screen is good, and brightness is good, so it's a shame it doesn't support the ambient Display setting. In fact I'd love this thing to have the full complement of settings from Stock Android, maybe under an Advanced menu item in the System Preferences..Please, Amazon? And please, strip out enough crap to let this pretty little toy speed up a little bit, okay? Thanks!

author: Monique J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: UPDATE: It's been about 6 months now. I use this tablet daily.  Yes, every single day.First the good. I still love this little tablet.  I do NOT use it for anything other than entertainment,  email etc. I have an ipad and laptop for work, school etc.  For the most part I don't leave the house too often without it. I've had a couple of issues that arent a big deal for me but may be for you.Battery life. It could definitely be better. I've used the tablet for several hours straight only a couple of times but I did need to charge it in the car while I was out.If your wifi is at all sketchy, expect lag. On a strong signal there hasn't been any problem. At least with my unit.Reading, I read a lot. No, seriously 2 or 3 books a week. Not those little 400 page ones either. I carry my old faithful kindle touch to read during the day. I began having trouble with eyestrain reading on the tablet. So while you can absolutely read on this tablet, which I do at night, just be aware.Games, Amazon needs to SERIOUSLY step up their game in this department.  I've been mildly irritated a couple of times after porting games by the lack of support from dev's. for the Amazon platform. Did I cave and install google play. Yes I did. YouTube is your friend. However, there have been a couple of issues even with that and game crashes have been an issue. So, I stopped playing them. Too much hassle.In summary,  for what I use it for, this tablet has been great and I will continue to use it as long as it lasts. The size and weight are fantastic.  Keeping my review at 5 stars because the issues that have come up weren't a deal breaker for me. I'm definitely getting my money's worth.This little tablet was a great investment for me. I can carry this with my phone for short jaunts out around town and be able to do almost everything  I need to do on a device. It has NOT of course replaced my laptop, nor has it replaced my larger iPad. Those are for work. This is for entertainment.I read a lot. I still have my 4gen touch kindle that I will use until it dies, and for long reading sessions at home that's what I use. For shorter reading or perusing magazines or comics I use this. In the event that I'm waiting for a notification and decide to read or check email, this is a handy thing to have in my bag.Let's talk about my bag, it is now LIGHTER. Ladies did you read that? With this I can carry something smaller than a diaper bag. (Gasp) or a briefcase, whichever.I've watched a few shows on the tablet. I personally didn't have any issues. They looked good and I used headphones so I didn't worry about sound.Alexa of course is handy and the fire tablet synced right up with our echo dots. No problems there.I can go on and on. I really like it. I also bought one for my 17 year old boy and HE even loves his. Finally got that kid to start reading more. Yes, with a fire tablet.

review_content: I got this for my mom because her old Samsung Galaxy tablet didn't support the latest version of her bank app. She doesn't use cell phones, so this is very frustrating.I got one for myself because my old tablet was out of space and I wanted to play some newer puzzle type games. author: xoxoxo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020
review_content: My kids started using their fire tablets/playing games online more during quarantine & complained that their old fire tablets lagged or glitched. Logically, I figured “NEW fire tablets will fix the issues”, right? WRONG! Every game/app kicks the out, boots them, or resets within a minute of starting (sometimes even while still loading!)My initial response to the constant complaining was that it must’ve been user error. So to try and prove this, I traded use of my iphone or Chromebook for a couple of hours while I attempted to use the “laggy/glitchy tablets”.I didn’t last more than 15 minutes. EVERY game app would take forever to load only to drop off and reset within in seconds. Second thought was “It MUST be the WiFi signal isn’t strong enough”. This led to hundreds of dollars spent on WiFi extender plugs through the house, a WiFi hub to provide a more consistent signal, etc. and ... no improvement.Summary: if using fire tablet for BASIC functions (reading a book, asking Alexa questions, watch a tiny bit of you tube) it’s a great value, as long as you’re aware even basic functions may rest themselves in the middle of whatever you’re doing.However, for my family personally, it was a HUGE waste of time, money, and effort. I regret purchasing these. For the complaints, wasted time, wasted money, and huge headaches I should’ve just gotten my kids a Chromebook or laptop!
title: Only for BASIC things
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: katlina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2019
review_content: I bought this primarily to replace an old Ipad for two reasons: to read e-books from the library and to stream Spectrum TV shows. It is far less intuitive to check out books from my library than the iPad app--I'm not sure if this is a library by library thing or across the board, but I can eventually download them.Unfortunately, Spectrum TV streaming does NOT work, even though it says it is compatible. Super frustrating! I'm better off using my old iPad that freezes randomly since it at least works some of the time. Why would they list the claim that Spectrum works with this???Finally, the battery drains even when you aren't using it because of the built in ads. I leave it unplugged on my bed at 75% when I leave for work and when I get home 10 hours later (and no one is in the apartment that could even be using it), then the battery can end up at 25-50% that night. I am fine with ads periodically when I log in, but I don't know what it would use battery life when I'm not even looking at it. I find I have to charge it every night otherwise it dies when I need it.I would avoid buying this one and pay the higher price for a nicer tablet option.

review_content: It's ok. author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2020
review_content: I bought this tablet to replace my first generation kindle that I had for like 8 years. It performs as I would expect an e-reader to do, for the most part, and it was very inexpensive for the sale price - which was awesome.I bought the version ‘without special offers,’ and I was a bit surprised (though I guess i shouldn’t have been) that you have to pay extra to not have constant ads on the device. Even without the special offers, I don’t love all the promotional/ad-like content that bombards each screen - especially if connected to WiFi. I just want to see the books & apps I buy, and nothing else.The touchscreen is a little finicky at the top where you have to slide down to access the control panel. Also, it seems like the battery drains rather quickly for an e-reader. I can still read for several hours, so it’s not a huge problem, but I would expect the battery to last longer if I have the WiFi off and low power mode on. The backing also seems less sturdy than my 1st gen (that thing took a lot of falls and was pretty indestructible) but so many older tablets/phones were sturdier then their newer versions.Overall, I’m still satisfied with the purchase, bc I was just looking for a way to continue reading e-books, but some of the finer details leave a little to be desired.
