author: S. M. Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: I remember my very first Kindle Fire, the first one that came out. I still have and use it, though after a decade it is starting to get draggy and tired. Not only that, many of the apps, when we try to run them, now throws up a message to the effect that  "this app is no longer supported on this device"  so I decided to get a newer model, the Kindle 7. What a big disappointment! While the apps now work again on this upgraded model, the things I love about the original are gone, such as the carousel and the bookshelf. The opening screen is ALWAYS some sort of advertising! And the whole experience is a push of advertising all the time, interrupting the flow of whatever we are trying to do. Why pay my money to buy a device so that it can push advertising at me all the time? Seems like what I paid for was to get ads shoved at me rather than, as with the original, paying for a device to read books, look things up, install apps to use, educational experiences. Almost all the tech devices are now just glorified gadgets for pushing advertising, from Kindles to smart phones to whatever. Sad.  You all take our money so you can push ads to get us to spend more money.  If I could find a way in the settings to shut the ads down, I would. But, thus far it does not seem to exist.
title: Pay for advertising...???
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Todd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
review_content: Originally I bought one to replace a family members' 5th gen Kindle Fire 7, noticed how much better the touch screen accuracy was along with a snappier OS and decided to replace mine.  I'd agree with other reviewers the previous Fire 7 5th & 6th gen were slow to the point of just being better as an ebook/newspaper/magazine reader and Prime Videos/Netflix tablet. This generation base model specs are a huge improvement as its faster with more storage, however the battery life leaves a bit to desire as the up to 7 hrs seems to be based on reading an eBook with brightness lowered or listening to your Amazon music library using the SDXC slot storage.  If you're going to use it for streaming such as Amazon Prime Video, SlingTV, Netflix, etc the battery life will be closer to 4-5 hrs depending upon brightness and audio streaming such as Tune-In, Pandora or iHeart Radio should average 5.5 hrs with minimal brightness.As far as the complaints of battery life when not in use, if you turn off the wifi & bluetooth via airplane mode the battery shouldn't drop more than 1% per day idle.  With the ad-supported models there is always the possibility it grabs more ads each day while wifi is on. Also if I recall Amazon Prime Videos auto-downloads a free episode of their "promoted shows" unless you disable it and that is known to drain any Kindle Fire battery.Pros:-Faster CPU: Everything is faster from general UI swipe between screens and application launches.-Storage: More storage compared to the previous gen and faster when applications are downloaded then installed.-Screen quality is brighter and crisper for text compared to my 5th gen Fire 7.-Touch screen sensitivity is extremely great compared to past Fire 7 models if you go as far back as the first Kindle Fire, in the past the gap between the screen and digitizer would result in some weird multi-touch dead-zones near the edges of the screen.-SDXC slot can use faster U3 cards so if you run applications off the card it'll be almost as fast as using onboard tablet storage.-FireOS: Its equally fast like the 8th gen Kindle 8, however with 1GB of memory if you start multi-tasking it'll start to slow down a bit.-Alexa: While I never used it, the function is useful if you need hands-free usage while using it.-Amazon finally put the speaker on the edge of the tablet which improves sound when standing up in a case and you don't need to crank up the volume compared to the 5th gen rear speaker.Cons:-Volume button placement makes it easy to accidentally lower the volume while holding it, the recessed buttons make it less common than the 5th/6th gen Fire 7.From owning a 7th and 8th gen Kindle Fire 8 the memory difference matters if you multitask applications or play a few demanding games.  In my opinion the Kindle Fire 8 is a far better value as you gain stereo speakers for moments you don't want to wear headphones and the battery run time with media playback is much better.  If anyone has pets, this Kindle 7 is durable enough for allowing a cat to play games on it or watch Netflix so you shouldn't need to spend extra for a Kids edition for a pet entertainment device.
title: Entry Fire tablet worth recommending
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2020
review_content: I have owned many kindles in the past. The last one I purchased was an older 10-inch model. Over the last several years I have started to appreciate the size of smaller devices as they are easier to use for me. I chose this model for several reasons. I was looking for something that I could bring to and from work that would allow me to read while on breaks, I wanted something that was small and easy to pack away when I was done. I would usually read on my phone and that was a strain on my eyes. This is larger than my phone but small enough for me to still like. This kindle also has a built-in Alexa that has the same abilities as the echo. I also enjoy the customization of the reading experience. You can change font, color, and brightness to aid or enhance your experiences. However, this tablet is far from perfect. The battery is good it does last me a day or two depending on usage. The charging port is outdated, I would much rather have the USB-c port that is available on other models. The screen resolution is less than perfect as well but in this instance, it is an example that you get what you pay for.  My final complaint is the speaker, there is only one and it is in a place that you can and will sometimes cover it by accident. I wish there was more than one. Overall, you get what you pay for. This is a great tablet. It has its shortcomings but for the price, it is hard to deny that this is a great tablet it has everything that I wanted and needed.
title: Great but not perfect
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Andrew O
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: I guess I shouldn't be too surprised that this device is so laggy and crashes so often when I try to install and play games from Google Play store -- or even from the Kindle store, such as SimCity Buildit or other -- because this is one of the cheapest tablets you can find.  You could say you get what you pay for with this model.  When I try to play a game, if the screen moves too quickly, the game immediately crashes so I have to be very careful when I'm moving around.  It comes with a 30-day return window and in the end I decided to keep it rather than returning it because there isn't anything that is a better deal and I wasn't willing to pay hundreds of dollars for something that would be lag-free since I use it so infrequently as it is not my main electronic device.  I wouldn't recommend it as a main device for anyone who plans to play games.  It might be fine for reading books, which is I guess what Kindle devices were originally designed for anyway but I haven't tried it for that.  Hopefully Amazon will find a way to use more robust hardware in the future to make it actually possible to play games on it comfortably without raising the price too much.
title: This tablet is not for gaming

author: Nicole Kendricks
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2020
review_content: The sales price got me to buy this Fire 7 Tablet.  Since it is a Amazon product.  It included everything Amazon has and you get your alerts when your delivery is near on the home screen.  All of the Amazon features are included.  With a prime membership you will have it all and more.  You could import all your email addressed to your tablet.  Add your favorite websites and bookmarks to the Silk browser.  Sync your calendar, contacts, photos and what ever else you may want from all of your other devices too your Fire 7.  The Zoom app is available to download for that video meeting that may take place on Zoom.  The Google Meet is not a app available at this time and a couple of other apps aren't , but hopefully it will become an available app as well as others.  The storage is 16 GB and you could get a SD memory card for more storage.  The camera take good pictures and it has a video camera I haven't used yet.  I like that the size is not so large to hold.  I take it to the Amazon hub lockers to get my code and scan bar when I have my package delivered to one of them.  I use Amazon Music, but you can get all the other music apps added for free if you was to use them instead.  And it has Alexa to as her a question and you could change her voice especially if you have other Amazon gadgets around your home for a different sound of voice.  And then you came turn Alexa off and go hands free without her.  Their are other features with the Fire 7 tablet like parental control and if you get one for a child you can use the Amazon Free Time app included and I would be only on the app with great choices for a child to explore.
title: The Tablet size is wonderful.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Andrew Verley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2020
review_content: I purchased the Tablet as an inexpensive alternative to an Ipad or Android device for my 6 year old daughter.  She had been using an old Iphone 6 that I was no longer using to watch videos and play games.  Here is my experience and what I found.Setting up the unit:  It took a while to get used to the controls coming from using Apple and Android devices.  Overall it was not to bad.  The biggest issue I had was cleaning up the apps screens on both the kid mode and normal modes.  Basically on the normal mode you are stuck with what you get, there is very little changing the screen layout, the screens you see or removing apps from those screens unless you installed them.  The kids mode worked well but it was very limiting, my daughter doesn't like it because she doesn't have any freedoms to install even free apps if she would like, this doesn't bother me to much because she can not browse to find what she could want she just doesn't use it.Modes:  The normal mode would be fine for an adult.  I would warn that it is very cluttered and there is next to no customization on layout or what you do see.  The biggest issue is that you have to link the tablet to an amazon account and everything is one click buy.  I even turned off automatic purchases and it still ended up buying items without a password, I may need to spend more time with this feature but after testing it a couple times I am starting to get shy with hitting the buttons and potentially making a purchase.  The kids mode is adequate but again there is very little customization, I would say more than the normal mode.The construction of the unit is fine, everything works as it should.Ultimately if I could I would return it due to the customization and the either total lock down or total open purchase environment.  It is basically an expensive paper weight in my household.The biggest improvement would be to have all the apps and stores on an app screen that you can access if you want not have it all on your home screens.  Give me one blank home screen like apple or android that I can customize and the amazon fire tablet would be an exceptional value.
title: Not an Ipad or Android device Replacement.  Build quality is great Software, not so much.

author: Abigail Williams
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2019
review_content: I started in the Kindle family in 2013 (!) with a Kindle Fire Tablet, and used it up until recently when the battery life was not great and the Hulu app stopped updating. Using the kindle recycling program, I bought this new Kindle in plum and was very satisfied with my purchase. Very clear graphics for streaming movies, access to all of my Amazon Prime shows, and seamlessly moved over my extensive collection of e-books to this new device. The battery definitely leaves something to be desired when exclusively streaming video (obviously that uses more battery) but it's good for 6 hours at least and charges fast in about an hour from 0-100%. The interface is updated from my old kindle, but is intuitive to use and is more desktop-like than the old home screen. I also like the update on the location of the headphone jack, charging port, and power button- all in a row at the top, out of reach for accidental pushing but not for use (the old power button was on the back and it was the worst!) Not sure if this kindle will last for six years like the other one did (It does seem slimmer and therefore more fragile), but I will probably always be a member of the kindle family!

author: Karen Ledford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2019
review_content: My old Kindle died this past summer. I tired from reading on a smaller phone screen via the Kindle app so asked for a Fire 7 for Christmas. My sister bought it for me and it arrived early.This is a decent tablet for how cheap it is. I got the 32 GB without special offers. Only available in black.I've had it 5 days now and it's #1 primary use is for reading books. The battery SERIOUSLY SUCKS. Or maybe it's the OS. Or all the bloatware.In sleep mode following a full charge, it will lose half its charge over about 3 hours. In SLEEP MODE! You expect some drain but that's ridiculous!So this morning I modified the various settings to reduce battery drain (no location services, no notifications, adjusted brightness, etc.). I don't use it for games, email, music, videos and other processor hogging apps. I turned off the data collection stuff. After I download a book, I go into airplane mode. Apparently you have to do all this to only have to charge once a day when it's on sleep mode all but ~2 hours of the day, and I'm only reading during that time.7 hours battery life my ass!

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review_content: I love my Kindle Fire and I read on it every single night. I recently purchased this one to replace the Kindle Fire I've been using for the past 4-5 years. The previous one had a fantastic battery life. I had to charge it about once a week, or maybe even a little longer than that between charges. This one, however, uses so much battery life while sitting idle! For instance, this morning I looked at the battery at about 8 am when I woke up and it was 84%. When I went to bed last night, it was at 68%! It had just been sitting there all day and the battery was draining like crazy. I'm very disappointed in this aspect of the new Kindle Fire. You can put it into battery saver mode, which is something I guess? But then the screen dims and there's an orange bar across the top and bottom of the screen. I will play with some settings and do some online research to see what I can do to increase battery life.All that said, I do still really like this Kindle Fire. I just hope I can figure out a way that I don't have to have it plugged in constantly. I use it as my alarm clock, so I really don't want that battery to die overnight!

review_content: I have been using Amazon Kindle Fire 7 (2019) for more than a month, and I absolutely love it. In my opinion, Kindle Fire 7 is a totally universal and practical tablet.---MEMORYI got my Kindle Fire 7 packed with 16 GB of memory. This amount of storage is more than enough for me. Even though I have hundreds of books, photos, and media on my phone, I still have almost 8GB of free space. What is more, I can also upload additional files to Amazon Cloud.---SILK BROWSERThis browser is very fast and packed with a lot of useful features such as dark mode, private browsing, and etc. I won't install any other browsers since the Silk browser is providing me with everything I need for comfortable and safe Internet browsing.---READING EXPERIENCEI never thought that reading ebooks on an LCD screen can be comfortable. I have already read dozens of ebooks on my Kindle Fire 7. I can tell you that I never felt any eye-strain nor any discomfort. The reading experience is amazing. I see no reading experience difference if I compare Kindle Fire's 7 LCD screen to the E-Ink display. ZERO eye-strain.---SPEAKERS AND MICROPHONEI am using my Kindle Fire 7 for audio chatting, messaging, and watching movies. The sound of the speakers is very good. What is more, its prebuilt microphone's recording abilities are top-notch.---CAMERAAs soon as I tested a camera on my Kindle Fire 7, I understood that it has a high-quality lens since it shoots too good videos and photos for a device packed with only 2MP megapixels. Photos are very sharp and crips. The same qualities can be applied to videos taken with my Kindle Fire 7 (2019)---LOADS OF HELPFUL PREINSTALLED APPSAmazon Kindle Fire 7 came with some truly helpful and convenient apps such as Amazon Shop (for comfortable shopping on Amazon), Kindle Store ( to buy ebooks), News ( to read compilations of news from my favorite news portals), Weather, Prime Video, Amazon Alexa, Amazon Music, and etc. I use all of these services, and therefore, I like this preinstall feature of the tablet.---HANDS-FREE AMAZON ALEXAI also love my tablet because it has hands-free Amazon Alexa. I use it on all occasions for playing music, checking out the weather, news, and other stuff. It is a very beneficial and useful tool.---FINAL WORDSIn my opinion, Amazon Kindle Fire 7 (2019) is one of the best tablets on the market nowadays. It is not expensive. It is smart, stylish, functional, practical, and light.
title: Universal, light, stylish, and powerful!

author: H. S. Marsh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
review_content: The Kindle Fire tablet makes the same mistake that most cell phones and other IT make.  If you want it simply to be able to read e-books, you end up with something that is more complex than necessary and that can be annoying at times. We have other ways to take pictures and play games. The only thing that it adds that improves the original Kindle is the ability to get to public library web sites so you can read e-books in their lending library. Other than that, the features are mostly worthless. We get them from other devices that are better structured for those other things.The screen is good but not better than other devices.  The touch screen feature is handy, especially to turn pages.Battery life is OK but not spectacular.  If you forget to turn Wi-Fi off after downloading an e-book, the battery drains pretty quickly.  That could be fixed by a software change that puts Wi-Fi into deep sleep (hibernation in laptop terminology) after a selected time of no use.Other than these minor complaints, the tablet is good.  Of course, since we've had it for only a couple weeks, we can't say anything about its long-term reliability, but Kindles in the past tended to be pretty good for a long time.
title: OK But Too Many Features If You Just Want a Kindle
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Ruby Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: I received the ninth gen Kindle Fire 7 for a Christmas gift. It's going back this week.I use a tablet mostly for reading online, including lots of PDFs and scanned books available in Open Library, so that's all I used this tablet for. Considering how much I love the two Kindle e-readers I have, I thought this Kindle Fire 7 would be a great replacement when the Asus tablet I had used since 2015 finally gave up, so I asked for it for Christmas.Unfortunately, the Kindle Fire 7's screen resolution is so poor that even the app icons look overly pixelated. Reading text in apps is very difficult, and reading PDFs is worse. Everything looks blurry, and it causes terrible eyestrain. The blue light filter, a feature I love on my phones and the Asus tablet, actually makes things worse, and I've yet to be able to adjust it in a way that makes it useful.One of my complaints is an odd one, considering - the Kindle app on the Fire is the only one that doesn't sync with new content automatically; I have to force items to it by going to Amazon's website. Yet my phones sync seamlessly!

author: Kindle Customer

review_content: Replaced dying kindle with this do to lagging responses. That 6 year old kindle beats this new one hands down for battery life. The battery life is horrible even dumping unnecessary crap that Amazon puts on its products. Playing games that requires touch screen action is a fricking joke. It was cheap, I will admit. A  reader for outside because the backlit ones suck in the sun, 3 7" for gifts and 2 for myself, (one cratered and was replaced by Amazon) an 8" because I thought an older one had died but it resurrected itself. This was supposed to be a replacement because, again, thought my old one had cratered.  This one was $30 plus $10 for a case.  $40 I should have put to my grandson's college fund.  I will keep it in my rotation of kindles so I always have one charged.  It is sleek and small, but not worth spit for longevity of charge.

author: happy buyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: Those who know me and I am sure Amazon knows by my purchases and good response I am a big fan of Amazon. It appears this tablet is well made and has good components. Were it fails to even remotely satisfy me is that Amazon controls much to much of what I'd like to do with it. I can put up with the ads and so on but I will not put up with the way I have very little control over the way I'd like to set it up. For instance I like Fire fox browser, but Amazon will not allow it. If I want google search engine it must be on Amazons Silk browser. Some of my news feeds I can not log onto, unless of course if I subscribe to Amazon's kindle version. As I see it I really do not own my device, I am just granted use with use  restrictions. I was given my 7 for Christmas and I am appreciative of the gift. In fact I was so thrilled to set it up and start using it. Sadly that thrill was gone too BB. I never felt I'd find a reason to not like Amazon. Again I can put up with the ads and such but using this tablet is like parent control at 65. How much is enough? Buy one of these and you'll know.

author: teddygrace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2020
review_content: A few irritations - periodically, the wallpaper changes from a custom one from my photos back to one of the stock wallpapers. It's inconvenient that the keyboard has symbols on the 2nd & 3rd pages that should be on the 1st. I've never had a Fire (9 of them) that had as much battery life as the specs say they do.For those complaining abt or disappointed that the Fire can't access the Google Play Store, finding this a reason to return the Fire or not buy one: YES, YOU CAN put the Play Store on a Fire (which greatly enhances use of the Fire - there are some very useful apps in the Play Store that Amazon used to have in the App Store, such as some parts of Microsoft Office - I always check the Amazon App Store 1st & purchase there if possible) by sideloading it - easy to do, but  Amazon STRONGLY advises against it, & if problems with or damage to the Fire result, neither Amazon nor Google can/will help you - strictly your risk. Plus, it uses a good bit of storage. But, the keyboard, the "Gboard" app, is far superior to the one on the Fire. To find out where to get instructions for sideloading the Play Store, search the Amazon Digital & Devices Forum.

author: Tom de
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
review_content: I got myself two new tablets for Christmas. I'm 75 and don't need presents but wanted to try a new tablet and also get a second one for just my music to separate that memory from the rest. I have a lot of music.  I got a new FIRE 8 HD and the FIRE 7. The Fire 7 tablet is a great size for walking with your music as the smaller size is easier to get into a jacket pocket or a sweatshirt pouch. I ONLY have my music on this tablet and was disappointed that I filled it to the max before I had downloaded all my music from the cloud. I then bought a SANDISK to put more music on and that worked really well so glad about that.The Fire 7 is pretty slow for downloading and also for making changes like deleting duplicates or moving a song to a playlist. author: T. Pallen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2020
review_content: Overall, I'm very disappointed with this device, primarily because it runs very slowly, particularly in regard to MP3 albums that I have purchased from Amazon. First of all, the music library takes as much as 30 seconds to appear at all; calling up the last album I listened to can take another 20-30 seconds; clicking on the "My Music" link leads to another long delay -- and so it goes. Once the requested album does open, all too frequently not all of its contents are available (a species of thievery committed by Amazon ever since its costly on-line music "service" first appeared). These delays are common to both Online and Off-Line music, by the way.I would blame part of these delays on my ATT internet connection were it not for the fact that other kindles I own operate at greater speeds.Another disappointment crops up when I am reading a book and decide to change the background color: what should be a simple, quick transition instead requires several steps because this Kindle looses track reading progress and it's necessary to re-select the book from my library. In fact, I'm returned to the Books category, but it's necessary to select "Library" and then tap on the book in progress. Doing this sometimes to a startlingly bright and blank screen before the text reappears. This kind of rig-a-ma-role is not necessary on other Kindles.The only advantage of this (slowly smoldering) Fire Tablet is its comfortable and portable size; however, I cannot understand why Amazon has not adapted the "origami" case + stand available for previous versions of this device.
title: Not as good as previous versions!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: R. Ortiz B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2020
review_content: I purchased this tablet for use by my children, with Kindle Unlimited.  Unfortunately, later versions of the Kindle OS have removed the option for games to be stored on an external SD card, which makes external staorage next to useless.  Of the 16 GB internal storage, about half is actually available to store apps and it is amazing how quickly a child will burn through this, as each game requires somewhere between 80 and 200 MB.  To add insult to injury, navigating the Kindle settings and manually uninstalling each app is a tremendous hassle, exacerbated by the painful Free Time carrousel (which does not let you easily seaprate intalled apps from those available for download).  Comparing this clunky interface with my Android phone makes me want to weep.If Amazon wanted to achieve reasonable ease of use, the following changes are suggested: 1. allow for storing apps on an SD card, for heaven's sake! 2. fix the painful Free Time interface for users over 5 years old, allowing filtering intalled apps and easily uninstalling by long press, as has been the option in every other major Android OS for the last 10 years.  Just a suggestion.
title: Inexpensive, but hampered by major limitations (including the clunky Free Time interface)

author: Brittany H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2019
review_content: I was offered $20 off of this tablet for being a Prime member and I wasn't sure what to expect. I bought three of these for my kiddos. I read that it did not support Google Play, which bummed me out.However, they offer what's called Amazon Free Time and it's BETTER and SAFER than Google Play in my opinion! You do get a free trial of Amazon Free Time and I'm glad I took a chance on this -- It offers so much educational content, apps, youtube videos and they're all age-related content. You don't have to worry about ads or random videos that may not be appropriate for your little ones.I highly recommend this tablet for your kids! My kids are 8.5, 6, and 3 and they all really enjoy this tablet! You can link your Amazon e-mail to them all and just create a child profile for each one. You can set time limits, goals for reading books, games, etc. It's great. You can also set their bedtime and it will shut off at that time and they can't log back in without knowing your password or pin.The tablet itself is amazing. It's quick, super cute, and I couldn't ask for more! You won't regret this purchase.

author: ReinoEMO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
review_content: TL;DR:I bought Ad versionUpdates eventually failed to download/install.Fire Tablet Bricked.Short 3 month warranty and I did not buy an extended warrantyBe paranoid and only buy Fire Tablets on sale and/or with extended warranty.My direct recommendation, buy a different brand.Review:First, I ended up getting the "Ad" device (did not realize there were two versions, one with Ads and the other without and that was my fault. The difference is the Ad one is $10-15 USD cheaper depending on whether or not it is on sale.The device when working is a 4/5 stars as it is a Fire Tablet and therefore has a limited App Store and not a normal tablet with iOS or Android with more things, but chances are you are mostly using it because it has a nice screen to read kindle books and not to take pictures or to play the LoL knock-off, Tencent owned Mobile Legends Bang Bang, for example (which is available on Fire Tablet for those that care, which i do not since I am not a fan of that game, but it is pretty popular).The issue is that I purchased my device and three (3)-ish months later the warranty expired which will obviously come into play later. Things worked well initially, but then it randomly gave up on me when trying to update the device. Apparently, it did not do so automatically which I enabled because of ease, and once I realized it was not automatically updating I went to manually update the device which then bricked it right before the full year. So even though Amazon is stating in Orders sections that I have time to replace the item, I can no longer replace it. If enough people report the bricking issue, it hopefully gets patched out for future owners so they are not getting the short end of the stick. So please people report these issues so devs or engineers are aware and can patch them out.Customer support will gladly try to assist to the best of their ability, but their hands are tied and they will only be able to offer a 15% discount and nothing else. So please purchase this device with great paranoia OR just buy a competitor's tablet from another site or competitor's site. Since other's will back up their brand(s) or partnered devices with at least a full one year warranty instead of 3.5 months. I have used phones and other tablets that have lasted me years, and with one year warranties so I have not had a need to get "extended warranties" since those competitor devices have been built to last relative to Fire Tablet.Yes, it can sound "tinfoily" to say that it is done this way to push the purchases of "two year extended warranties" but that is a great business strategy, and I am not arguing or warning against it. However, the issue is they are seemingly aware that their products are not great compared to their competitors and therefore will not back up their Fire Tablets for a full year. Unsure if the Ad version is more likely to brick your phone, so if something breaks report it since maybe there is an issue with the Ad version, i don't know I cannot prove this, but it does not hurt to report things and if there is a patter to get it patched or fixed.So if you get a Fire Tablet, make sure you get it on sale and/or with an extended warranty. I, however, will be hard-pressed to purchase another Fire Tablet and will most likely purchase a competing brand (preferably a South Korean brand since I own several devices that are South Korean brands, and even if made in PR China, they are still working great after 2-5 years depending on when I bought it).
title: Updates Brick Device & Small Warranty Window

review_content: A lot of the reasons for me giving it only three stars is because of my lack of knowing exactly what a Fire Tablet does and does not do.- I wanted a tablet to read books with and use with a few other apps but didn't want to buy an iPad because of the hefty cost. review_content: Ordered a black and a plum 7" Fire on july 15.  The black one came first and setup was a breeze .., as it should be.  It's been great.  The plum 7" was an entirely different story. author: James L. Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: Nothing about this device is intuitive. I have it specifically for 1 app that I need that only comes on Kindle. That app doesn’t show updates in the App Store. I have to wait for the app to prompt me because somehow available updates aren’t synced to the store. Also the battery life is terrible. I only use the thing every other day or so, and if it’s not fully powered off it will run through its entire battery in one day of NOT being used. I also find that if I change any setting I need to restart the device for it to work. It’s simply a terrible design. The screen is much larger than my smartphone but using it is so annoying that I’d rather just watch movies or play games on the phone. Even though I’m missing out on a ton of screen size. I can’t emphasize enough how counterintuitive all the controls are. It drives me crazy trying to do anything. Googling directions on how to do simple tasks often yields an incorrect or ineffective solution. Not like I haven’t tried to get help figuring out the system.... would recommend any other tablet over this one. But I’m still going to have to use it for that one aforementioned app that is only available for kindles, and there’s no substitute. Grr.

author: UserA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2019
review_content: I have an old, 2nd generation Fire HD 7 which I cumulatively use about 2 hours a day for email, web queries, shopping Amazon, and reading. It's gotten so old that I tried replacing it with a Fire 10, which was a disappointment, and now a newer Fire 7. After using this, my old HD 7 is still my go-to tablet...until it quits. Both the Fire 10, which I bought  last year, and this new Fire 7 have wifi connection issues: weak reception even next to the antenna and frequent disconnects. My old HD 7 always shows the strongest connection anywhere in the house. My other complaint is the wide-screen display format. My HD 7 has a "fatter" screen in portrait mode, which is almost exclusively how I use it. Email, documents, and web pages are all easier to read with a more square screen, which is why all premium tablets (iPad, Surface) use a 3:2 aspect ratio rather the the 16:9 ratio on this new Fire 7. If one only watches movies (with headphones, to avoid using the single, tinny speaker on this Fire model) I suppose it would work fine. The screen is good on this Fire 7 and it has an SD slot for more storage, which are both improvements over my old one. It also seems marginally faster than my old one.  For now, though, because of wifi issues and the aspect ratio of the screen, I'm sticking to my old HD 7 until its demise.

author: Kolby
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2019
review_content: Ok so I've only had this for one day so far, but right way i notice a difference from the previous 2017 fire 7 model.- The build quality seems to be a tad cheaper (especially the buttons feel more wobbly, may give out over time)- The battery life, yes, seems a bit less. Even turning the brightness down to a quarter, but also using it consistently, i was getting close to 6 hrs.- I strongly recommend to use the wall charger when charging, and do not use amazons charging cord as this thing is as super stiff to plug in. And I had to almost yank it out, which i think is part of the reason the charging port doesn't last as long on these tablets.- I do notice that it will lag when scrolling at times, and the image is a little grainy, but granted it was under $50 bucks, i ain't complaining.- Playing games is actually quite smooth, i was fairly impressed. For a faster experience overall, make sure to close out of all other apps that don't need to be opened.Overall this tablet doesn't have the best battery life, or build/port quality. However, with the increased size to 16gigs, and slightly faster processor, not to mention that it still is snappy and tons of content within amazon's ecosystem, IMO, its still impressive. And  to get this (especially on sale) under $50 bucks....or 2 for that price on prime day.....its really good. I would still recommend, but advise to be gentle with the charging port to not have issues charging down the road.

author: DVX
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2020
review_content: My first Amazon Fire tablet finally broke down on Friday, my new one arrived 2 days later, on Sunday.  Awesome.I ordered without analyzing the 'fine print' on the Fire sales page, trusting that its terms coincide in general with those of my first Fire (although subconsciously wondering how the same low price applies after two years and to a bigger and better Fire;  my subconscious said 'wait and see').  This morning, I noticed the battery seems to have a rapid depletion rate compared to my first Fire - from 100% to 88% after an hour (Fire was on, WiFi on, but neither was being used).  I figured the videos and merchandise offers on the lock screen might be draining it.  It turns out that to unsubscribe from those Special Offers, I'll be charged $15, originally set up as a subsidy that makes the $49 price possible.  Buying this 9th generation Fire 7 would otherwise cost $64.99 rather than the $49.99 I paid for it.  On the other hand, one quick swipe directly upwards removes this recurring screen saver and takes you right back to were you were before it came on.I don't know how this purchase will turn out.  Maybe I would have paid the $64.99 after reading the 'fine print', because my Fire is a valuable backup computer.  Maybe the battery life of it actually is longer than that of my 7th generation Fire, as claimed.  Maybe the 16 GB memory will be useful too.  What minor issues the Fire series has, the 7th generation is still an awesome machine.More good news!  Audio would not play through my earphones, continues to play through speakers. This happened on my previous Fire 7 (7th gen.).  I spent the whole day searching for a solution.  Went back home, grabbed all my old earphones, tried them and audio though them instead of through speakers.  The old ones are of a different brand AND one of them has just one "ring" around the jack, the other has two rings, the one that won't play audio has three rings.  New lessons to learn.
title: Awesome

author: carguy76

review_content: This is my fourth Kindle over about 10 years. My last ones battery just refuse to take charge anymore. I do have a problem with this one. Which is very sad to me because I have been a long time Kindle supporter. I have given them as gifts to family members. Both of my children have their own Kindles with free fly. I'm a prime user with Kindle unlimited as well. Hopefully I'll figure one day how to get it to work.

review_content: I had an older Kindle Paperwhite. I like to read books, as well as the occasional manga or comic. author: Robert Monk
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020
review_content: This may be an ok product for some, but un-announced fee to remove ads boils my blood and is a 1-star no matter how good the thing might otherwise be. Since I bought this to use as the system display for a solar PV + batteries installation for a customer, I can't install an ad-hosting scheme in their utility room.Also, the app I specifically bought this to run, from Emporia Vue home energy monitoring, is not on the Amazon app store. Nor is any other app I really want.Jailbreaking for access to the Google Play store appears to be a dicey proposition requiring a windows PC and potentially shady installer software that may or may not keep up with Kindle updates that will likely break the jailbreak and cause glitches or failure-to-run for these apps.Probably an alright cheap medium for kids' apps and books, but think of it as Amazon's window into your home to sell you stuff, not a user-centered tool, like all computing devices should be by default and unless spelled out otherwise.I plan to return mine unless I discover better work-arounds for the above issues.

author: Owen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
review_content: Before we start let me tell you that this device can be mildly tweaked without voiding any warranties, which makes it a high quality for the price Android tablet with the best of Amazon features and value built in. Having Prime Video along with the Amazon Library of software is a great value in itself. The Appstore seems to have a pretty good amount of apps to enjoy, and the hardware specs are fantastic for the price point. A little more RAM would be welcomed, but if you are getting this for $50 and under you can't complain at all, it's fairly fluid even in the intense applications.Now for part 2: if you install the Google Play Store, this thing really comes to life. Having SnapChat and your favorite mobile games on it is a real treat. I was able to link app accounts I had on my iPhone 8 Plus to a Facebook account and move them over to my Kindle Fire 7 very fluidly and without constant crashes. I just hope they keep the Fire OS Android based for years to come, as it's a developer's treat to tweak it to an even better level of entertainment. There are tech articles that outline a process how to do it, which isn't terribly difficult, just has to be followed in order. If you aren't slightly tech savvy or willing to give something new a try, you probably won't be able to install it. Which isn't the end of the world, as the device already comes packed with great features. I'd say if there were even more apps in the Amazon Appstore, you wouldn't even need to bother with doing this.
title: Versatility with some tweaking, great value for specs. Amazon exclusives a plus!

author: Craig M. Reed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: For the price, you can't find a better deal (Even at full retail). This is not productivity tablet.  You can stream (and download for offline use) video from Amazon Prime, Netflix, etc.  Music is also great again the big players, Amazon Music, Pandora, SiriusXM, and more.  The battery life is amazing.  I use it at work for hours non-stop paired to a bluetooth headset.  The size is great for travel, or one handed use while lounging the recliner.  Don't forget about communication.  You have Amazon Alexa, Zoom, and Skype.  Plus the basic services like email, calendar.  For what most people do with their tablets this is a good choice.  Cons are are weak built in speaker but paired with a bluetooth (or wired) speaker or headset and problem solved.  While is does not natively support Google play store, there are very easy ways to get that added without much know how.  Plenty of youtube videos to walk you thru it.  If you're looking for casual use.  This is worth some thought.  I have the 7", 8" Plus, and the 10". and very happy with them all.
title: Entertainment on-the-go

author: Shelly P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: I bought this for myself as a Christmas gift, hoping it would be an upgrade to my older Kindle Fire.  I use these things very sparingly.  Mostly for games while I'm traveling.  Maybe an e-book or movie now and again.  But not heavy use at all.  The battery drains so quickly!  It drains even when it's not being used, not connected to wi-fi and not running anything in the background (as far as I can tell).  My older Kindle Fire's battery lasts and lasts compared to this one.  It drains so quickly I had to keep checking and rechecking to make sure I wasn't actually looking at the older one.  I was really looking forward to this being a nicer version of my old one but sadly there isn't really any improvement that I can see.  I don't use Alexa or some of the other features that are available so maybe those bells and whistles make it better for people who do.  I just needed a basic tablet to play games on and read/watch movies during vacations.  For the price I paid, it will have to do.  But I probably will not re-purchase another Amazon tablet in the future.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2019
review_content: The issue appears to manifest after the sleep mode is engaged. I've tested on a JBL micro speaker a Bluetooth headset, the audio system of a Toyota Tacoma and a Dodge Journey.For the micro the playback will stop and after a few seconds the speaker emits a beep and the application goes into pause mode.The same thing happens with the headset except there is no beep.For the systems in both vehicles the play back will start to 'skip' a second or two (the story or song continues but no sound is heard) and then it will stop completely. The audio system display will then show the "device not connected" message. The Dakota system will reconnect (my fire is the default device) but with the Journey I have to explicitly reconnect.The elapsed time before the connection drops is not consistent but does depend on the sleep timeout.30 - seconds: Playback stops anywhere between 2 - 6 minutes1 - minute: Playback stops between 8 - 10 minutes5 - minutes: 12-19 minutes30 - minutes: 40 - 50 minutesI've already returned one table for this issue thinking it was a one time only but now I'm thinking it may be a basic design flaw. (Didn't have this issue with my old Kindle)Just spent 3 hours on tech Chat with no joy. Got passed to phoned support. Had to explain AGAIN what the problem was. They issued a warranty replacement order (just like my first unit) but this time I will keep this unit as the Amazon tech team (I guess the actual geeks?) will contact me next week to try and troubleshoot this issue.If I get no joy I will get a full refund and use the money to fix my old Fire.
title: Dropped Blue Tooth Connection - No solutions from Tech Support

author: BW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: This 9th generation Fire was a gift to replace my old reliable 4th generation device because the new one has more memory.  While on the surface the 9th generation is a good device, it is straight out of the box absolutely infested with adware for additional aps, suggested movies to watch, recommended TV shows, and of course - products sold by Amazon.  My trusty old 4th generation device was not plagued with these problems.  During my FIRST conversation with customer support, the representative was able to remove SOME if the advertising, but not all, by changing some settings on Amazon's end.  Unfortunately, those changes also apparently prevented the new device from receiving email; in fact, the email confirmation that I received from CS stating that the problems were solved was the last email the device received.After trying to compare settings - screen by screen - between my old and new Fire Tablets, I decided to contact CS again for assistance.  The CS rep was marginally attentive to my description of the problems at hand. He asked if he could share my screen and I agreed.  I watched for quite a while as he from screen to screen without ever suggesting any changes to settings or Aps.  He said he was making changes in the background and I had to restart the tablet numerous times.  He never solved any of my issues with the new Fire.  I did receive an email stating that "...  we have escalated the issue to our technical team and I will contact you once we get a revert from the technical team regarding it."  That was five days ago and I have heard nothing since.  I left a low rating on the email that I received following that second CS encounter hoping that it would prompt a response from Amazon; it did not.  Thankfully, during the shared-screen session with CS, I was able to have a glimpse of some email advanced settings and I was able to go correct those settings to allow email receipt.  Strangely, the CS rep never noticed those during my second telephone call.I am disappointed at Amazon's lack of follow-through and hope that this review might encourage them to provide some actual competent customer support.
title: Device Infested with advertising - Spamazon

author: Dr. David R. Bess
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
review_content: I have a Kindle Paperwhite but purchased this Kindle Fire exclusively for the text-to-speech feature.  I do a great deal of driving and want to be able to listen to my Kindle books on the road.  Many of them do not have an Audible version, and there's an additional fee if they do.  Now I can listen to a Kindle book on the road, then when I get to my work or home I can sync it, then continue to read on my Paperwhite.Now, to review the quality of the reading with the text-to-speech, it is very good.  There are 6 options for the English language:  American male and female, British male and female, and Australian male and female.  I prefer the British voices, and make my choice depending on whether the author is male or female.When I first purchased this device and tried to use it on the road, the text-to-speech kept shutting down.  It would read for a few minutes, then stop.  After doing some online research and discovering it was a common problem, I put the sleep mode on its lowest setting.  I also turned off all notifications for all other apps.  When I listen on the road, I also put it on airplane mode.  Now I don't have any issues with the text-to-speech shutting down.  I only gave four stars for this review because going to all this trouble shouldn't be necessary.  Amazon surely can tweak this problem of their device and fix it.Still, this little Kindle Fire is a great bargain for $49.  As far as the other features, the screen is a little slow, as is the browser, but for $49 there's little room to complain.  For me, it's well worth the money I paid just for the text-to-speech feature alone.
title: Text-to-Speech Works Great Once Configured Properly
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Ruth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: I purchased the Fire 7 when it was discounted in November.For the price, this is a very nice device and serves the purpose I want it for.I have a Fire HD 10, and I like the larger screen on it for viewing videos, and surfing the web, but I find ittoo large to use for reading books on, especially those that I download from Overdrive or other e-reader apps.The Fire 7 is just the right size for this purpose.I purchased the Amazon Kindle cover for it, and it matches and fits perfectly.  Unlike some of the reviews I read before purchasing, I have no issues with it standing up in either landscape or portrait mode.The battery life on this device is actually better than the battery life on my Kindle Fire HD 10 that I purchased last year, but I think that Amazon needs to do a better job on increasing the battery life of these devices.This is an entry level tablet that I purchased at a very affordable cost, so the sometimes slower processing speed when surfing the web and the mono sound is not an issue for me.The device is meeting my needs and I am pleased with it.

review_content: (See update)  I got this only to read on and so far it has done well with serving it’s purpose. Other than reading I use it mostly for playing solitaire and browsing Facebook. author: Anna M. Boley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2020
review_content: I use Amazon a lot, shopping, kindle, audible. Some of the small things my phone doesn't do I enjoy, like having my newspaper and magazines more accessible, or being able to immediately see my new kindle book has an audible file attached without searching for it. Unfortunately I use Google a lot too, hopefully they will integrate one day. The ads on the lockscreen don't bother me at all. I have seen some minor speed issues when loading apps or video but that's expected, I wait a few seconds at most. Once loaded I've had no issues. Amazon has done a good job of keeping their own products in check, I can be reading a kindle book and switch to the audible book and back again on this tablet without issue so far. I also find it far easier to spot things like kindle unlimited books that seem to be hidden in the phone app, recommendations below a book I've finished sorted as unlimited and regular is a plus. Using your prime account benefits is also easier, you may like me find benefits you didn't know about because they were hidden before.

author: HowardArt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020
review_content: We bought the first Fire 6" tablet when it came out; today it still runs, even though it won't hold a battery charge all night.This new 7" is a different deal altogether. I bought mine during the "Prime Days", where I snagged it for $29.99. I thought I was doing good, I bought a nice, useable case, and a 64GB expansion card. All set!Now, we've bought a few for the kids, who have always told us they're slow, and they're right, not as fast as a Samsung or Apple, but I figured, you get what you pay for.Well, this new 9th generation has proven such. It won't install certain titles from the very limited App Store, I get screen flicker that I've never had on any other model, and it takes the cake on slow! I got fooled into believing the latest and greatest would be an improvement, but I had to write in and say "not so fast!"Now, it's not all bad, it runs my bible software (Olive Tree) just fine, but every so often I have to replace the "config" folder because something goes wrong and I can only use the cheap bible it comes with. It does hookup Bluetooth items, such as a folding keyboard I have, my BT headphones, and the BT play unit for the car. I can also watch Prime Video, Netflix, Xfinity Stream On it just fine (With the headphones too).But what I don't like, Amamzon's App Store does NOT have a viable replacement for MS Office, and for that matter, not one for Open or Libre Office either. The one they feature gets $50 a year, which kind of hurts because it's not as good, and my MS 365 lets have 5 computers and a dozen or so tablets and phones.It reads books just as well as all Fires do, I haven't tested the Audible...But overall, it's slow, that screen flicker bothers me because it's not when I'm watching any streaming, just working with the tablet itself.This may seem a good unit, but save up and get the next one up. Too cheap for my blood...I have writing bad reviews, but I've been working on this for 7 months now, giving it the benefit of the doubt - but I wish I had bought a better model...
title: I love 'em, but this one has disappointed me

author: huckjam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: Had it for a few months never really used it past a few mins on the web browser. So last week decided to start using it put in a brand new 128gb Sandisk MicroSD 3 days later error on screen sd must be reinserted or files will be lost. But wait its plugged in still, I remove and reinsert nothing restart tablet the same issue. Says I must reformat card try that and card is no longer readable so I put in PC no partition, no drive letter, no disk info, nothing just disk1 in management. I cant format, partition, or recover. So I call it a fluke and get another card BRAND NEW Sandisk the kind I've been using for years in my phone, Nvidia shield tablet, Nintendo switch, cameras, and many more also happens to be the exact kind amazon recommends. 2 days later guess what? Another unrecoverable corrupt microsd. 2 cards in less than a week. Oh and I forgot after the first card was destroyed I factory reset the tablet just to be safe. I have 2 gb sd cards that are over a decade and a half old that still work fine Ive never had a card go corrupt before without it being pyshically damaged its just too much of a coincidence this happens from 2 cards in 2 different batches of 2 different size in one week in a tablet so I do a quick google search and guess what im not the only one this is WIDESPREAD. Garbage tablet is garbage.
title: GARBAGE DONT BUY IF YOU DONT LIKE REPLACING SDCARDS EVERY OTHER WEEK

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: I have purchased a total of 4 of these tablets. And as much as I love Amazon this tablet for me is a hit and miss. First off the screen and display is good.  Volume is decent enough, nothing headphones can't fix... Unfortunately, the tablet starts to dwindle after roughly a few months usage.... The two tablets purchased for Christmas 2019 are constantly in use. My girls won't put them down unless they're charging or they (girls) are asleep so they are always being used. I would say roughly these tablets started being problematic around month 4/5 not really sure... Constant use of these tablets takes a toll after awhile. The ability to connect and stay connected to wifi is frustrating. Then there's the constant freezing of the tablet. Sometimes we have to restart the tablets multiple times, sometimes to no avail. Oh my gees the battery life is almost non existent. No sooner you charge it up it's in need of a charge again in less than a hour. If I would have reviewed them the moment I recieved them I would be happy and positive. But probably  not so happy had I waited a bit longer... But being that it has been since last year that two of these purchases were made, this is a fair and honest enough review. The recent purchases of Amazon's Fire Tablets were from Best Buy. They lasted a good 4 months before problems with wifi connectivity and not being able to do anything with them started. I purchased them from Bestbuy because at the time the time frame for delivery was after the time school would have started and I needed them ASAP... These tablets were for online class curriculums and such "ONLY" being that my children are homeschooled due to Covid-19. With that being said they are not used nearly as much as the previous two tablets. They are strictly for school and they are sometimes not used at all during the school period. So same product, same results. After a year you can say "well at least you got your money's worth" and I guess you'd be right... But remember that the tablets started not being so good after about four or five months.... The low cost is what caught me last year $39.99 is a hell of a deal and it's and Amazon manufactured tablet... Give it here!! This year they cost $49.99 and I purchased again, yes I did two of them to be exact. In spite of the problems with the previous tablets so my bad... I guess I was hoping for improvement. Anyway, I'm not saying don't buy or it's the worst buy. But I am saying if you plan on long term use spend your money on another brand. (Sorry Amazon)
title: My Experience With Amazon's Fire Tablets

review_content: While this certainly looks and feels like every other fire ive ever owned (going back to the first generation of them)...the two biggest complaints about this one are the AWFUL battery life and the page turning ability.Battery life has to be perhaps half or even less of any previous generation kindle fire, i dont get it...maybe something is running in the background all day every day but even with casual reading i have to plug this in to charge far more often than any previous kindle fire ive ever owned.  very disappointing but not the end of the world. author: techishmom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2019
review_content: I can put my Fire 7 Tablet in my purse and never be bored again in long lines, waiting rooms or anywhere there is wifi. Most of my games can be played without wifi. I place it next to the bed at night to stream a show on the Fire 7 and it also wakes me up as my alarm clock in the morning either with the clock alarm settings or the built in Alexa feature I can ask to give me reminders for the day or ask about the weather or request a fav song. I use the calender for my events each week. I like the 16 GB memory upgrade from the old Fire 7 which had only 8GB and the memory expansion option is nice too. What did we do before we had these amazing devices? I would also recommend a protective case/stand. Many choices are sold here on Amazon and also a tempered glass screen protector is really good to have on it. Amazon has these tablets for affordable prices to serve customers well that are using it for their services so it pays to take the savings and protect it also with a protection plan.
title: Amazing, useful, fast and pretty!

author: buyzalot
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2019
review_content: So far I like this little tablet.  It was so affordable and seems to do everything my previous more expensive tablet did and then some.  I love the Kindle portion of the tablet.  I have a kindle so that I can read outside, but I much prefer this for indoors.  The light is just right for reading in bed.  The size of this tablet makes it easy to hold for long periods while I read or play solitaire or other games I easily downloaded.  I have added more than 80 free books and have started reading the first one... can't wait to get really into it.  That doesn't include the 26 I had previously.  Hopefully that will keep me busy for a while, since I am disabled and love to read.  I purchased this specifically to use on the plane when I fly from NY to Phoenix at the end of the month.  I will update then with how it did on battery life for the flight, as I can't really speak to that aspect of the tablet yet.  So far, so good.  Highly recommend right now.  Look for an update when I've had it a little longer!

author: K. Lovett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: I got this tablet in a prime day special, but had I paid full price I'd be very upset right now.I've had the tablet for less than 6 months, and battery life right now, fully charged, drains within 36 hours with no use and the cover on and closed. I use this as a 'for fun' device and primarily run 1-2 mobile games, that's about it. These game apps are closed when the battery leaches at an epic pace.Second MAJOR issue - even with the wifi off and volume off, it likes to randomly let me know verbally and loudly "I'm having trouble connecting to wifi". Again, when the device is not in use and the cover closed. I have to take extra care to make sure the tablet is not in my bag when attending performances or in class, as it can be quite disruptive. I've looked at the settings at length and cannot find a way to disable this VERY DISRUPTIVE feature.Finally, the lack of access to the play store is beyond asinine. There are numerous apps not available in amazon's store, or that are terribly out of date. If you want to make a competative android tablet, do not choke hold our android capabilities.At this point, I would not recommend at all that someone try one of these tablets.

author: Crystal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2019
review_content: Heads-up, these won't work well with Bose Soundwear speakers (the U-shaped ones that sit on your shoulder), presumably because the Bose Connect app is not available on the appstore. The only other app, Bose SoundTouch, is not what's needed. I did manage to get the Kindle Fire to connect to the Soundwear speakers (just kept hitting the button and hoped they found each other, which they eventually did), but the connection kept failing when the device was connected to wifi. If you can download your media to the Fire and then disconnect the wifi, then the Soundwear speakers stay connected to the Fire. Unfortunately, I rely on Alex for text-to-speech, so this is not acceptable. But if you're streaming to the Soundwear speakers, the Kindle Fire won't work because the devices won't stay connected. The device does connect well to my Bose Color Soundlink speaker, thus the 4 stars. I'll update my review if I can figure out how to fix this problem.

I had noticed that there were ads on the lock screen, but thought they were there, because I had downloaded her games. Nope, the ads only go away if you pay them $15. author: DENNIS T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020
review_content: For the price and what it can do, it really is a nice tablet. The resolution of the screen is good. Been watching  Disney+ and Netflix with this (bought a separate case with a stand) and every is fine. Sound quality is ok, the speaker could have been better located to the front of the tablet rather than the side. Best to use headphone port or bluetooth. I do take my tablet outside to read occasionally, but the brightness level does not go high enough to make the clarity required for reading outdoors. Camera quality isn't the best; the back camera seems to take better pictures/videos than the front camera even though they are supposedly the same megapixels and are 720hd capable. The processing speed is ok... The speed to surf the web is surprisingly slower than I expected but oddly enough watching Prime Video, YouTube, Hulu all run smoothly no lag. Video games unfortunately do have some lag and at times crashes. Overall this is a 4/5 stars despise quality is lacking in some areas but excels in what I love using this for: watching movies, TV shows, reading books, and shopping.

author: Glitchtastic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: It's not great but it does the job. I have not had issues with streaming or reading, however, most games crash within 20-30 minutes so I removed all of them. I have had a few times where the Books screen won't load at all and I have to tap "Library" in the upper right corner. I don't have apps running in the background and can't think of any other reason it would do it. I also don't use the silk browser because it's painfully slow and I can do it faster on my phone.Battery life is decent with reading and streaming and I have no immediate complaints. I didn't expect more than 3 hours when streaming and I get a bit more than that. However, when I close all apps and let my device sit, I feel like it drains quicker than it should.Overall, for the price, I won't complain, especially since I did a trade-in discount and had a credit. I would recommend more for child use or casual use but definitely not game-play.

author: Rachael Nelson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: These things are an insanely good deal!Okay, let’s be clear, this is no iPad but you can buy 10 of them for the price of a single iPad!  We bought several of these. We even leave a couple of them in the car so we always have entertainment handy for the kids. You have all the apps you need and adding an SD card, you can set it to act like regular internal storage. This means that even with apps like Netflix which allow you to download movies for off-WiFi usage, you can drop a huge SD card in this and download all your heart desires.We give them to the boys (ages 4 & 6) and there was a little bit of a learning curve from the iPad. The iPad all hinges around the home button and with this, like any other android, you have the three buttonless buttons that only appear when you have your finger on the bottom of the screen.  So I’m not sure if they could have navigated around like they used to if we have it to them when they were only 2 years old, when they first started using an iPad but they can now.The only thing I wish it had was a more traditional home screen launcher with juts apps. It would be nice to disable the additional tabs (such as “books”, “video”, etc) that you get when swiping from the main launch page.We bought the ones with ads on the home screen. They really aren’t that annoying so we haven’t been tempted to pay the $15 to remove them.

review_content: I really liked how the kindle organizes all the stuff in to different categories such as books and video, which makes it very convenient to find things. This tablet can be used to do just about anything one would use a tablet for and the battery life is good so far since it can last from a couple of hours to a whole day depending on how it is used. review_content: We had this tablet for three months before it just stopped charging. No reason, no damage. Just stopped. author: IfOnlyICouldReadAllDay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: This will not be a verified purchase because I received this tablet as a gift. I chose the plum color. It's unusual. I asked for the tablet because (i) it was on sale for $29.99 and (ii) I wanted a tablet mainly to read/listen to my ebooks. Before getting this tablet, I used the free Kindle app on my phone and it was perfectly fine, but there were times when I got annoyed because I would be reading and all sorts of notifications would interrupt me, from social media, phone calls, etc. Since I received this tablet a couple of weeks ago, I have only downloaded two additional apps: YouTube and a Sleep Timer. The Sleep Timer allows me to put the tablet to sleep while using the Text-to-Speech function to listen to ebooks.I have no complaints. I wanted a small tablet that could fit in my small bag. This fits the bill. It's not much bigger than my phone. I wanted a tablet to read ebooks on, so I didn't want it to be too big to hold in my hand (I have ligament problems and holding large things gets difficult). It works for that. I also LOVE that I can use Text-to-Speech to listen to books that don't have professional narration. That was a pleasant surprise, since my phone didn't have that function. I get to complete a lot more books now. I love audio books but many authors I enjoy don't have their books in audio format. This tablet is a great companion for my Kindle Unlimited subscription as I can read books, listen to Audible books (Read and Listen for Free with Kindle Unlimited) AND use the text-to-speech function for other books. If you're looking for a tablet to use for simple things, then this is a good purchase for you. It was a STEAL at $29.99 but I would pay up to $50 for this.
title: Great for reading eBooks!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: PlumStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Deborah England
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2020
review_content: Bought this for my senior mother who has difficulty adapting to new technology. She's enjoyed it for it's easy to use platform & durability. I had bought it for her Christmas present, but have it to her just after Thanksgiving because her eyesight was deteriorating & reading her puzzle books/paperbacks had become strenuous. It took her 3 weeks to feel confident using it, but within the 1st week she couldn't help volunteer her appreciation for the gift & how perfect it was for her situation. My only complaints are that there were only about 6 of the 20 preloaded apps that she would ever use (& they can't be uninstalled or disabled so they are cluttering her screen) as well as the availability of Libby by Overdrive app (6 yr old app) on Amazon apps. Libby is the only e-reader employed by our rural library. It took me days to struggle through the necessary hoops to load this onto her device & was an excruciatingly frustrating process. Amazon apps are designed to fit the needs mostly of families & senior citizens who are also most likely to use the library & the e-readers associated with those libraries. For seniors it's a point of accessibility (all e-books can be enlarged, available via the net instead of needing to rely on transportation to get one's books, audio books availability, broader selections available). To me it's a wasted opportunity by Amazon.
title: Easy for senior citizens to grow confident using

review_content: So for the price, it's fine.  In the end, I wish I just bought a real tablet for under $100 that has the ability to do what I'd really like so I can customize it.
