Again, I think it's Alexa and the other forced Amazon apps that one can't remove.I did watch a movie. That was fine.  I have yet to listen to music with it.I bought for $49.  Two weeks later the price dropped to $39.  The screen smudges ALOT. And often.  So $49...  plus a case to protect for $15... .. .disable the ads, $15... screen protectors to get rid of the smudging, another $9.  There goes a $100.
title: OK for the price. Meh. Good enough for reading.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: CynthiaB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: I am a professional writer and editor. I live my life on tablets and laptops. I'm also a voracious reader in my spare time and while I prefer the old fashioned books you hold in your hands, I have to admit that it is very convenient to put a Kindle in my purse and pull it out when I have to wait at the doctor's office, waiting to pick up a family member, or even in line at the DMV! I take out library books online and they load directly into my Kindle. So easy and convenient! I had my first Kindle Fire for 5 years and never had a moment's trouble with it until my 6-foot tall son stepped on it and broke the screen. I didn't waste any time buying another. I love the size of the Fire and my grandkids love to play games on it. They're too young to be allowed on my laptop I use for work so this is the perfect compromise. It's handy to put a cartoon on when my grandson is fussing in his car seat or my granddaughter wants to make a TikTok. The quality of the Fire is excellent. I got one with 8 GB of memory because I download a lot of apps between my grandkids and me. I have a ton of apps but still haven't run out of memory. If I do, I'll just buy a memory card. The picture is sharp and the sound is surprisingly loud. It's louder than my laptop that I had to buy a Bluetooth speaker for.  I go through laptops pretty fast using them so much for my job so when they crash my Kindle is great to watch my movies and shows in an emergency. Its battery life is about 4 hours. This new Kindle charges much faster than my original one too. The only negative thing I can say about this Kindle is there is a lag time when I touch something to open, about 10-15 seconds that my old one didn't have. When I turn it on and swipe the locked screen sometimes I have to swipe it 4 or 5 times before it opens. Those issues aren't a big deal but it's one of the little things that bug me. I use the Document app for making notes for work while I'm out and it's easily transferred to my laptop with the sharing option and syncing. I have not activated Alexa because I'm not really into that but it's a great feature to have if I ever want to use it. One thing I loved was I thought I'd lost all my pictures after my first Kindle was crushed but when I activated my new Kindle ALL my pictures from the previous 5 years, including pics of my newborn grandbabies, were all there and loaded into my new Kindle when I signed on. That was such a wonderful thing to discover! I'm really grateful for that. This price was $49.98 which is a steal for what you get and they last forever. Aside from being crushed when stepped on by a grown man, this device is extremely durable. My grandkids are 1 year, 2 years, and 7 years old and I allow them to carry it around and use it by themselves. They're constantly dropping it, stepping on it, and throwing it but it hasn't cracked or been damaged in any way. If it does it's easily replaceable at that price. Everyone should own a Kindle!
title: Love my 2nd Kindle
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: Twilight BlueStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Duane A. Priest
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2019
review_content: I bought this product before it was officially released to replace a Generation 1 Fire Tablet that I purchased several years ago.  The original is actually still in use; I keep it bedside to read books and play the occasional game when I can't sleep.This new version of the tablet is excellent.  The value for the money is significant.  The upgraded OS is compatible with so many different apps.  The display is crisp and clean, and the speed at which it processes commands is fast.  What I find most handy is that I can walk up to it, even when it's asleep, and issue an Alexa command and it will transmit it immediately.  The new version is much lighter and better constructed, and I love the new case.  If this one lasts as long as the original, I'll be quite happy!UPDATED 04/25/2020:  My first review didn't mention battery life... the battery life on this unit is questionable.  If you use it at all each day, you'll want to charge it every evening.  Even if you don't use it, the battery drains at an alarming rate.  I finally bit the bullet and paid the $15.00 plus tax to get rid of the ads, and I've found that actually helped to extend battery life somewhat.While Amazon has a wide variety of apps available for the Fire, unfortunately some of the apps and games I really wanted to use aren't available.  I did a bit of research online, and quickly learned that I could turn off one security settings, download and install 4 files, and then have full access to the Google Play store and all of it's apps.  The whole process took about 5 minutes, and the value it added to this device is phenomenal! This has become my go to device, replacing an aging iPad.  I can't believe how easy the process was, and I highly recommend it to anyone who needs access to more than the Fire store has to offer.  Be aware that this hack may invalidate or impact Amazon's warranty for the device, but for me, the ability to open the device to a realm of new functionality is well worth the risk.
title: Fast, capable, easy to read/use, Alexa capability,
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Francis Dirr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
review_content: These fire tablets I am buying are for my children, I am certain they are contributing to the problem but now I am on my 5 or 6th Fire tablet,  I was happy to see that the latest version ( and the one I purchased) has wireless charging because that has always been the issue.  The jack to plug in charger has ALWAYS failed over time, in about a year or so the charge jack has been abused to the point that they will no longer accept a charge.  On the latest purchase I spent the extra 40 bucks for the wireless charging jack and that should solve this issue.  I am rating three stars on this version or model because even though I am sure the responsibility of the jack failing is shared (my opinion) children just do not use the same care that I would when connecting to charge.  But it should be designed to withstand the abuse inflicted by 9 year olds!  I would recommend if your child is using spend the extra money and get a unit that can be wirelessly charged and get the charging dock.  Although I just realized that the wireless charging stations I already have work just fine....

author: Richard Osborne
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2020
review_content: I purchased this tablet to mainly be a replacement for an older Kindle reader. For that, it's great. Excellent screen, excellent functionality all around. I'm beginning to think, however, that I should have just gotten a regular Kindle reader instead of the Fire tablet.The battery life is terrible. I mostly read in bed at night during this pandemic lockdown, since for most of my waking hours I'm at my computer and don't need the Kindle. So my reading in bed before I go to sleep amounts to around 15-20 minutes each night. I end up needing to recharge the tablet every 2-3 days - after only 30-60 minutes of actual use. Despite the fact that I keep the WiFi and Bluetooth turned off except for when I need to download something, the battery continues to drain rapidly even when the device is not in use and the screen is turned off. I last charged it two days ago, then read for my usual 15-20 minutes that night. The following night (yesterday), I got into bed and prepared to read, only to discover that the battery was completely drained to the point that I couldn't even power the device on.My Fire tablet is the ad-supported version, so I suspect that whatever internal app handles the ads is still trying to download new ads even when WiFi is off, and draining the battery in the process.
title: Abysmal Battery Life

author: Tina Sue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
review_content: I've had my old Kindle Fire HDX (3rd generation) for many years now. I was excited to get my new Kindle Fire 7, but I've been mostly disappointed.  I expected to have to learn a new interface, but so many changes were made and not everything works, at least not on the one I got. It doesn't "predict" words I'm typing - it's set to do it, but they don't show up. Battery doesn't hold the charge as well as the old one. The touch screen isn't very sensitive at all- often Facebook videos don't play. Neither fingers nor stylus make them start, and I've noticed the same lack of screen sensitivity in other areas where it can take a number of tries to connect. The back of the unit is hard, slick plastic (vs. rubberized) that slides wherever you set it down. Mine has slid off surfaces twice and hit the floor. It IS narrower and easier to hold in the vertical position because even a woman's hand spans it really the only positive I can give it right now.  Often I get a screen that pops up saying the connection to Amazon has been lost and I need to reconnect. And in spite of clicking the "stay logged in" box, it requires me to key in my password over and over. Also, while this is the fault of the game developers, as I understand it anyway, none of my games transferred, so I'm starting at the beginning of each one. In this digital age, I find that unfathomable. Unfortunately my new Kindle was a gift so I'm stuck with it. I'm just continuing to use my old one for the most part.

author: Rich
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
review_content: I always wanted a tablet but just never knew what I could do with one considering my phone did the same thing. I was given the Amazon Fire 7 tablet as a gift and so far I do enjoy it. What I mean by that is you can only get apps from Amazon apps, which they really don't have much. If your an android user like myself, you won't find a lot of apps like you do on the Play Store. For example, I went to search for the Ebay app, it wasn't on there but I found PayPal. Same thing if you wanted the Target, Walmart, Best Buy etc, you won't find them. I had to search online to find a safe way (without hacking or tampering with the device) to install Google's Play Store. Once I got that installed, I could get all the apps I wanted. The battery life is also an issue, the battery seems to die a little fast but it does last throughout the day.Overall, I would say this is a great tablet or even if your starting out on your first tablet. author: Kelsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
review_content: I purchased this as Christmas gift of 2019 for my mother. I wanted to save money so I disconnected my cable but kept the internet. Of course, I have streaming apps and such. I knew my mother would lose her sanity & assist in making me lose mines because she wouldn't be able to watch news. LOL! So I surprised her with this and she has been glued to it ever since. She uses it for internet purposes, keeping in touch with family & friends via Whatsapp, browsing YouTube for music and hair tutorial, among other things. The setup was easy yet a bit complex. Why? She just wanted to get straight to using but it took a good 45 minutes to go through the setup process, downloading apps and connecting to the WiFi. I don't like the pre-downloaded apps, it seems you cannot delete to make space with the storage. Also, you cannot really personalize the home screen. The play store makes it somewhat difficult to find apps even when you search it directly. It took awhile to find the actual Whatsapp and download it. The screen size is smaller than I thought and the camera quality to be honest is horrible! If you understood the jokes between having an Android and an iPhone then you'd understand when I say the camera quality resembles an old school Android. LOL! Long story short, it's not for me. It was for her so as long as she enjoys it and can do whatever it's intended for then -- I'm good. Plus it helps my sanity.

author: good2Bking
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2019
review_content: Traded up to this 9th gen fire 7 from my 5th gen fire 7. Some challenges with initial set up. It corrupted the SD card from my 5th gen, so I had to get a new SD card. Minus one star.  Lost all of my Amazon underground apps... Minus one additional star. Also, it appears Lookout mobile security and antivirus app for Kindle is no longer available. Disappointing.  Battery life not bad but not quite as good as the 5th gen. Perhaps because of the more robust processor in the 9th gen.  So, after these few hiccups, all appears to be working well at this point. Will update/edit review as I discover more pros/cons. Right now I am satisfied. All in all you can't beat it for the $16 it cost me to upgrade during cyber week pricing. Still a big Amazon device fan.12/27/19 edit: Very dissatisfied with battery life. Tablet sat for the last two days untouched. Is down to 81% from a full charge. My 5th gen Fire 7 would've still been in the nineties. This 9th gen Fire 7 discharges at a more rapid rate of 5% or more per day than the old one. Starting to regret my trade in. Minus one more star.12/29/19 Update: Charged up my new Fire HD 10 yesterday and compared it against my new Fire 7... both charged to 100% and each untouched for 18 hours. Results: Fire HD 10 is at 98% and Fire 7 is at 86%.  Standby battery life on my new 9th gen Fire 7 is HORRIBLE. Battery in my traded in 5th gen Fire 7 would've been in the high 90's after 18 hours standby like the HD 10. Very dissatisfied with the battery in this new 9th gen Fire 7. This one will crap out sooner than later. author: Daniel Mills
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: Overall, you can tell that these tablets are cheap and have low quality assurance. Their reliability is low, they're very glitchy, and we simply aren't impressed.We bought two of these tablets on sale for our kids for a road trip. We basically just needed them for watching movies and shows on Disney+. All that we downloaded on each tablet was Disney+ and 2 or 3 small toddler games. Then, we attempted downloading a few movies/TV shows in the Disney+ app on each tablet. This very small amount of storage use on the tablets has simply wrecked their usability. They are wildly inconsistent in connecting to the internet and bluetooth, and sometimes they flat out won't work. I'll turn it on or restart it, open Disney+ and it'll just sit there for minutes trying to load. I'll come back to it a few minutes later and it's logged off. I'll set up a movie download and it'll just close the app. I'll click on an app 8 times and it won't open, so I'll open another one, and then literally several minutes later it will open the original app that I wanted and crash the whole system. It'll connect to bluetooth one day and not the next. One tablet will load and play a show just fine and then the other will simply decide not to work that day--then they'll switch places the next time we use them. We've only used them for maybe a total of 30 hrs of playtime and they're sluggish as if we've had them for years. We even tried factory resetting them (even though they hardly had anything on them), and they still didn't work well. Again, we haven't bogged them down with 50 apps, and they're practically brand new.I know they were cheap, but I think these tablets were only worth about $10, not the $30 we paid for them on sale, and certainly not the $50 they are normally. If you want something that you can count on even remotely, this is not the tablet. The inconsistency and unreliability shocks me. We are not impressed and will be returning them.
title: Very Cheap
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Raul Tavarez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2020
review_content: Compré esta tablet como una prueba para ver cómo funciona el financiamiento de Amazon en que puede comprar un artículo y pagarlos hasta en 5 cuotas. La tablet no está mal, pero por su precio, 50 dólares, carece de ciertas cosas que podemos echar de menos. Por ejemplo, si pantalla, se ve algo opaca cuando vemos videos y no goza de muy buena calidad y por otro lado, aunque usa android está limitada a la appstore de Amazon a la que les falta muchas aplicaciones que hay en la Play Store de Google y si queremos instalar esas apps debemos recurrir a apps de tercero para descargarlas exponiendonos a virus y demás cosas y no siempre las apps funcionan luego de haberlas instalado.Sin embargo, por su precio, no podemos pedir mucho, está muy bien adaptada para el ecosistema de Amazon y funciona decentemente. Otro aspecto negativo, es que cuenta con Alexa, pero no funciona en español.
title: Precio justo pero con algunas carencias

author: EF
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2019
review_content: This is the reason the Fire 7 (2019) is a must upgrade-- it runs a currently supported version of Android. This issue isn't as trivial as it may seem.The older 2017 (7th Generation) Fire 7 is based on Android 5.1.1The new 2019 (9th Generation) Fire 7 is based on Android 7.1The 2017 tablet will not receive a newer OS. So this distinction is important if you want to run apps other than those that are pre-installed. Many apps simply will not be available for the older version of Android.Other than that it is much faster.I ran benchmarks that were compatible with both Fire 7s. However, it is difficult to assess the true strength of the new Fire 7 (2019) since the old Fire 7 (2017) could not run current benchmarks due to its old OS.On Geekbench 4, the new 2019 tablet puts up a 46% better score.On PassMark, the new 2019 tablet scores more than twice the CPU numbers.The new fire tablet also render images more than 50% faster than the old tablet. This means it draws, moves, scales, and rotates images faster. Consequently, this translates to faster UI performance and a smoother less laggy experience.Amazon has also bumped up the storage from 8 to 16GB and from 16GB to 32GB. Which means more space for apps and photos. Write speeds on the new tablet have improved significantly to 82% faster; while reads have decreased 35%.Unfortunately, memory has remained at 1GB. This does not present a major issue as the tablet cannot effectively run more than one resource intensive app at a time. But this may make using the tablet more tedious since it will be up the user to preemptively close open apps and wait for background tasks to complete before launching more apps. The upside is memory performance is more than twice as fast as the outgoing tablet.The few other improvements have made its way into the new tablet such as raising the MicroSD card limit from 256GB to 512GB and updating the front (selfie) cam to a more respectable 2MP from 0.7MPAnyone looking for a Bluetooth improvement will be disappointed as it has remained at 4.1LE. There is no Bluetooth 5 support.----- Details -----fire 7 (7th generation)- 34s start up- Android 5.1.1 (32bit)- ARM A7 CPU (32bit) = Benchmark == Geekbench 4 - 446/1202 == PassMark - System 2657, CPU 10167, Disk 9466, Memory 2025- Mali 450 MP4 CPU = Benchmark == PassMark - 2D 2364, 3D 817- 2D Graphics - Image rendering: 2773- Memory Speed - 1098 MBs / 273 MBs R/W- Disk Speed - 143 MBs / 60 MBs R/W- Completely outdated platform. Below minimum requirements for many apps.- 8GB or 16GB Storage- Supports up to 256GB MicroSD- Bluetooth 4.1LEca- Silver colored buttons- Speaker located right backside of casefire 7 (9th generation)- 28.5s start up- Android 7.1 (32bit)- ARM A53 CPU (64bit) = Benchmark == Geekbench 4 - 641/1775 (Slower than iPad 4 single / faster than multi) - on avg 46% faster than gen 7 == PassMark - System 3196, CPU 20793, Disk 11079, Memory 3756- Mali T720 MP2 GPU = Benchmark == PassMark - 2D 2542, 3D 824 (FPS capped - cannot compare true speed)- 2D Graphics - Image rendering: 4204- Memory Speed - 2006 MBs / 514 MBs R/W (~85% faster memory performance)- Disk Speed - 106 MBs / 109 MBs R/W - (35% slower read / 82% faster writes)- Meets minimum OS requirements for many current apps- No more 8GB Storage. Only 16GB and 32GB- Supports up to 512GB MicroSD- Front camera is now 2MP- Still Bluetooth 4.1LE (no BT 5)- Color matching buttons (with body)- Speaker located left side (bezel) of case
title: A must upgrade if you have an older Fire 7
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Michael Matney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2020
review_content: I'm use to having the Fire Tablet 8HD. I got this one through our insurance company to use for a fitness/wellness program they offer. The tablet works find and looks great. I really don't use this one for anything other than what it was intended for. I'm use to having a larger screen, and use my 8HD for my Kindle reading and game playing. Plus I have vision problems, so the bigger the better. My husband on the other hand got one with his fitness/wellness program also and loves it. He's been using his the way I use my 8HD and is very pleased with it. The battery life seems to be doing good so far, for me anyway. I run my 8 down pretty quickly playing games and readying for hrs sometimes, but the battery life in it I think does well also. It's a great little tablet if you don't mind the smaller screen, works well, everything functions well, just like on my 8. So I'm pleased with it, and I have a backup in case some does happen to my 8!

author: Clady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2019
review_content: This tablet brings me back to the old days of the initial pc/internet. I can remember just sitting there waiting for it do something.......that's how slow it is. 1990 days. It in also unreliable I will press on an app icon and it just either goes back to the home screen or pops up with something unrelated to what I press. You can't customize your home screen other than to move the icons around.  The only thing I have patience to do with it is read a book but even that is frustrating. Don't think it would be great for kids because it is too locked up to be practical. It is a good study tablet that is very attractive options for colors but was ackward to hold without the case I had to purchase separately. The pictures give you the impression it comes with a case but in the body of the description it does say not included. There are other things that are frustrating which have been covered by other reviewers so I have not listed it all. It is more like an Amazon remote control than a tablet. Mostly likely will return unless I can find a way to speed it up.

author: Kathy B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2019
review_content: I thought an upgrade didn't mean a decrease in functionality. The reduced battery life is really annoying. It does charge faster than my prior Kindle, but the shorter battery life causes me to re-charge more frequently during the day. A faster charge is nice, but doesn't make up for the inconvenience of the lousy battery life. You would think  that with advances in technology, particularly in batteries, a new Kindle would at least be able to maintain prior version functionality. The other features are just as good as my prior Kindle so I'm happy with that, but next time I upgrade I doubt it will be another Kindle. Btw, I refuse to use Alexa due to data privacy issues.

author: Charles Feldman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: Hi, Two things that stood out about the Fire Tablet, are that 1) You have to be careful to enter a pin number or password to be able to access the Fire Tablet (which you can do by swiping down to start) because once you sign in with the email address that you used to register the device, it is impossible to sign out. So before I protected access to the device, anyone who was able to pick it up would be able to access my email. 2) I had to call Amazon support (which is easy to do, as they respond quickly) to figure out how to read my Amazon books on this device. On my computer, when I go to Amazon Content and Devices, it gives me the option to click on Read to read a book. But on the Fire Tablet, you have to download the book before you can read it. I have no idea how much space on the Fire Tablet each book would take up, because I have gone back to reading the books on my computer now that I have it back. For Zoom meetings, the tablet is fine, but I just needed it temporarily, and now that I have my computer back, I am just keeping the Fire Tablet for an emergency.
title: Difficult to Read Amazon Books on Kindle

author: A Hart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
review_content: I wanted to love this little guy but I was left disappointed instead.  I bought it to replace a Fire 8 tablet I purchased in Jan 2018, my screen cracked on that one a year after I bought it after I put it in my work bag with a metal water bottle.  I read the reviews on the current Fire 8 model and found an overwhelming number of them recommending the Fire 7 over the 8 because of lagging issues with the 8.  Although the Fire 7 is faster than the 8 the quality of the glass screen leaves something to be desired.  Last night I left my phone charging slightly overlapping my Fire 7 on my bed and my screen on the Fire 7 developed a long crack across the entire screen after my car (who's not overweight, only about 15lbs and very tall and long) decided he was going to lay on my devices for a bit.I have a very old Kindle fire that I won in a contest in 2014 that I have carried around with me, dropped on cement and tile, rolled over on while sleeping, sat on, and have placed in my work bag with different type of bottles (glass, metal, plastic) and I have not had any issues with the screen cracking or breaking.  The newer Kindles are not made with the same quality as the older ones were.  Next time I'll probably just invest in an IPad.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2019
review_content: We have purchased several Kindle Fires.  They work mostly great with two big complaints:  (1) downloaded content becomes unavailable once you reconnect to wifi (which means unhappy kiddos with no movies available to view on a long car ride--only fix seems to be not connecting to wifi once you have downloaded content) and (2) eventually the charger port will stop working.  We have purchased six or seven kindle fires over the years and on every single one, the port where you plug in the charger becomes loose and the device will stop charging.  Fortunately there are enough deals throughout the year you can replace fairly inexpensively.  One minor complaint is that it's often hard for the kids to locate downloaded content because it displays all purchased content.  Downloaded movies used to have a checkmark on them, but on newer/updated deices that no longer appears.
title: Great Tablet Until the Charger Port Stops Working

author: Michelle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: Other reviewers seem to have gotten devices that worked just fine, but for me, using this tablet (TWO of them in fact) was an extremely frustrating experience. Within a few weeks of getting my first Fire 7, I started having issues with my book library crashing on me whenever I tried to scroll through it and/or read any book other than the  the most recently purchased one. I called support and they walked me through a factory reset as well as some other solutions, and all seemed well for a few days. Then the problem started again. I called support again and they sent me a replacement refurbished Fire 7. From the moment I tried to set that one up I knew it was yet another faulty device. It took forever to register, as it kept starting itself over halfway through the process and kept saying it needed to be connected to a WiFi network while also saying it was already connected to my home WiFi. Once I finally got it registered I opened to my book library and Lo and behold, the same crashing issue started within a few days. Keep in mind it’s not like I was overwhelming the device’s processing or memory capabilities by having multiple apps open at once. Occasionally I would watch Netflix but rarely. Other than that, I used it solely to read. There was no gaming, no apps of any other kind were ever open or even downloaded. I called support again and they recommended the same troubleshooting processes, which yielded the same results (not a permanent fix before the issue would start all over again). They even did a diagnostic on it and emailed back saying the problem was I had too many apps open in the background, to which I responded I never use any apps other than my book library, so how it that possible?? By the time I finally got around to saying forget it, just give me my money back, it was too late because I’d bought the device from a third party retailer (Best Buy) and my warranty had expired. Now I’m out $40.00 and stuck with a kindle that crashes when I so much as blink at it. I don’t know if these bugs are in this generation or not but I’m hesitant now to buy another fire kindle at all. I think I’ll just keep using the kindle app on my iPhone and call it a day.
title: Just my bad luck??

author: SilverWings
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2020
review_content: I think sometimes when I tell people we have Kindles, they still only think of them as being solely for downloadable books. Music, internet browsing, email, games, social media, etc.This is the second one I bought for my son. He had a much older one that was reaching the end of it's days. He got a lot of use out of it, and there was a great sale price on this at the time so we jumped on it. You definitely get all your money's worth and then some, that is, if you are someone who takes care of their stuff. I can't speak for those who might drop them on the ground or into water :)  But with regular wear and tear, they seem to hold up pretty nicely.Amazon does have it's own shop and app versions but it's fairly easy to find info on the net to sideload the Google app if you prefer to use Google Play and have access to their games. I think if I can do it, most people probably could and for those who can't, they can find someone to help them I'm sure.

author: MushaAleste
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2020
review_content: I decided to take the plunge and buy one of these Fire 7 tablets. It’s a powerful processor for this price point. 50 bucks is a great deal. I think at certain times of the year you can get them much cheaper. Keep an eye out for deals.  You can load google play store quite easily. It requires you download 4 separate files. It’s a very quick process. It took me like 5 minutes after initial setup. I ended up reenabling security settings afterwards. Everything works.  I proceeded to download my go to free streaming services like Tubi for awesome crappy horror movies. Video quality and sound is great.  The main attraction of this little beast is a portable retro emulation station. I installed retroarch and tested out the classics such as NES, SNES, Genesis, and Gameboy Advance. They run flawlessly. Get one of these little powerhouses. I’d suggest getting an OTG cable and a cheap controller too. I’m not a fan of using virtual controls unless it’s just an jrpg.

author: Twix
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: I got my Amazon Fire tablet for Christmas. It's great so far. I had pretty low expectations about my tablet. I thought it wasn't going to be a good tablet because of the lack of the Google apps. The Play store and all, but it has some pretty good apps. It doesn't have the official YouTube app, but it has third party YouTube apps. The one I'm using is called HD Tubes For YouTube. It's a great app that functions like a  desktop. It plays really well and it has all the functions the app doesn't have. I own a Microsoft Phone and the apps for it are terrible. Facebook, messenger, Instagram, YouTube. All are just sad third party apps, but the Amazon app store surpassed my expectations. It's not as good as Google Play Store, but it's high up there with them.The battery life is great. There's some apps that does run it down quicker, but when I'm not on those apps. The battery life lasts a lot longer. That happens on most if not all tablets and touch screen phones.The Screen quality is very vibrant and colorful. You can reduce the blue light which can distract you from sleeping. I like how you can do that.The touch screen is very responsive. I have no problems with it at all so far. I'm hoping that I have many great years with my Amazon Fire 7 (9 Gen) tablet.

author: Linda B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
review_content: First, I want to say I usually don’t behave like an angry keyboard warrior. However, I want to give people a heads up about the Amazon fire tablet 7. I preordered this. Got it brand new back in June this year. Great price, the case was more expensive than the tablet...  I purchased this solely for the purpose of using amazon coins for in-app (game) purchases. This device...ITS SO SLOW. I wasn’t even able to finish setting up basic things (e.g., Alexa, etc.) because it would be stuck in loading and time out after 45 minutes of waiting. No matter the strength of my WiFi connection, cannot even search anything in the web browser. It takes so long to open an app or do anything. I can’t imagine relying on this thing for anything other what I bought it for. It’s ridiculous.  If you are looking to buy a multifunctional tablet that won’t increase your blood pressure- look elsewhere. (Buy an ipad—if you’re anti-apple then try something else. Just not this.) You’ll thank me later. If you plan to use it for 5 minutes at a time to make in game purchases with coins. This is for you.  Side note: the case. I think I was able to make it stand the device up 2 times the first day I got it. Since then I’m at 0:25.  Lastly, I’m not going to blame the device but I cracked the screen somehow...with the case on.. (cough cough) and was going to try to take advantage of the trade in to replace it so I can keep making in-app purchases. Brand new fire 7 they offer 10$ (reasonable).  However, trade in is only available for the limited edition tangerine color. This thing is brand new (minus the screen damage) but you would think they would accept trade ins for their new gen products. Something else for tablet shoppers to consider as well. And I wasn’t stupid enough to buy the device protection they offer - not sure if they cover cracked screens, but I don’t see a service for fixing it. And I’m pretty sure (Dont quote me I didn’t put in much effort looking into this) if you buy a screen repair kit and you tube it, you’ll probably void some manufacturer warranty. And won’t be able to trade it in the future (if they ever accept them) To buy another is only $30-40 now. They’re essentially disposable. Like toilet paper. Not to sound cliche but here it is anyway: You get what you pay for.Final comment: every dollar counts. Don’t waste it on this. Invest in something you won’t consider throwing into a busy street every time you pick it up and use it.
title: My flip phone was faster...You get what you pay for.

author: J. Aller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2019
review_content: Back in the day the Amazon 7 tablets were a bit too slow and under powered but the 2019 model is more than adequate for daily use by adults and of course kids. The new Fire OS is based on Android 7 and makes a world of difference too. It's a perfect size to travel with on a daily basis. Videos look better than anticipated. Silk browser is decently fast and have not experienced any delays and or quirks. If you are on a budget or are looking for a secondary tablet that will never break the bank, buy this! For those who are crying that there is no google play, you can add it to this tablet or use some other app store to get the handful of apps you need, its not hard! Also if the ad on opening screen bothers you kick down the $15 and you should sleep better for it. Battery life may be the only item that I can complain about but its not that bad considering its a sub $50 tablet.

author: Pamelicious
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2019
review_content: Caution: Layman's review ahead.I got tired of remembering to bring my Fire to work to listen to podcasts, etc., so when the 7 went on sale on Black Friday, I decided to get it so i could just keep it at work.It set up quickly - no problems there. But man, this thing goes through battery power so quickly! Way faster than my 4 year old Fire 8!The smaller screen doesn't bother me a whole lot - I find the smaller size easier to store at my desk. But yeah, of course a bigger screen is much nicer! I don't need it just for podcasts, though, or music - so no biggie at work.The 3 rating boils down to two issues I have with it: the fast battery drainage and the charging cord. Unlike my old Fire 8, the charging cord feels as if I have to force it in - and I don't want to! It doesn't go into the slot easily, and I'm afraid that in jiggling it around to make it fit, that I'll break something.Other than that, I'm happy to have an alternative at work so I don't risk leaving my trusty Fire 8 at work overnight!

review_content: This is the only thing I ever bought from Amazon that I was sorry about. I bought one for myself a few years ago because I didn’t want to spend iPad money. author: Professor Gains
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2019
review_content: I'm gonna start the review by saying this. If you want a tablet for taking pictures and editing photos for Instagram or if you want a tablet to play fortnight, This tablet isn't for you. This tablet is better for a non power user who want more than tablet or wants a a tablet for reading books and watching videos. I looked everywhere so far I haven't seen many tablets with this much of a solid buid for $50. The software is pretty optimized im surprised how good Fire OS runs on limited hardware. The screen is good for content consumtion. The parental controls are solid. There are some issues though. For starters the display has no form of Oil Phobic coating at all. This coating has been available since the iPhone 4 so when the smudges come they come. Personally I would have sacrificed the rear mediocre camera for this coating but due too Amazon's camera integration with the app it's pretty much a nessesity. The camera has the same quality as a Nintendo 3ds. The unit of measure for this camera might as well be called killo pixels. This is a solid detox tablet. It's great for kids. The sage finish is lovely and I'm enjoying the tablet for $50 you can't complain. If you want top of the line specs on a tablet either buy a surface book or an iPad pro. I'm gonna keep flexing this baby at the community college for $49.99!. The ladies won't resist such a good bargan.
title: Great tablet for a great price.

author: Bobbie.L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: It has a decent screen, mediocre CPU processing capabilities. It's nice that it's based on Amazon's own operating system instead of Google Android or Apple IOS, and has Kindle capabilities built into it. As such, it took me a little longer to figure out the device with a "foreign" OS, but I got used to it pretty quickly.I don't use it to watch movies or shows, only clips when necessary (I HATE STREAMING because it slows down the InterNet, because the Key InterNet nexus hubs controlled by the big networking companies are too cheap to upgrade the switches and routers to handle all the traffic!). Tablets are basically big-screeened Smart Phones that don't make phone calls, so I use mine accordingly- to read Kindle books, surf via WiFi, some music, etcetera. Amazon claims it has a quad-core processor, but it's still a tad slow (1.3GHz) and freezes occasionally, so maybe it's the mere 1GB of RAM...BlueTooth-capable;WiFi-Capable (802.11n);Memory: 1GB RAM, 16GB internal Storage, Expandable External Storage up to ½TB (micro-SD);Non-Flash Front and Rear camera, 2 Mega-Pixel (max);Non-HD TouchScreen (good enough for MY tired old eyes)There's also a mini-phone jack for headphones. I wouldn't give its music abilities a shout-out, but it's fine to play 128-bit (sampling) music files while on-the-go. My laptop's sound processor via BlueTooth to my home audio system sounds a LOT better, but the music is still acceptable through the tablet for most non-musicians.
title: Nice Tablet. Nothing Spectacular, But It's A Great Deal When It's Priced Under $80.00...
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Ranger Princess
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2019
review_content: I’ve owned this tablet for almost two months now (I didn’t buy it directly from amazon, but through Best Buy because of the great back to school sale price lol as if the price point wasn’t good enough!) and it has been amazing! I have used this tablet daily for just about everything: surfing the web, listening to music, watching videos, gaming... It is so useful and has become a staple in my day to day activities. I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this tablet, I was expecting it to be pretty cheap at only about $50 but since I mainly wanted it for simple daily tasks I didn’t want to spend a fortune on it. And this fit what I needed perfectly! Better than I was expecting. The screen is great everything looks clear and bright, although the glass is very reflective and leaves finger prints but it was easily fixed with a matte anti glare/anti fingerprint screen protector. The audio is also very good and clear. It runs surprisingly fast, I was expecting it to be a bit slow and laggy when surfing the net or especially when gaming such as Minecraft etc. but I haven’t had a problem with speed. It’s very responsive, honestly it’s as fast as my iPhone. The colors are a big bonus. I love the unique selection, I got the sage green and it’s beautiful! Exactly as pictured. It was actually one of the main selling points that made me decide to try this tablet was because of the visual appeal, it’s nice to have a nice classy pop of color rather than a stereotypical gray or black device. I would love to see a blush pink color option added in the future but that’s just wishful thinking. It’s a good size too, easy to carry in my bag on the go, but still big enough to game and watch videos comfortably. It’s about the size of your average paperback book just slightly narrower. I also like that you can have multiple sign on accounts and kid accounts. The restrictions and curfew settings are pretty great and would make a great family device, or for those like me who like to keep themselves accountable. I also like that you can increase the existing internal storage with a micro SD card.Now as for cons, I don’t have any big ones, at least they are not deal breakers. My only complaints are these 4 things:1.the battery does charge slowly, (the only reason I gave 4 stars for the battery) it usually takes a couple hours to charge, but it’s not too much of a hinderance. The battery life is pretty good, it lasts a while and I always get a few solid hours use before the battery starts getting low.2. The tablet starts to get hot after extended use. Since it has a plastic backing it gets a wee bit hot to the touch especially if it’s in a case, but again it’s not that big of a deal and it does cool down fast once I turn it off.3. More of a wish than a con but I wish it was procreate/photoshop compatible and that procreate or photoshop were available in the AppStore not just knockoffs. As an artist myself I would love to be able to do digital art on this, or if Amazon came out with a tablet and pencil specifically for art I would totally be down. I would prefer not to spend $1000+ on the iPad Pro just for my art.4. Again another wish rather than an actual con but I wish the newly released Call of Duty Mobile app was available in the Amazon AppStore. Actually I really wish they had more of a selection of apps, there’s precious little, if any, of the actual big name games and apps available, most of them are just knock offs.Over all I love my Fire 7 it’s a great tablet, can’t beat the quality for price point.
title: Possibly the best $50 I’ve spent on myself so far
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Book Buddies
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2020
review_content: I'm a very visual person and I read ... a lot.This is my 4th kindle product and I had the very first generation kindle.What I love the most about the Fire is the tablet aspect.  Like I said I had the very first generation of kindle with the black and white screen with only a list to see your books, and recently I purchased the Oasis too, because I wanted something lighter and smaller for travel.  However, only months after purchasing the Oasis, I've gone back and purchase the Fire tablet, for the same and different reasons.  The same is it's smaller and lighter for travel, but the different is the visual.While the Oasis fulfilled my need for smaller and lighter, I was so unhappy with the visual...no color and I love my book covers in all their glorious color.Is the Kindle Fire the very best product on the market....I don't know, it depends on your needs....this one meets mine.

author: Eliza

review_content: So far, I love this thing for the price. Obviously, with a price tag like the one it has, it’s going to be pretty basic. There are about 20 pre-loaded apps that you cannot delete, even if you don’t plan on using them.2. It seems like the WiFi connection is always less than stellar, even when my other devices have great connections.3. Can be sluggish and slow to respond at times, but not hugely noticeable.4. Very basic screen and picture quality.5. Due to the mono speaker, I don’t recommend using this without headphones.6. Because it is an Amazon-altered Android system, there are certain apps that you are unable to download, unlike a typical Android system.The good:1. The price! There’s a lot of bang for your buck here.2. I love the size, quite a bit bigger than a phone, but not huge. Perfect for travel.3. Great for watching media, reading, listening to music, and playing games on the go.Overall, I’m happy with this purchase!

author: Michael R. Bradley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: Unless you live and breath Amazon, you're better off with an Android tablet or even an iPad. This was a gift. I mention this because I wouldn't spend this much for a product that is so limited. And with all the Amazon advertising it throws at you, it really should be cheaper. Since it runs on a modified version of Android you can only get your apps from the Amazon store. I would recommend it for novice users, but for the same price you can get more product with an Android tablet. It has a nice display, it connects easily to your wi-fi and gives you a nice internet experience. The down side is the poor battery life. I was able to side-load Google Play store so I could get the apps I wanted, and with special software I was able to get rid of most of the Amazon "special offers", but I don't find myself using it much. As I say, spend your cash on an Android tablet, or an iPad.

author: Eva Sawyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: So it has been a while since I had a Kindle Fire, but recently my ipad had to go in for service and I wanted to be able to still read. I had a gift card so I only had to pay about $20 out of pocket, so this seemed like a great low budget item for me.  And boy, was I right! I remember what I disliked so much about the Kindle Fire in the first place - it is just so bogged down that it is almost unuseable. There are apps that come with the tablet that you can't delete, and between those and the operating system, 80-90% of the tablet's storage is already gone. Then add in the fact that the tablet is so unresponsive and I am glad that I got rid of it. It shouldn't take minutes to open the Kindle app, choose a book and have it load, especially when it is already downloaded... that should happen in seconds. Overall just a frustrating experience.

author: Jesse Conti
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
review_content: So when my old Fire tablet finally died after 5 years, I ordered the NEW Fire 7 tablet.  The charger that's included didn't work at all and yes, I tried it in many outlets.  The charging dock, that is the usb port is also defective.  It seems to have a loose connection that causes intermittent charging, which results in a constant dinging.  Finally the wifi.  It says it has an "excellent" wifi connection in the settings, but it often takes an hour or more before it even begins to download a new book.  I don't think that's a server issue because it never happened on my old Fire tablet. It simply ignores the download request sometimes for several hours, and no, restarting the download doesn't help at all, neither does powering it off.  I'll send this in for exchange today and hope the replacement will be better, though I'm not optimistic.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: Specifically asked before purchasing if it could be used for USB OTG and charge at the same time via a "Y" OTG adapter cable. Was told "I don't know" (why bother answering?) and then "Yes" (which is WRONG). It will NOT do OTG and Charge. You can do OTG. You can Charge. You can NOT do both at once.Why still give it 4 stars? Because for $50, it's a heck of a deal. Note that it is COVERED with advertisements, but for $15 extra you can get rid of those after you get sick of seeing them. Battery life isn't fantastic, but then I did have an OTG device connected so that probably drained it a bit faster.P.S. author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
review_content: Good for the price. Has lasted longer than I expected, but you can never tell for sure with mass-produced tech, so it's good that this is _so_ cheap, and that Amazon is good with returns.The e-reader app is OK. If this is mainly for reading and the other tablet stuff is just convenient to you, then the reading experience on one of Amazon's e-ink devices is better by far.Handles streaming video well. Most websites work fine with the default browser. Reddit is the only big website I've browsed on Kindle that deliberately frustrates the mobile browser (seemingly to encourage you to use their app, which does not exist for Kindle). Battery life in my experience is about 6 hrs on Wi-Fi as long as i keep Alexa off. If Alexa is on it drains very quickly!The keyboard overcorrects everything. That's terrible for writing if you post things online, and there's no way to help it: no options to disable autocorrect, and no alternative software keyboards. Creative/technical writing or programming would be almost impossible if you're one of the unlikely people who does those things on a tablet.Does not have the same app store as Android. You can't expect common apps to be available. Check before you expect it. Thankfully Amazon has a good suite of entertainment options of their own, and all of the main streaming services and social networks are available on Kindle.

author: Frank R. Scaglione
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: I originally bought one last year and it was great. I liked having 32GB. Unfortunately a couple of weeks ago, it updated on its own overnight and started acting weird. It kept on freezing, even after rebooting. My wall paper for the screen wouldn't stay. It kept on reverting to factory every couple of hours or every time I would power down and re boot. I called Amazon and they said it was a problem with the Kindle and wasn't covered under warranty anymore. I reluctantly bought a new one. The new one came with the new update from the factory. It worked great on the first day. On the second, it started working weird like the first one. Freezing. Not holding my wallpaper settings. It won't play YouTube from my Facebook app. It did at first, but then recently stopped. My first one of this generation is practically v dead in the water and this one is going after a couple of weeks. My daughter has a 9th generation, and it started freezing constantly after recent updates. We replaced it with a new one which has the current system updates. It freezes constantly and acts weird, and we constantly have to re boot it as well. I'm convinced that the current system updates are at fault and Amazon needs to address these issues. author: Ca13b_R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
review_content: This product is hardly worth $50, get it on a deal. All games are far too laggy to play. This tablet struggles to run candy crush with graphics set to Ultra Low. No google store, so no YouTube or HBO Max. I had to go through a loophole to get the google store. The battery life is not 7 hours. It is only 4-5 unless you set the brightness to so low it’s not even usable. The brightness is awful and on full it’s still too dim outside. Touching things like the keyboard are not only late response, but also a typo every other word is that laggy and poor at sensing where your finger is touching. This tablet is not user friendly all. In fact you shouldn’t even get this as a gift for anyone. Even the Amazon Store is so laggy it’s too hard to buy stuff😂. The camera is unusablely bad. It’s so user unfriendly that should absolutely not give to an old person or young adult. It’s barely good for kids. The only 2 uses I get out of this tablet is streaming Apps like D+, Hulu, Netflix, etc. and books. It’s good for people who travel on boats, buses, trains, airplanes, etc. and not much of a loss if it breaks. I don’t know how the people who make this tablet can look at it and be proud to sell it, even if it’s $50 or sometimes cheaper. Also, the Alexa is less responsive than an actual alexa.
title: Price IS too good to be true.

author: Nancy K. Farlow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: I love my new Kindle Fire 7. It has way more features than my older model that died, for about a third the price. It has a fast response time, a camera, and good screen display quality, although the latter two don’t matter a lot to me. I use it mostly for listening to recorded books while driving. I discovered that this new Kindle Fire 7 has a microSD slot, and I just happened to have an old 32 GB microSD card lying around, so I popped it in and, bingo, I can download a lot more recorded books! I was always deleting some books to make space for others on my old Kindle Fire, but now I don’t have to do that. The speaker is not loud enough to hear if you’re more than a few feet from the device, although it doesn’t matter to me when I’m driving because I use Bluetooth to play it through my vehicle’s speakers. But if you need room-quality sound you’ll want external speakers.

author: Kenny S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2019
review_content: I won an 8" Fire HD in a raffle a couple years ago, and while I never had any desire to own a tablet, it quickly became my go-to for watching videos on YouTube and Amazon Prime. I could pair it with my bluetooth earpiece and carry it around the house or watch Top Gear while I did the dishes. It was great... until I dropped it and shattered the screen. (For anyone thinking, "Well, just replace the screen!" - I tried. Waste of time, money, and effort.)Since I had gotten it for free, and it wasn't really an essential item, I didn't feel good spending $80+ on a new one. $50, however, seemed reasonable, and I was willing to trade 1" for $30.I wish I hadn't.Between the small, 7" size, and the single speaker, this isn't much better to watch videos on than my phone. Because videos are the ONLY thing I use my Fire for (I have a PC or phone for everything else), this kind of makes the Fire 7... pointless.Bottom-line:If you use tablets for multiple tasks, like e-mail, videos, reading, games, etc., but don't have the cash for a larger one, this is the way to go. If, like me, you primarily use your tablet for videos/music... it's not worth it. Just shell out for the Fire 8 with dual speakers.

Also he sees other games he wants to play on there, but the small hard drive space doesn't allow more than 5 games at a time, having to uninstall a game to put a new one on there, so we will be forced to buy a sd card. author: Ronda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020
review_content: This is by no means my first tablet however it is my first Kindle/Fire tablet. I have spent ages uses various cheapo tablets that were basically ok, but just ok. I've done a lot of soul searching recently and one of my biggest life changes has been to put a higher value on myself rather than letting someone else devalue me as a person, and one of the results of this shake up has been getting control over my own life financially. This means making decisions for myself in a way I haven't ever done before. So without someone else telling me some off brand knock off junk tablet was "good enough for what you do with it" I decided to go with the brand name product.The major difference is visual quality. Things look amazing! The touchscreen is very responsive. Everything about it is great. And it didn't actually cost more than the off-brand ones. Another benefit of going with a well known brand was that so many different cases are made to fit the Fire 7 perfectly so I was able to find a case I love that expresses a little personal flair. I don't think I will ever go back to Chinese knock-offs again.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2019
review_content: The All-New Fire 7 tablet is lighter and slightly smaller than my old Generation 3 Kindle Fire HD. However, the "updated" home screen and the clustering of all the app icons on the screen are distracting and outdated. I really miss the Gen 3 "carousel", which showed the apps/books/music most recently used. This new one shows the most recently used apps too, but they don't stand out as they did on the carousel. Battery life and speed of this All-New Fire 7 are supposed to be better than anything previous. I disagree. Battery life appears to be about the same or maybe less; speed - the All-New Fire 7 responds slower than my old Gen 3.  It's almost like I went back to the old Barnes & Noble Nook from years ago, just with more bells and whistles. Amazon didn't do users any favors with this "upgrade." I would NOT recommend this to a friend, and I would NOT buy it again.

review_content: This 9th generation Fire tablet is really nice. Screen quality and battery life much improved over the 5th generation, my other tablet. review_content: This is a great size for a Kindle reader. It runs a little slowly on an older processor I suppose but nothing terrible. The real problem is the unpredictable behavior. review_content: Nice job for a very reasonably priced little tablet except for 2 things. Fire models just don't seem to address an all-around reading need or a sunlight usage, if those are requirements for you.

author: Linda Hannon-Weber
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: I bought 3 of these for the grandchildren for Christmas. They love them, which is great because it frees up the TV for other viewing. One of the issues that I have, which is no fault of the actual device, is that I want to name them by my grandchildren's name on my amazon account, but Amazon has other ideas. They want to just number the devices 1, 2, 3, etc....I did change through Amazon and I hope I was successful in doing the same on the actual Kindle.  Also, the parental application leaves a lot to be desired. On one hand, they would like to charge you for this through some program. Don't do it...just change what they can and cannot see or if they need to purchase something, they have to ask you for your passcode. For me, that is easier than paying them to monitor the account. I just may not be device savvy.
title: Great value for the money
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: SageStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: mavis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
review_content: I traded my old Fire for this new, latest version.  The new is consistent with my old one, which I am happy about because it wasn't "improved" and made more complicated to use.  It doesn't seem to be much faster, and I am ok with that.  I expected the battery life to be better, but it hasn't been. It is average, same as my old Fire.  For my needs, this little tablet is fine for me.  Nothing eye-popping. There aren't' enough ads in our lives, it seems, so we must get more and more from our electronic devices.  I got one with the "without special offers" option, and it provides a smoother delivery of the screen you really want to see and use fewer interruptions for everything in the world you don't care about, want, or need.  It was worth the few extra dollars.  Mind you, there will still be ads!
title: consistent
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Zachary Stonebarger
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: One of the best tablets I've bought made by amazon in a long time. The battery life could be better but other than that it's one of the best ones on the market. It responds super fast, no lagging when doing tasks, and is super responsive to screen touch. I normally have to enable developer mode to make my previous fire tablets run fast but not this one. Right out of the box it's running like I set everything to .5 on animation scales. Best part of this tablet is like the others, you can put any class 10 SD card into it and format it as internal storage so you can download apps and games to the SD card. I would reccomend a 32GB. I have a 16GB currently in it with Facebook, messenger, netflix, hulu, showbox, 6 or 7 games and the google playstore on the SD card and I have 10GB left out of the 14GB i started out with. Buy a bigger SD card if you can. Amazon sells ones that are made for amazon fire tablets and they are the best ones I've owned.
title: Buy this tablet. It is worth every penny.
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
review_content: I've got to say im disappointed. The size is good and if all I'm doing is watching movies/shows or reading im solid. However, the moment I try to use or download apps, game over. Half of the apps I use like Uber, Home Depot, etc I can't get and when I try to use Facebook it uploads for a 10" screen so I only get a piece of the things I'm scrolling through. Your own amazon app dosen't load in full and cuts off less than half of trying to scroll through your home screen. It also freezes up more frequently than I think it should when trying to do simply normal operations like releasing the keyboard when I push the search bar or scrolling through Facebook marketplace. Maybe this can all be fixed easily with an update or there is already a solution I don't know about but as for now. I'm not recommending.
title: Disappointed
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 16 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: Fire 7Verified Purchase

author: Karl Knowles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
review_content: I've only had this Fire 7 for a few weeks but so far it's looking like I can officially say it's the best under $75 value for a portable MP3 capable device to use as a "Books on CD ripped to MP3 for road trips" player I've found... and I've tried a bunch.I honestly wont use Kindle or any other subscription service.  My local public library either has or can get just about anything I want to listen to.  Else I simply buy it outright, and then donate it to the library.All the cheap Chinese MP3 players are poorly constructed, all but impossible to read and typically fail with a year.  Quality MP3 players cost hundreds.  This mini tablet is easy to read, super simple to navigate and has way more than enough storage capacity via the SD card to hold my entire library.  My Car Talk collection alone is over 16GB!I've bundled this with a Bose Soundlink Mini II for the perfect portable package that I can take anywhere for awesome sound.Sure, I'll probably use some of the other features the device offers.  But for me it's primarily just an MP3 player.
title: Looking for an inexpensive yet robust MP3 player... here it is!
verified: Digital Storage Capacity: 32 GBOffer Type: Ad-SupportedColor: BlackStyle: with Case & Screen ProtectorVerified Purchase

author: Jason
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
review_content: I really enjoy this tablet. It integrates well and makes working smart devices easy. Good screen, streams stuff just fine. Overall great for the price point! But what’s that? Only 4 stars? This is because I also wanted to use this as an e-reader to replace an old old old one. The problem that I didn’t realize I would have is that amazon won’t allow you to download the Nook app. Nor is there anyway to convert files that doesn’t require a desk top and a free afternoon.I get wanting to be exclusive and all that but geez. I’d even pay a one time fee to convert titles I’ve already purchased just to save the headache. That would be way better than rebuying a few hundred bucks worth of material that I’ve spent the past 15 years on. So, 4 stars for that, until amazon buys Barnes and Noble and I can read all my old books conveniently.
title: Nice little tablet - but...
